description:
Very nice ambience in this place. I enjoy low lighting like there was here. A little pricey... but I guess that's probably part of the experience of being in SF; it being located in the heart of Chinatown. Had a mai tai and a whiskey sour. The mai tai, their specialty, was fantastic; the whiskey sour good but nothing special. Would come back again just for the chill spot and good cocktails. 

So the drinks were very expensive ($11 for a mai tai expensive), but the drinks were good enough and the awesome location and vibes inside bring it to 4 out of 5 stars.
author: Dakota C.

description:
This is a pretty cool touristy dive bar in the heart of San Francisco Chinatown.  You basically walk in, order a Mai Tai, and then get the fuck outta here.  It's part of a series of bars that you must hit when you are a tourist.  I decided to become a tourist in San Francisco, the city I grew up in, for the first time in my life.  I must admit, it was a blast.  I could see how tourist could find this gotham city to be charming with that cold annoying air I grew up with and to this day, I must admit actually love.

This bar is rather special because it is an Anthony Bourdain haunt.  As you walk in, there are photos of him having a drink here.  It's not all that avante garde, but I will say it did have a unique vibe about it.

It's true San Francisco bravado at its worst.   Having lived in San Francisco from when I was 12 until I was 28 years old, I never once walked into this bar.  Back when I was bar hopping, it was the triangle, Yancys in lower sunset, Rat & the Raven on union and few other haunts in Noe Valley and then if we were really feeling tacky, the Peppermill in Daly City.

For tourists, I strongly recommend that you hit this and then work your way to North Beach with the night cap at Buena Vista for an Irish Coffee.
author: Tony U.

description:
This place has a vibe. Half dive bar and half Asian version of tiki bar? 

Came in on a Tuesday night and were given a semi-warm welcome by the bartender who may also be the owner. The first half of the place was filled with paper lanterns and a fairly large Buddha in the corner. Very festive. The other half was more of a dive bar with secluded areas filled with groups of tables. Multiple TVs showing sports and m

 Lots of signs/banners for Mai tai so had to get it. For $11 it was a large glass filled to the brim but was too strong. Personally would prefer a little more pineapple juice.  Beers were pretty cheap also and got a bottle of tiger for $5. There were other beers even cheaper. 

Overall interesting place to chill with friends and get cheap drinks.
author: Nikkee A.

description:
It was a lovely first-day-of-Fall, (9/12/2018) that my friend & I went out on a whim and decided to have an SF adventure, which started out in Chinatown.  After taking in some of the sights, sounds (and even smells) amidst the hustle and bustle to be expected on a Saturday at the famed indoor/outdoor marketplace where you find all sorts of art shops, Chinese eateries, fresh produce stands and probably everything and anything in between, we noticed across the street a very curious looking cave-like structure that seemed that it may have been closed as no one was seen entering, nor leaving.  

Of course, that instantly brought out the inner curious cat I am and we immediately went over to check out the scene to see exactly what in the actual hell this place was.  When I describe the outside as a cave, I mean that.  Tucked between two gated-shut storefronts of some sort, it literally stood out as the exterior to me looked like it was designed to resemble an old stone entrance carved into a mountain.  As we approached, that was confirmed.  Mind you, we heard nothing inside from where we were standing at the entrance, we didn't see anything either entering or exiting, so we were slightly wary of what lay within.  I mean, it could've been a complete sh*thole, or something else... so what did we find within the bright red doors with golden trim?

There were so many people inside!  It was a dim-lit mecca of Asian decor, absolutely gorgeously ornate Chinese lanterns which adorned the ceilings and dragons on the walls which were painted in a rich, red & gold color scheme complete with an ornate shrine behind the bar area with several bamboo plants on either end mixed in with your typical light-up beer brand signs here and there, black scalloped with gold leafing wall accents as well as a small jukebox on the left side.  Nice & clean interior. 
 Plenty of tables in house and even a larger lounge chill spot on the far wall available for you to pick whichever area called to you to be seated.  Bruno Mars was heard overhead "This hit, that ice cold, Michelle Pfeiffer, that white gold..." The friendly bartender was the most adorable & sweet Asian lady who immediately greeted us and expertly created concoction after concoction at the bar.  

One of the very first things we noted when we walked in was none other than Anthony Bourdain had once popped in as there was a sign on the window with is photo!  How freaking cool is that?!  Had to research it to see more about it and confirmed 'tis true - as sighted in this article published in Miami New Times' entitled "Anthony Bourdain's The Layover: I Left My Liver In San Francisco (A Recap)", written by Laine Doss, 1/10/2012.

I quote, 
'20 hours left. It gets ugly from here.
More drinking is in order, as Tony heads to Li Po Bar in Chinatown, where he downs a few lethal Mai Tai's and plays liar's dice (which is the same as liar's poker).
Tony is drunk. And cursing. We hear, "holy shit these things are f**king lethal" and "I'm really glad I don't live in San Francisco because I would be f**king drinking here every night."'

Now, if THAT doesn't instantly get you Chinese Mai Tai intrigued, you clearly don't have a pulse & you should probably seek medical assistance, asap. I, of course opted for one of them & my friend was encouraged by a friendly (& tipsy) patron who was seated next to us to try the Lucky Buddha Beer. 

The Chinese Mai Tai went for $11 and was advertised all over the place as containing light and dark rum as well as Bacardi 151, a Chinese Liqueur (whatever the hell that is) & pineapple juice.  They had me at 151.  It was served partially blended and delivered just enough sweetness from the pineapple juice and a freaking KICK like no other Mai Tai I've ever been served.  I was an insta-fan over it!  If I stayed for another, I'm pretty sure I would've wanted yet another & I would've ended up dancing on the bar and belting out some cheesy karaoke song or would've found myself engaging in semi lewd behavior which would've ended me up in jail or on someone's lap.  Or both.  Needless to say, ORDER THIS!   

The Lucky Buddha Enlightened Beer came in the coolest emerald green beer bottle that literally had a smiling, joyful Buddha in 3-D on it!  My friend seemed to really like it and offered me a sip and it tasted like a very light & refreshing pale lager which was quite delicious.  I'm pretty sure my friend was feeling enlightened after finishing it.  Kinda surprised he didn't start changing "Om" and started levitating from his seat.  Another great find!

Bottom line:  It's the coolest, big-little bar packed to the hilt in gorgeous Chinese art where you can sit & chill and make friends with some of the usual's who frequent the place whilst getting shit-faced amidst your SF tourist playing!  It's a definite must, a funky little dive! I'd give it 4.5 stars, but I'm bumping it up to a full 5 since it was such a great accidental discovery!  

Get your Li Po on!
author: Jeanie B.

description: Exactly as I expected after seeing this featured in a bourdain show. As you walk in, there are lots of pics capturing the legendary man. The Chinese mai tai is the go to drink here and it is delicious. Extremely drinkable and dangerous. In addition to the main bar area there's another room tucked away in the back with some extra seating. Fun place to duck in for a strong drink in the heart of Chinatown.
author: Yin H.

description:
Li Po is run down. Li Po has seen better days. Li Po is a broken snowglobe of bright colors and hand made mai tai signs. 

But Li Po is full of magic. 

Cracking open the front door is like cracking open a fortune cookie of good times.   Order a Chinese Mai Tai, tip the bartender, and pay her a compliment for in an ocean of beautiful mediocrity, Li Po is a tarnished masterpiece.
author: Andrew W.

description: Second stop on our Chinatown bar crawl. The mai tai is the exact kind of drink your mother warned you about. It's the kind of drink where you start the conversation about work and end up pouring your feelings out and I mean that in the best way.
author: Sharvari J.

description: Wow, a really cool dive bar filled with awesome Chinese art and posters. The shrine is a site to behold and you wouldn't believe all the nooks and cranies you can checkout just from looking at the big red doors in front. The drinks are decent and its a nice place to kickback with a small group and grab some drinks. The prices are reasonable for San Francisco, nothing that tickles the tastebuds but grab a beer and kickback.
author: Taylor Z.

description:
A divey dive bar in Chinatown...  who knew?  Apparently a celebrity once came here too. 

If you like dive bars, then this might be the place for you. It's everything you expect, filled with a host of interesting characters. Definitely a locals haunt.

They're famous for their "Chinese Mai Tais" which I was not impressed with. Made from mix, juice and blended. Sugary sweet and icy, more gimmicky than anything, not strong and $11 a piece. 

It's a good meeting spot but you can do better.
author: Dan K.

description:
Hidden gem in Chinatown!  Was there on Chinese New Years and looked a little sketchy at first but had seen a picture on the front that Anthony Bourdain had been so peeked in and it had a cool almost Tiki Bar vibe from the 50's going on.  It seemed their most famous drink is the $11 Chinese Mai Tai and the majority of people were ordering one.

It has Dark and Light Rums, 151 Rum and Chinese Rum and some Pineapple juice.  My friend had 3 of them and was pretty wasted afterwards.  I had a taste and it was pretty good, but opted for the $5 beer selections.  Definitely worth a visit for locals and tourist's alike.
author: James H.

description:
This is the old Buddha lounge now located a block ish away from the  buddha lounge yet keeps the name over the door. Welcome to Chinatown it where things can get you know a little bit bizzare. 

Parking is street only which means there is no parking. This is one of the most pedestrian friendly cities in the world however, so there are lots of ways to get here that do not involve driving. 

As I said earlier this local divey spot goes so far out past bizarre that it transcends the description. i mean just saying that this is an odd unique spot, doesn't even begin to cover what this dark, drink and art filled refuge from a prior era is. The lighting-what there is of it-is heavy on red lantern thingys. Once you've a drink and your eyes have adjusted a bit you start to notice things. Like the full temple size shrine to prince siddartha hidden-to the extent that you can hide something so large-behind a corner of the bar. The temple dragon on the ceiling. The so dark you can barely make them out mogul murals. The 1900's style friezes and cornices. The certification from the president annotating that the chinese mai tai's here are unique and copy written. The 1940's style beer ads on the way to the restroom, and the basement storage area that is the restroom itself, all of which look dirty even though they might not  actually be as grimy as they appear. Seating ranges from 1950's vinyl bar stools, to garage style table/chair combos to cozy little nooks, all of which have a non standard look. 

So yeah all that with some of the best-and hardest hitting-chinese mai tai's evah? Yeah that's five stars right there. The beer selection is okay, and yeah they've a full range of spirits but really the go to drink here is the mai tai. It's made with Chinese whisky and it's magical. The service is of the don't ask don't tell style. Prices are on the low side-happy hour three dollar beer? Yes please! but if you are using a card it's a twenty dollar minimum, which is roughly two mai tai's, a happy hour beer or two and the tip. No biggie, but you better be sharing with  friend 'cause in this bar two mai tai's is a lot to handle.

 A solid chinatown dive bar experience any way you cut it.
author: Steven W.

description:
We came in not because of Anthony Bourdain but because a friend of mine who lived in SF for a long time said it was great and that I had to try the Chinese Mai Tai.

Coming in the place I didn't think much.  A dive bar is a dive bar.  I don't care that the decorations are weird and kitschy or that there isn't a lot of seating.  I usually don't expect to sit at a bar like this on a Saturday night.  

We obviously ordered the Chinese Mai Tai.  I don't know what to think.  Yes, the bugger is strong but that's basically what it was.  Strong.  No discernible flavor and it was really icy.  It was not worth the $12 for a drink that I would have made in high school.
author: Christina R.

description:
An Anthony Bourdain approved San Francisco Institution.

Old, Dirty and Delightful just like... oh never mind. The Chinese Mai-Tai is a concoction created some odd years ago from some odd ingredients to make a sugary, boozy bomb of a drink. The place is nasty, but that's why we love it.

Don't be a pompous hipster and go down the route of 'there wasn't 20 artisanal ingredients in the Mai Tai - The bartender didn't have tattoos and a beard'. Live a little.
author: Christopher D.

description: Popped in to Li Po after a lunch of Szechuan noodles in Chinatown. I didn't realize it's across from Buddha Lounge which I had visited the day prior. Nice bar hopping opportunities! I came here for the Chinese mai tai of course and to take a pic of the Anthony Bourdain pic... Rest in Peace Mr. Bourdain. There was a steady stream of tourists that came in probably for the same reason I did. It's a pretty big bar with a back room of pool tables and an upstairs that I didn't explore and don't know if it's off limits to patrons. The Chinese mai tai is less mai tai and more.. lychee slushie. It was good though if not very strong. I think orders under $20 have to be paid in cash so prepare for that. It was a nice spot to stop in after walking around Chinatown for an hour or so. I imagine it could get pretty rowdy at night. I'd definitely come back next time I'm in town.
author: Emily B.

description:
COME HERE!  If you can find it that is!  The location is non-descript and not well marked.  

The Mai Tai was pretty dang good and this is exactly why people frequent this place.  While I could tell that they are no longer using Bacardi 151 (bc its discontinued), and substituting with a cheap tasting over-proofed rum they still managed to taste better than some others that I've had recently. 

The bartender on staff was extremely friendly.  Chatted with us about the different types of beers we've never seen/tasted before.

Did you know that Anthony Bourdain came here in 2012?!?!

Check it out!
author: Lea B.

description:
This is the definition of a kitschy Chinatown dive bar who's claim to fame is the CHINESE mai tai. Who knew there was such a variation? Or maybe its real claim to fame is a visit from Anthony Bourdain back in 2012. 

Came here per the suggestion of a bartender at nearby Devil's Acre. Keep in mind that these are completely two different establishments and two types of fun.

I wasn't expecting much upon entering the premise. It's a discreet dive bar in the middle of a random Chinatown street, which is surprisingly calm at night. There wasn't much signage outside of the place except for a hand written sign denoting "CHINESE Mai Tais".

We entered and the crowd was mellow and sparse, but it was a Sunday afterall and who boozes on a Sunday?!?!?! Us.

Almost all of the patrons drank Mai Tais, how could you not? There was signage on the walls that highlighted the drink's ingredients although many of them were crossed off. I guess you can say this is a mystery concoction and you never know what you're going to get.

The decor was very stereotypical Chinese. There were dragons and the walls were gilded with chinese wallpaper - although there was a booth and the designs seemed more thai than chinese. 

There was a middle aged chinese man manning the bar. We suspected that the random playlist filled with a mix of Top 40, hip hop, EDM, and alternative was his. Needless to say all of the songs were singable and recognizable. 

I had a surprisingly pleasant time here despite this place being everything that I wouldn't typically enjoy. First off, who orders mai tais at a bar nowadays unless you're at a tiki bar?! And I'm not sure what exactly makes THESE mai tais "chinese" but they tasted delicious and buzzy. Imagine a random drink filled with random booze and a hint of pineapple. 

If you're looking for complete randomness and feel like being a lil experimental with your bar hopping, give this place a visit.
author: Connie M.

description:
I work for the hospitality industry here in San Francisco and stopped in to look at the lounge on 8/4/18 to see if it could accommodate a large party for an upcoming work celebration. My husband and I walked in to the back and as soon as we got there, we were approached by a woman with braces asking what we were doing. We had just walked in and were not loitering. I told her we were just checking out the place and she said "it's not nice to come in just to look. We get too many tourists in here." I excused ourselves and left.
I noticed other reviews about the same issue. I also noticed a hand written sign outside that says Anthony Bourdain has visited there. If they don't want "tourists" is there, then take down the sign. I also wrote an email directly to the bar and received this repose, please see below: 

Welcome to have a drink even just a soda and stay there to look, in stead of just checking and look around and said just looking, have you even realize why the bartender will say that to you, I'm so sure not only you, there is a tone of tourist and people come over and say "just take a look". How ignoring, disturbing, you just think yourself, you free people not nice to you, have you ever thing why people will react like that? You bring people or large party here or not, we don't mind, again this is not the place to come and said "checking out"

So do not give this place business! They are rude and unprofessional! I will never go there and I will tell everyone I know not to go there.
author: Elvia D.

description:
Finally! It's been maybe four years since I've been wanting to come here and try their Mai Tais. That's really all there is, 6 beers and Mai Tai for $11. It's cash only here so stack up.

They make their Mai Tai blend with their special hidden ingredients and gently pulsate it on the blender for a light slushy texture. Yes, they're totally worth it! I also suggest ordering their Buddah Beer which comes in this beautiful glass Buddha-shaped bottle and their Tiger beer from Thailand. The Tiger beer is brown sugary, sweet, but mildly bold at the same time. Beers are all $5! Their service here is great too with a family of maybe 5 just working all together. 

There are plenty of seats so make sure to grab one quick!  A hidden secret is to also walk downstairs towards the restrooms and follow the path as you enter through a whole different lounge area with a bar! There's great music and almost gives off this patio club vibe lol! Take your group of friends for a more relaxing and more spacious atmosphere down in the bottom area!
author: Allister D.

description: Came here because, well...Anthony Bourdain. But we were disappointed. Me and my friend got mai tais, but they were super sugary and came out super quick, which leads me to think they were made beforehand and just poured when we ordered. Also, the bartender kept telling us we could check out the downstairs so we walked down. First off, don't fall because we both tripped (sober) because the stairs are super slanted. Second, it was sketch downstairs so we walked down and walked right back up. Go if you're in the area to say you tried the mai tais, but don't go out of your way. You're not missing out on anything special.
author: Ashveen S.

description:
Dive bar at it's finest If Anthony Bourdain likes it we have to go Try their mai tais you can't even taste the alcohol which can be dangerous It comes
mixed with a secret Asian alcohol not sure what Definitely a spot to hit up if you're looking for a stiff drink while strolling through Chinatown
author: Malia P.

description: Interesting place, dropped in to try the first Chinese Mai Tai, taste great. not the best interior, but is something worth exploring if you are stopping by the China town area.
author: Vic S.

description:
Yaaas!! The mai tais here are a must try! Three different kinds of rum, Chinese liquor, and pineapple juice all mixed together. Who knew such a combination could be so tasty yet so potent?

Best advice is to just take it slow when drinking this. Or if you are weak like my friend who blacks out after three angry orchards, you should share this drink with a stronger person. ^^
author: Tiffany H.

description: Rude, obnoxious staff. Bartender tried multiple times to overcharge me, and verbally abused me and my wife when we tried to explain their mistake. They also confiscate IDs when you open a tab. You couldn't pay me to go back to this place. There's plenty of SF bars where they dont treat you like this
author: John E.

description:
My girlfriend wanted to come here after hearing that this place had a pretty intriguing "Chinese" Mai Tai.  

The decor was fine. Nothing special.  Just another Chinatown bar with not-enough seating.  Luckily we were able to find a seat after just a couple minutes.

We both ordered the famous mai tai and to be honest it was nothing special.  It was much too sweet (shame on me for ordering a Mai Tai to begin with) and just tasted like someone poured canned pineapple juice into rum.

It was unspectacular and I probably won't be coming back.
author: Nick D.

description: Fun bar, strong drinks. Get the mai tai. You won't taste the alcohol and but you will feel it after a few. Came in around 10pm and it wasn't too busy yet and was able to grab the sort of hidden table in the small room which was nice. My dad would love the decor here. Pretty cool.
author: Sam V.

description:
My friend told me about this place and that I had to pay it a visit for the Mai Tai

It was a dive bar with a good atmosphere but unfortunately my wife didn't feel the vibe

Mai Tai was good. I would return, but with my guy friends, not my wife
author: Timmy T.

description: Funny Chinese five bar, go to the hidden room downtown if you want to dance. $11 Mai Tai's are strong, drink with caution! Come here for a unique after work happy hour with your coworkers.
author: Miranda M.

description:
Why Anthony Bourdain went here, i'll never know. The claim to fame for this dive bar in china town is the mia tai.

BTW - there is no original Chinese version - that's BS marketing. Or maybe how they hype their substandard version.

 Ehhhhh. i make way better at home. Over priced fruit juice.
author: Matthew B.

description:
Checked this place out because I heard a lot about the bar Anthony Bourdain visited in Chinatown ! 
It's a dive bar known for the Mai Tais. They have one person behind the bar and it's a small cozy space. Almost 95% of the people drank the cocktails and I tasted one too. It was very sweet and tasted like pineapple juice. My friends who visit often all got the signature drink while I got the beer ($5.00). 

Note : There is a $20.00 minimum for cards here so be aware. I had a difficult experience with this. 

The other drink selection ( like wine etc) was very limited and not great ( except for the cocktails). They do serve Chinese beers so that was cool. 
Overall, I was ok ok about this place.
author: Shivani B.

description: This is where you go at the end of a night in SF for a last-call Chinese Mai Tai.    Been many times.  Hit Buddha Bar nearby while you're on Grant Avenue.
author: Mark R.

description:
Like everyone else, I came here on recommendation for the Chinese Mai-Tai. 

I'm not sure why, but I was under the impression it would be a bit spicy or that it had Sriracha in it. That was a false notion, but the drink was still great! Just as advertised! 

The place isn't much of a looker, but c'mon y'all, it's a dive bar. Get over yourselves. I came in the middle of the afternoon on a Wednesday so it was pretty empty, but it definitely looks like the sort of place that comes alive after dark. 

I'd give it a second go if I were to visit again. 

One thing to note: Cash Only.
author: Katherine B.

description: It's a dive bar no doubt but the mai tais and chill environment are great for getting together with friends! You never know what kind of crowd you are going to walk into and that makes it fun. Plus the drinks are tasty and strong. Have had some great memories (and loss of memories) at this place :)
author: Ann H.

description: Came to this place for the famous Mai Tais and since Anthony Bordain and other people have been here. It was very overpriced at $11 per mai tai. It was good, but not blow your socks off. The bartender was very nice and attentive.
author: Alyssa M.

description: This is an absolutely classic Chinese Dive Bar.  The atmosphere is amazing in a dive bar kind of way.  Drinks are strong and well made.  The Mai Tai is a must have--the Chinese liquor is a killer.  Highly recommend while you are in Chinatown.  Not for everybody, but if you like an occasional dive bar, this is a great one with tons of old school crust.
author: B W.

description: If you like cocktails with spice then you will like this place. You only need one Mai Tai to spice it up.  Any more then that, is just crazy! It was a pretty cool place to hang in the Bay area.
author: Nancy R.

description:
I'm an SF native. I have included Li Po on my bar crawl through San Francisco for decades. That ended last night. We usually start in downtown at The Starlight Room, and go to Irish Bank, Buddha Bar, and Li Po. It is a fun walking tour of the touristy parts of town for my visitors. 

But last night, I walked into the Li Po with three still-thirsty visiting friends, and pointed to the giant lantern, as I looked for a place for all of us to sit. The bartender lit in to me and told me to get the hell out and stop running tours in the bar. I said, "Excuse me?!!" So she just started yelling at me about coming in and not drinking--I mean literally, before we had a chance to all four get into the door! So I asked her if she thought I still wanted a drink after being greeted that way, and asked how the hell she knows what customers want--I mean seriously--you kind of have to stop and point out the charm, since while the Li PO is "charming", it kinda gives off a "Shithole--RUN AWAY" vibe when you first walk in. She yelled back, "YOU WANT DRINK--ORDER DRINK!" at me. I told her to (in no polite terms, as I'd gotten none from her), where she could stick her drinks. Meanwhile, my friends had turned and walked out--they won't shop where they aren't welcome. And that while I'd come there for years, that was the end of it. The tech bros thought it was all so funny--they got drinks and a show at our expense. 

She seems to like them better than people who think old businesses in SF deserve the attention, not the hipster crap oozing all over the city. But she'll soon find out that when they decide they want a condo and real bar there....she'll be less entertaining. And from the other Yelp reviews of Li Po, I guess I'm lucky my wallet and phone weren't lifted off of me during the altercation.

I recommend the Buddha Bar across the street. That place is an equal institution without the discourteous vitriol. And they understand how to make people want to spend money in their establishment. Hospitality.
author: Colleen M.

description:
I chuckle at the original "Chinese Mai Tai," because I'm not really sure what that even means!  Bar-hopping to Li Po, my coworkers and I could immediately sense that the location had a lot of historical background.  The decor seems very ancient but also has a lot of character to it.  We only tried the Chinese Mai Tai and grabbed a table in the back corner!  Although the bar does seem old, I'd say they were throwing some great R&B/Top 40s hits of the 00s.  This was awesome!  I'd give this a 3.5 stars just for the music.

Overall, not a bad place to be in the wee hours of the night in Chinatown.  From my knowledge, there isn't that much to do in this area at night, so this could be it!  Also Anthony Bourdain was here, so at least it has some street cred?
author: Jana L.

description:
They had me at Chinese Mai Tai, so this tiki nerd had to see what the fuss was about.  While I wouldn't say the Li Po Cocktail Lounge was anything like a true tiki bar, but it had a great dive bar feel to it.

Me, being the tiki nerd that I am, I have gotten particular about how I like a Mai Tai.  If it contains orange juice, pineapple juice, grenadine, or coconut rum, it isn't a true Mai Tai in my opinion, and sometimes the combination of those things, make for a sickly, sweet tropical concoction. I'm sure there are some people out there that like that, but not me.  

So I had my reservations about a Chinese Mai Tai, but since I was there in Chinatown, I was going to have one, good or bad.  In actuality, the Chinese Mai Tai was not bad at all.  A bit on the sweet side, but not too much.  Whatever is in the Chinese liquor they add, helps balance out the drink.
author: Amanda W.

description: Hands down a must stop spot for a Chinese Mai Tai. The ambiance makes me think of what a Shanghai dive bar would look like once upon a time when opium dens were in their prime. They have a large amount of seating with some tucked away spots if you wanted to get together with friends and get some work done. The next time I'm in town I will be going back.
author: Nicole D.

description:
Great bartender, great Chinese mai tais, horrible customers. Anthony bourdain recommended this place (and so, of course, everyone comes here). The decor is cool and dirty and I love it, but I can see where some people think it could be a little bit of a health hazard. 

-Cash only
-Tip your bartender
-Don't be an idiot
author: Kay E.

description: Bartender had a slick pompadour and made a mean mai tai. Cheap as far as quality SF bars go. Lively decor. Endearingly seedy environment. Will return.
author: George L.

description: As numerous people stated, yep it is a dive bar in the middle of china town. I'll add it's too cramped, way too small, way too loud, and the Mai Tai's are WAY too strong. So if you like people, a little crazy, and are looking for a night to make some I can't believe I did that stories, go here for a few rounds.This place reminds me of growing up in the Midwest having basement parties where the decor of the basement is random mismatched furniture and the music is too loud and everyone's drink is too strong. Total nostalgia, if the mood is right I'll be back
author: Morgan S.

description: This place is legit!  In the middle of Chinatown, you get the entire experience.  The bar tender def knows what she was doing, mixing up the world famous Chinese mai tai.  I wish I had more alcohol tolerance, to have drank another!  Sadly I didn't.   Can't wait to come back for another two or three rounds!
author: A M.

description: Great place for drinks but the Chinese bartenders will tell you to keep it down if you are too quiet because they think you are scaring the customers away.
author: Nestor R.

description:
If you're looking for a kitschy, stereotypically "Chinatown" place straight out of the '50s or '60s, then Li Po fits the bill perfectly. The ambiance and decor recall a long-lost era when everything Chinatown was seen as being exotic and slightly seedy, if not outright sultry. Imagine smoke-filled rooms with suited, bow-tied businessmen sporting Clark Gable mustaches being served by svelte, immaculately coiffed Chinese ladies in form-fitting cheongsams.

Alas, such an era is long gone, but Li Po manages to stick around. While the establishment just oozes history and an aura of glory days far in the past (even its website is one heck of a trip back to the Netscape/AltaVista/Lycos era of the internet!!!), these days it's pretty much a low-key dive bar that's known for its mai tais.

The mai tais are indeed good, plus they're cheap. This place is certainly worth a visit just for the conversation-starting throwback, like in a super low-key first date over drinks. Word to the wise, however: if you're sober enough to notice large bugs of a certain kind lurking in all the nooks and crannies of the walls and decor here, you might want to think twice about lingering too long.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Li Po Lounge is a quintessential Chinatown spot.

I love that it hasn't changed through out the years. Dive bar for sure. Definitely needs remodeling. But don't. Lol. The big-ass paper lantern near the bar shows some DEFINITE wear and tear. (Like a literal tear.)  I like you just the way you are - please don't change!

Touristy AF especially after airing on The Layover. I still like it though. Their mai tais are on point and not too sweet. (I hate stuff that has tons of food coloring or artificial sweetener! That's not the case here though :D)

At $11 for a pretty stiff drink, you can't go wrong!
author: Emily C.

description:
This place is gnarley. It's mad dark inside, there's quirky decor all over the place and you're kind of like where the f-ck am I? But I suppose that is its charm.

Onto the Mai Tais. I had not eaten since lunch. It was nearly 8pm. My sister was visiting. We did the China Town thing, and then decided to do the Li Po thing. 

I had like 4 sips of it and started to feel it and gave the rest to my sister. I couldn't! 

It was soo strong. Delicious? Yes. But so strong for little me who was starving.

I'll come back again for more mai tais when I can handle it.
author: Priti K.

description: Wow. The Chinese Mai Tai is killer, major buzz, definitely a must in Chinatown SF. But be worn this is a small dive bar,Bartender was most gracious.  Start here and then Rome Chinatown feeling tipsy!!
author: Will L.

description: Anthony Bourdain told us about LiPo and their famous (and original) Chinese Mai Thai.   5 Liquors + pineapple juice = dangerous.  So tasty I sucked it down and wanted another.  Bartender was awesome.  She took our photo and gave my wife some shopping tips.
author: Adam B. J.

description: Great mai tais ($11) in this hole in the wall! They were delicious. There is a $20 minimum for cards. We sat in the back corner, which was pretty warm, but they have fan blowing. After we all went downstairs for a bathroom break, we noticed a hallway and went to check it out. There is another bar downstairs and the decor is very different from upstairs. It's ACed and has string lights around for decoration. We'll defintely hang out downstairs the next time we're back.
author: Teresa N.

description: The cocktails are not very notable and the place smelled. It's a little too divey for me.
author: Chris S.

description:
Does anyone else look around in confusion when the words CHINESE MAI TAI are mentioned?

You're basically looking at a rum-conction of sweetness and daiquiri-style drank. It's not a traditional mai tai, hence the words chinese mai tai. I did not care for that drink at all, but just by looking around the colorful and dimly lit "tropical Asia" vibes space, I could tell why so many people thought the lounge itself was pretty cool.

Sure, it's definitely a ringer for a tourist trap. But the ambiance is so old school and the catchphrase of "Anthony Bourdain was here" makes Li Po a special Chinatown bar. I didn't like how sweet the chinese mai tai was, so I went with their tsingtao beer. I'm a beer gal, so I was happy chillin' with my beer. I heard that the mai tai was VERY strong. The only bartender was mixing a bunch of different rums on Lunar New Year's parade when we went out, and blended the drink like crazy so I'm not surprised. There were some cocktail waitresses walking around offering tastings of the beer and handing out promotional items like flashing sunglasses and what not. The place has character alright, but remember to bring cash and a small-ish group cuz the space isn't that large.
author: Jodi H.

description:
You have to stop here in China town. 

My boyfriend and I saw an awful hand-drawn sign out front of the bar and wondered if we had reached the correct bar that had been recommended to us by friends. 

Once inside, the bar was packed! Not only was it packed, but literally every bar patron had a Mai Tai. The old Chinese decor and tattered lanterns only add to the quirky and unique Li Po Lounge experience. The Mai-Tais were exquisite, however, the saucy attitude of the bartender is what makes this place only four stars.

 I get it--- you have hundreds of tourists buying your Mai Tais. But part of customer service is not make the customer feel like a burden.
instagram: @glowrae
author: Glory F.

description: It's definitely a dive bar. The Chinese Mai Tai has a weird taste but my wife liked the Electric Lemonade (which is basically a Blue Hawaii but with rum instead of vodka).  Glad I went but won't be back for the Mai Tai. Might try some of the other cocktails.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Cue the liposuction joke.  I bet the bartenders appreciate it as just much as when a tourist asks:  "What is in your 'Secret Chinese Liquor'?"  

Did you know about the Chinese Mai Tai here?  If you don't immediately raise your hand, don't worry, you are not alone.  This is actually one of the better kept secrets on Grant Street.  (Tourists - Grant Street is what you think Chinatown is all about, although it's not.  Grant Street is souvenir shops, mediocre restaurants that REALLY try to pull you in, and basic consumerism.  I went to China and got a California license plate with my name on it.  ...sigh.  At least it was cheap.)  

Alright, not every place is that.  Li Po is a (you know what's coming) Hidden Gem.  Maybe not so hidden since Mr. Bourdain stopped by and got lit.  Maybe having a few of the famous Chinese Mai Tai's was why he later went on to proclaim Sam's home of the "Greatest Burger Ever!!!"  (BTW, it is good, but Bourdain had some kind of goggles on ... not that there's anything wrong with that.)

The Mai Tai is pretty darn good.  Dark Rum, Light Rum, 151 (STRONG Rum), Secret Chinese Liquor and Pinneapple Juice.  Blend it.  Serve it in a plastic hurricane glass with no garnish.  It's tasty and strong.  And, I haven't found anything quite like it.  $9.  If you have two, you may not make the best decisions as the evening progresses.  Just a warning.  The rest of the place is sorta divey-shiek.  Not a lot of frills, but some cool decor and a good mix of folks from a range of different spots.  It's a little rough around the edges, but it is cool.  I'd probably go up to 5 stars if there was more than one good view of the TV and if they had a few decent beers on tap - bottles only for $4.50.  At least they have Buddha Beer.
author: Adam S.

description:
We came all the way to SF got a hotel and everything just to try out this original Mai tai and I'm so bummed to say it was super mediocre :(
Boo I know. It was 95% ice and we didn't catch any sort of buzz at all. We took a chance and went across the street to the Buddah bar or something and literally had the strongest yummiest drink ever took an hour to finish it lol. Maybe we just got a bad batch who knows.
author: VANESSA H.

description: All you need to know about this place is the stairs to the bathroom have a big pad at the bottom on the wall. As in so many people have drunkly stumbled down the stairs they had to put in a pad to keep people from braking though the wall. A drunk buffer, always a good sign.
author: James M.

description:
Had the best mai tais here!!
Super chill atmosphere
Always a stop whenever I'm in SF!
author: Jazmine R.

description: My friend showed me this spot after dinner one night. We showed up and the bouncer was very friendly and social! A nice welcoming! The bar is very hole in the wall from the outside but very spacious inside! Not many people, people were mostly in and out after their mai tai. Obviously, got the mai tai- $11 each, cash only. It was very tasty! (Be careful;)) you cannot taste all the rum, mostly pineapple juice. You can easily get very drunk off these. THEY ALSO SELL TIGER BEER! I loved the vibe of the bar! Music was great but not too loud. Also the bar wasn't crazy college rager, more laid back with good people. I will definitely be coming back here again!
author: Marcie A.

description: Wow, talk about disappointing.. We came here for the world famous Chinese mai tai and were pretty disappointed with the results. While the bartender bragged about four shots of light and dark rum, 151 and a Chinese liquor.. We could barely taste any alcohol. Just the mild hint of turpentine (I'm guessing that was the 151).) There was absolutely no way we drank 4 shots in that one drink. I guess maybe a shot and a half and if you're lucky you might get two shots total. The atmosphere was kind of grungy looking, definitely a dive bar for sure. The bar was pretty dead on a Friday evening, And the only drink we saw anybody with was the mai tai. Not sure what Anthony Bourdain was thinking when he described this drink as a killer, then again, Bourdain was already pretty drunk when he got to this bar. I'm not regretting our visit, we saw an episode of Bourdains show that featured some of the best places to eat and drink in San Francisco so at least we have a fun story to share.
author: Prescila B.

description: Come in for the history and the gimmick, but don't expect good drinks. The mai tais are watered down and have mysterious "Chinese liquor". The bartender wouldn't tell us- for all we know it could have been anything. Cool little spot to chill in China Town though- very touristy.
author: Tika O.

description: I've been here several times when I'm in the Chinatown area. I always remember about that random bar with a tasty version of the mai tai! Good spot to stop by to just grab a drink. It's nothing fancy, but don't forget there is a downstairs area.
author: Nicole A.

description: This is a fun spot.  Mai Tais are great although a bit sugary.  Great vibe as its a little dingy, but not too bad.  Good experience I would recommend to everyone in SF.  Cash only, but Chase is right there.  This place is awesome.
author: Justin S.

description: Great place to get your Chinese mai thai on! Came with the hubs while visiting SF and came across this fun bar with great decor. I liked the friendliness of the staff and the fun music selection. Good for large groups! Cheers.
author: Stella C.

description: I always seem to get here with at least 3 beers already in me, so I waver on getting the super strong Mai Tai, being that there are no backs on the stools.  Was here on a Friday this time and it was full to the brim with millennials in their work clothes. Always a great time and love the obstacle course getting to the bathrooms in the basement. Pretty much coed.
author: Paul S.

description:
this is exactly as I would expect a bar in the midst of San Francisco's China Town to look.  Filled with hipsters and ... damn it hipsters. 

The Mai Thai was pretty good, and overall I would say this is a pretty sweet joint to hang out if you don't really have any plans for the evening.  Maybe even get some dinner before heading over.

Thank you Anthony Bourdain for putting this on the hipster map. not really.  

P.S. Tip - bring cash, it's a universal fact that chinatowns only accept cash, but but for you hipsters who dont know.
author: Anthony C.

description: Wayne, best bartender ever. Thank you for the excellent service. Will definitely be back as long as Wayne is working.
author: Jess D.

description: This place has a dive-bar vibe. The bartender was friendly. We saw a sign for "original Chinese Mai Tai" so we decided we'd give it a try. Usually I hate Chinese liquor because it tastes HORRIBLE. But, the pineapple really masked the taste of the liquor. I wouldn't say it's the best Mai Tai I've had, but considering it used Chinese liquor--it's alright.
author: Mary V.

description:
For a Mai Thai its as one would expect, however, it definitely packs a punch 
Gets crowded so if you have a large party it will be hard to all sit together 
Cash only 

Overall Thoughts

I feel a little closer to Mr. Bourdain now....even if its only .00001%
author: Eddie W.

description:
The famous chinese mai tais. I've heard so much about them, but honestly, I'm not a huge fan of rum, so I've never been in a hurry to check out Li Po. Plus, Chinese liquor? Every run in with it has left me in pain. See why I wasn't in a hurry to try one?

A group of us decided to do a Chinatown bar crawl of sorts on Friday, August 7th. Li Po was our second stop. We dropped by at 7pm for a round (well, more like two) of drinks. We found a table in the back.

*Chinese mai tai: whaler's dark rum, Castillo light rum, bacardi 151 rum, chinese liquor, pineapple juice ($9)
*Lucky buddha ($4.50)

The mai tai was okay. I actually thought it was weak. I mostly tasted pineapple with a hint of alcohol. But this is coming from a girl that always asks for her drink extra stiff! I've been known to ask for a double or even a triple when it comes to mixed drinks. The buddha beer was good. One of my gfs enjoyed the mai tai, so I gave her mine and ordered the beer instead.

I liked the vibe of the bar, but it can feel a little touristy due to the exposure they've gotten. I normally like these kinds of bars when only the locals hang out there. I still had a fun time though.

Remember to bring the dollar bills. The bar is cash only.
author: Elena N.

description: Our bar tender Jackie was AWESOME! I've never had a Chinese Mai Tai and we came here to try them. It was good! One of my friends with me has had a Mai Tai before and she said she liked the other but this one is much better!
author: Tracey T.

description: Cane here yesterday around 5:00 for a quick drink before heading to another bar that didn't open till 6:00. I was the only one out of our group of three that got a drink. So here is why I give this place one star my friend went outside cause his phone reception was not that good inside and when he came back in to where we where sitting the bartender walk up to him asking him can I help you    and ask him for ID and still after the ID was shown she still asked if he wanted a drink over and over trying to pressure him to buy something he just water for now and she said water is $2.00,  me and my GF where just sitting there watching this go on, after a little bit I finally tell her we're all together cause I already purchased a drink, so she finally walked back behind the bar. I won't come back here no more for any drinks for how the bartender treated my friend and she has been the bartender here for as long as I've been coming here.
author: Dennis T.

description:
The bartender made a point to tell us that the bar had been open for 79 years, but the decor did not hide that. Everything seemed out dated and the signage were all hand written. The bartender was very nice but too overly friendly. I came to catch up with some coworkers while visiting but instead of being able to socialize with each other it was like we were entertaining him. 

They are also cash only, which seems to be a thing in China town.
author: Shannon F.

description: After long walk to Coit Tower. We stopped in Chinatown strip to drink some Mai Tai. The drink was simply AMAZING! The cost for a Mai Tai was $11; this is the best Mai Tai I ever had. Ambiance is cozy and bartender is super nice.
author: Diba T.

description: Fun old dive bar, worth a visit. Bartender was very affable, beer was really cold- just the way I like it. Booze was clearly watered down. If the faded out price tags on the bottles aren't enough of a clue they're being refilled for pouring, don't serve an Irish woman a shot of Jameson & expect her not to notice.
author: Susan C.

description: If you're reading this review, you have either already had the Chinese Mai Tai, and want to see what everyone else thought about it, or you're from Michigan and have a trip planned to SF in a few weeks, and want to see if that place from Anthony Bourdain's show is really that great. Well, tourist, I say pop your head in here and try at least one Chinese Mai Tai. Or share one with your wife and also get your normal shot and a beer. If you don't like sweet drinks, you might not like this drink, or won't be able to get more than one down. I'm not a big sweet drink fan, but I actually really like the Chinese mai tais. I think they're fun. I have been to Li Po a few times, and in my experience, the strength of the alcohol in their infamous drink depends on the bartender. The best one I ever had was on a week night, right after work, when it was pretty dead inside. The bartender was a lady, and the mai tais were strong. But my friends and I noticed that when an older man got behind the bar, the drinks were sweeter with less alcohol. Dive bar environment, a bit kitschy, can get crowded on Friday/Saturday nights, and kind of diverse crowd. If you're visiting SF, you're probably going to go to Chinatown anyways, so take 30 minutes of your vacay and 11 of your dollar bills, and give a Chinese Mai Tai a chance. You just might go home with some interesting stories to share... or a hangover ;)
author: Liz M.

description: Went in for one drink...Mai Tai! It was perfection. Stop in to this historic place and have one for yourself. #happy
author: Teddie P.

description: Execellent deliciously sweet Mai Tai. The decoration and design of place give you a feeling of Chinese bars from the old days. One of the oldest bar in Chinatown.
author: Huong L.

description: Their Mai Tai's are very popular and are known for their "liquid crack" (ingredients is just Chinese Liqueur, Pineapple Juice, Dark Rum, Light Rum, and Barcardi 151 Rum). It tastes sweet and Anthony Bourdain loves it! I only wish they wouldn't put so much ice (half the glass was ice). This place looks kind of sketchy, like one of those secret establishments that the mafia runs from movies. Definitely recommend coming here.
author: Vicki L.

description: Had one of my first dates here with my now 5 year long lady friend ;) and mother of my child. Only remember good things. Small place, open late, and super chill. It's a good memory
author: Kaveh M.

description:
The reviews on here are baffling.

"I had a great time, drinks were good and it was fun." - two stars
"Mai tais aren't real but I can somehow make them better at home." - two stars
"I went here to see a Chinatown dive bar but it was too much of a dive bar for me." - one star
"Bourdain came here and that guy sucks." - three stars

It's a Chinatown dive bar. It's not TGI Fridays, they're not gonna sing you happy birthday and it's probably gonna smell like old spilled drinks. And the drink they're famous for is huge, sweet, and has roughly the same octane as race gas. And trust me when I say you're not gonna be the only tourist there. But guess what - it's fun, it's unique, and it's definitely worth a 2 buck Uber from your Union Square hotel just for the experience alone.
author: Jack L.

description: My husband has been telling me about this bar for years and we finally went together! We both had two of their famous Chinese Mai Tais and they were delicious. I like that they add a twist of blending it just a little bit for a nice texture. I do wish that they were a little stronger, but the experience definitely made up for that. The female bartender was greet as well! Super nice to talk with a little and made a solid drink. We will be back!
author: Hayley A.

description:
The Good:
-  old enough to be a historic landmark
-  underground basement reminiscent of your teenage underage drinking house parties
-  Chinese Mai Tai with "Chinese Liquor"
-  heavy pours
-  attentive service

The Bad:
-  a bit rundown
-  rampant with hipsters
-  cocktails on the sweeter side
author: David C.

description: I thought I won't like Mai Tai again after been served with the worst Mai Tai before but LiPo's Mai Tai is one of the good one I've tasted. This is gonna be my togo place if I want Mai Tai.
author: Kath S.

description:
Great Mai Thais. I love the bartenders they are both so funny and have been working here as long as I can remember (which is only 5 years or less)

But this spot is pretty great especially if you can find a seat at the bar
author: Jonelle C.

description:
They were cartoonishly rude from the outset. The bartender nabbed a drink from one of our party right after serving it. Bartender proceeded to defend himself though we weren't accusing him of doing anything intentional, just requesting he fix the error. The bouncer saw us complaining and after realizing we were normal, sober customers, who were just bewildered at horrible service, profusely apologized again and again. It was clear this wasn't his first time being forced to do damage control, and he was clearly uncomfortable with the situation. Minutes later, the bartender chose to taunt us about the incident unprovoked.

Life is too short to deal with idiots. Rarely in this city, you find crappy service, and when it happens, it's great that you can just turn around and go one door over and know you'll have a great experience. Save yourself the bleh Mai Thai and skip the trip. Learn a fun dice game across the street at Buddha Lounge and have a blast!
author: Simon T.

description:
I don't like it when a bald man with a fat belly stupidly grins at me as I order another round of Chinese Mai tais. 

Truth! There he was, a little golden buddha statue behind the bar. Staring at me. Grinning. As if saying, "you can handle another round?! Anthony Bourdain got effed up on those!"

I was unprepared. I came here on an empty stomach, what am I, a newbie? I should've known better. Dark and white rum, Bacardi 151, some chinese liquor and pineapple juice goes into my wine glass and it has this pretty color that's just irresistible and you take a sip? whoa, duuuude. You keep sucking on your straw and next thing you know, the glass is empty and you haven't even warmed up your seat.

I asked the bartender if I can look at the bottle of the Chinese whisky. She smiles a slow, dangerous smile and curtly says, "no, it's a secret"  and walks away.

Some things are just better left alone. A mysterious Chinese whisky is one of them.

* hic *
author: Janice C.

description: 5 stars b**ches!! This has the BEST drink in the world. Get the Chinese mai tai. Worth it? Worth it! Yes I just had one. Yes I am happy.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
"Mandy Patinkin really isn't in enough things." 
~ Me, today, right before I found out he played Inigo Montoya in Princess Bride... how I did not realize this, I do not know. 

This is only important to know because this joint is popular among distinguished, grey-maned menz of a certain age, as Sir Mandel Patinkin is. Actually, that's not really even true... I mean it might be. I really have no idea, but apparently at some point in time Anthony Bourdain stopped in here so this place is kind of a big deal as far as Chinese dives go. I'm not a fan of AB, so I could care less, but if Mandy Patinkin ever comes here and they put his pic on the wall I will upgrade this review so hard... you don't even know. 

There's no food, so don't come here for that. You probably wouldn't want to eat here anyway. But there are some pretty b*tchin' Chinese Mai Tais ($9, and worth every red cent) that'll put you right to bed, despite their sugar content. For sure get this and then chase it with the Lucky Buddha beer (which really isn't that great but it combats the sweetness and it's just what you do here). 

The music will be all the Ja Rule and Ashanti mash-ups that were hella cool at your freshman high school dance and it will be awesome. Never in a million years could I have imagined how flagrantly jubilant I'd feel hearing Nelly's 'Air Force Ones' in a  modern day public setting.

The crowd will be what you'd expect from a bar that plays multiple songs prominently featuring Ludacris in the year 2014... meaning, expect the unexpected. It's as mixed a bag of people as you'll ever find. All ages. All walks of life. All having the best and booziest time in recent memory. Super fun and super conducive to making friends (the guy who let me cut in at the bar to order my drink was actually a dead ringer for Mandy Patinkin, swoon). 

Cash only, FYI. Bars, they're just like us... hate paying their taxes all the same.
author: Candice G.

description:
I wasn't expecting this place.

Walking down the streets of Chinatown on a Monday night, I didn't think we'd be stopping anywhere to drink.  But a text from a friend who would know where to go urged us to try it.  "My favorite dive" he said.

Let's do it.

Their speciality drink is a Chinese Mai Tai for $9.  Chick drinks aren't usually my thing, but I have to say, I wasn't expecting it to be good or to like it.  But I did.  

And Amos, the charmer behind the bar, dealt with the motley crew of patrons  - one of whom continued shouting about how he broke the Mai Tai record of 12 by drinking 13 - admirably.  Professionally, with a smile and leaving everyone, even the drunk Englishmen with his new record, happier.  

I will be back.  And I will bring cash because I'll be breaking my own Mai Tai record and going for two.
author: Libby R.

description: Li Po is a no flairs bar. You will not find top shelf alcohols, craft beers, or extensive wine menus. Li Po focuses on cheap booze and their signature drink called the chinese mai tai. They have several TVs throughout the venue, so you'll be able to catch the big event that day.
author: Joseph T.

description: Got the Chinese MainTai and it was not good. Shorted on the shits and tasted  not great.
author: Mary A.

description:
A fan of Anthony Bourdain, I had to add Li Po Cocktail Lounge to my San Francisco bar crawl. I honestly expected something to be really special about this place for it to have made it onto the Travel Channel, but I was rather disappointed.

Li Po Cocktail Lounge has definitely become a tourist trap since Anthony Bourdain's visit in 2012. Just about every customer orders the Chinese Mai Tai (light rum, dark rum, Barcardi 151, Chinese liqueur, and pineapple juice). The bartenders seem to focus on making as many of these drinks as quickly as possible rather than friendly service.

The Chinese Mai Tai's are $9 each, cash only. They are really nothing special; they taste just like what they are, rum with some pineapple juice. Even though the rum flavor is present, they don't seem to be very strong in alcohol at all: this is a joke considering there are signs advertising just how strong they are.

The worst part about this place is the blaring outdated hip hop music. It just did not seem to fit the overall look of the place. It can also get really crowded and hard to walk through the bar. The clientele seem like the type to chug as many Mai Tai's as possible and let loose: there was a mini dance party in the center of the main floor of the bar. Not that anything is wrong with dance parties, it just did not seem to fit with what I expected out of the bar.
author: Lindsey D.

description:
OK having dinner with the wife and met a couple of people who told us about a drink "Mai Tai". What is this magical drink? Where do I get one? The journey takes us to Li Po Cocktail Lounge.

I must honestly say that I have never had a Mai Tai. I was a bartender for 5 or 6 years; never made one. I don't even know the ingredients; just stuff and rum??? 

Now I had one; very cool. Great tasting drink. Balanced drink with rums and juices; and that quick blender with ice. Refreshing with a kick.

I guest what makes this drink a winner is the actual location. Just take a look at all the pictures and you can see this is one chilling joint for cocktails. Day or night:)

I usually don't go to places that are mention in various food shows, but Li Po Cocktail Lounge is a real winner for a Mai Tai or any kind of adult beverage. I am sure it has it's moments at night.

Mai Tai for All. Live large...........
author: Billy V.

description:
This place is known for their mai tais. I hate mai tais and this was probably one of the worst I'd ever had. Yet I'm giving this place four stars. Why?

The ambience is gorram awesome, especially if you like divey vibes. You can see pictures out front from when Anthony Bourdain came here on The Layover. The inside is decorated exactly the way you would expect a Chinatown dive bar to be -- like a place you'd go in the 1890s to get Shanghai'd. 

Best to go after you've tied down a few elsewhere, but still highly recommend this place.
author: Ilya V.

description: Heard about the world famous Mai-Tais here and decided we had to check it out. This place is a little dive-y but i was surprised how packed it got on Friday night around 8pm. The Mai Tais were delicious and the music was top notch - lots of Beyonce which is never a bad thing. No complaints here. Funky little place - I will definitely be back
author: Ilana B.

description:
BEST MAI-TAI'S EVER!

I think one gets the job done right! Don't hold yourself back from exploring other options on the menu. The staff are fun and work fast. This lounge also has a neat basement room, which is ideal if you see yourself hanging out here with a large crowd. 

Cheers!
author: Sarin P.

description: This place is crazy. You walk through these funky doors into this dark dive bar. It has all kind of crazy decor both outdated and in need of repair. But who the hell cares when you have one of those Chinese Mai Tais. I don't know what they put in them. But it is a delicious sweet alcoholic crushed ice glass of yumminess.  Have two and you will leave happy.
author: Robyn J.

description: Mai Tais are $10 each. Seems pricey for a so-so beverage. But you can't beat the location... heart of Chinatown. Has us missing Shanghai.
author: Mackenzie W.

description: Every time I visited San Francisco my buddies and I would stop by to have their famous Mai tai as featured on No Reservation with Anthony Bourdain.  It was at least an hour wait to get dinner at R&G Lounge so we decided to stop here.  The place is a hole in the wall, dark, grimy , dirty.  This time around we were promptly approached by a rude bartender who demanded we show our ids, sure ok, then he shouts at my girl "no outside drink!"  As she was holding her boba tea.  Ok well fuck you too asshole we'll just grab some drinks elsewhere.
author: Phung L.

description:
Cool dive bar in the heart of SF's Chinatown known for their Mai tais. The drink is definitely hyped up because Anthony Bourdain went here and raved about it. It is quite strong. Had a funky old whiskey flavor to it. But drinkable and a few will definitely get you tipsy. 

The area is golden. A perfect spot to rest from walking.
author: Candice N.

description: The spot to get Chinese Mai Tais! I can't comment on much else because our mission and purpose was to drink Chinese Mai Tais and that was what we did. Dive bar-ish setting but we were only here for a short while so didn't mind.
author: Hughes C.

description: Mad props to Li Po for opening two hours earlier than usual to accommodate us reveling in the festivities of SantaCon this past weekend! When other bars (cough, Comstock Saloon, cough) actively and purposefully kept SantaConners out of their doors, Li Po welcomed the onslaught of jolly red-clad, white-bearded folk who just wanted a nice pick me up on the way from the Union Square commencement to the debauchery that would ensue in North Beach later on. Just as advertised by Bourdain and the likes, the Mai Tais here are excellent, and sneakily strong. Normally a $10 drink in a plastic cup would be a rip-off anywhere other than perhaps Bourbon Street, but honestly the visit is worth it even if to simply to admire the myriad Chinese decor inside, and be treated well by the quick and polite bartending staff behind the counter. Will be back soon!
author: Andy L.

description:
Best Dive in SF? Quite Possibly.

Came here this weekend after a night of DJing in the Mission District with my bud, and it had been awhile since my last visit, but I was jonesin for that world famous Chinese Mai Tai of theirs and I couldn't get it off my mind. So we ubered on down to Chinatown to get a little toastier before stumbling down to Sam Wo for late night eats.

Lets just say appearances aren't everything, this spot is a little rough, but worth your visit if you're into dives and just overall cool little places to grab a drink and catch a barstool. The music tends to be pretty good as well, and that Mai Tai? Still strong and delicious. Just go, I can't say you wont regret it (you might if you drink too many of the Mai Tais), but it'll be worth it!
author: Duggan B.

description: These were literally the worst mai tais I have ever tasted. Unable to finish- and I routinely drink sailor Jerry's straight! Point is, they were unsavory and unsatisfactory. Maybe try a canned beer but the mai tais were awful. People were nice though.
author: Dalton S.

description: Kinda smells weird but the drinks are awesome and will definitely be worth your while. You will get tipsy after one mai tai. Enjoy yourself. Play games. Have a great time.
author: Jenna G.

description:
The interior was probably really nice back in the day. The word decrepit comes to mind now. 
But the drinks were strong and cheap
The interior was brightly lit when I was there, but it shouldn't have been. 
Cash only, baby. Get the Mai Tai
author: Brandon D.

description:
This is a 4 star establishment because I don't entirely remember the whole experience. I'm pretty sure it's better than a 3 but not quite sure if it's good enough to be a 5. Thus, I've decided to rate Li Po's a very solid 4. Here are the cliff notes of what I remember..

- Those $10 Chinese Mai Tai's get you from sober to mess you up real quick. Instant 5 stars.

- The bartenders are somewhere between jerks and okay guys. But hey, they're like bus drivers... They get me to where I need to go regardless of how they treat me. 

The bar is like any other Chinese bar except more awesome. Nothing fancy but has great prices and plenty of seating. Cash only so bring your Hamiltons, y'all (Hamilton is on the $10 bill).
author: Chris W.

description:
Bartender was extremely personable! We got the Mai tai's of course. Nice and strong but sweet after taste so it wasn't hard to drink. 

They played hip hop from like 2005 so it reminded me of my high school days lol I loved it.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Prompt and friendly service could not overcome an underwhelming MaiTai.

PROS: the ladies behind the bar were quick w/ a greeting, and will have your MaiTai blended and served in a plastic cup in a time that would threaten a Jamaican sprinter's best effort

CONS: the MaiTais. Anthony Bourdain must have imbibed in advance of his arrival here . . . they were below average in both flavor and alcohol content. Also, I was kind of put off by the plastic cups. Cost savings on glassware and staff?? Crazy tourists always shattering glasses against the wall in a time honored MaiTai ritual only a few know about? Whatever the reason, me no like. Lastly, the bar had a really strong odor of disinfectant. Pungent, bathroom-like, industrial strength odor. It didn't help the taste of the MaiTais.

I wanted to like LiPo . . . 

Cheers!
RS
author: Rich S.

description: Li Po is literally my most favorite place in all of Chinatown.  The Chinese Mai Tais ROCK and I love my favorite bartender Jackie.  :)
author: Ann-Marie J.

description:
Have you ever heard of a Chinese Mai Thai? Me neither  ... that is until I made my way to Li Po Cocktail Lounge.

This grunge style cocktail lounge specializes in Chinese Mai Thai (cost = $9), which consist of a whooooole lotta alcohol types blended together in one fantastic drink.  

I discovered this place as I overheard a conversation  rabout this neat cocktail lounge in China Town. China Town and cocktail lounge don't seem to quite go together and that's what made this place so intriguing. 

Don't go here expecting a swanky bar with outstanding customer service. This place has a different type of charm. The dive bar vibe, strong drinks and fun music make Li Po great. Head to the bar, order a round of Mai Thais and take a seat either upstairs or in the basement. The ground floor is more of a lounge area where the basement has this grungy underground feel with Christmas lights, couches and a makeshift bar. 

Now I'm not going to explain anymore because you need to check this place out for yourself.
author: Aletta B.

description: Tasty mai tai's, nice atmosphere. Middle of ChinaTown. Cool location. I'd recommend going there after a day of walking through ChinaTown. Nice and refreshing. Have cash in hand.
author: Keagan G.

description: OMG! This is a gem located in Chinatown. The Mai Tai is their specialty and was absolutely fabulous! LOVED it
author: Teresa B.

description: There is an Ikea futon for watching TV and a nook with 70s diner chairs. A nice man entertained us with a firework outside of the bar. He was not affiliated with the establishment but provided the service free of charge none the less. Everything ended up making sense.
author: leo b.

description: A must stop in Chinatown if you're visiting! Li Po is a little dive bar nestled in the often hectic environment of Chinatown. Small intimate and a bit dark. You come to Li Po for the Chinese mai tai and you'll understand why every person at that bar is drinking the same. So tasty! Great place to checj
author: Kayla U.

description: Went to Li Po with a friend and got some beers to make the $20 card minimum, which was fine. So we got 4 beers and I left a 4 dollar tip, but the next morning I checked my statement and it said 42 dollars! So I think maybe they switched the numbers at the end of the night entering the cards, I know it's late. But I call and ask and they say no, you ordered 2 mai tais on top of your beers! I definitely didn't black out and order more drinks, and I definitely remember writing $24 on the receipt. Unfortunately I didn't keep my receipt, who does from bars? So the lady argues with me and says that what it says on her paper and promises she'll check the cameras to somehow prove to me that I ordered mai tais and call me back. Fast forward one week later and I have a $46 charge because of course I tipped 4 dollars on 6 drinks (which I would never do). Tl;dr make sure you have cash when you go here because I got scammed
author: Alani W.

description:
I like the ambiance and the bartenders are the nicest people you'll ever meet.

The Chinese Mai Tai is quite good if a certain bartender makes it. And it is awful if another one makes it. You take your chances on that.

This place is my favorite bar in San Francisco.
author: Carl H.

description:
1 drink u need 2 know.. the "CHINESE MAI TAI" !

each time we come 2 San Fran, we have 2 stop by 4 our Mai Tai dues.. this drink is so big that the whole place drinks it, if u don't understand me, just come, sit down @ the bar n look left n then look right, wat do all of u have in common? Mai Tais, Chinese that is..!

simply the best Chinese drink there is, if not the best in the planet!

both refreshing n can b strong if u have more than a few

this place I calculated makes on a good day w/ 2 bartendars, about 4 drinks (Mai Tais) per minute, which is 240 per hour.. or 1920 per 8 hours opened x $9 per Mai Tai.. u do the math, they r ballin' OUT.. OF.. CONTROL! (meaning making hella mula)

word of advice: just go there n surrender!

*only thing, this place needs some updating
author: Johnny L.

description: We got in right at opening time had the best convo with the bartender my only regret not partaking of their famous Mai Tai's I'll be back you can count on that!
author: Velonda H.

description: It's as if I've stepped into a film noir set in 1930s Shanghai, half expecting tables of mah jong and mobsters discussing opium deals to flank the place. It is dark, seedy, and absolutely delightful.
author: Christina S.

description:
Not a fan of Mai Tai's but the {chinese} Mai Tai's here are DELICIOUS!
But BEWARE: they are on the strong side.
Ingredients in a mai tai: dark rum, light rum, Bacardi 151, chinese liquor, & pineapple juice.

The inside isn't too fancy & the bar has more of a casual vibe. I'd honestly come back here for the drinks rather than the environment but UGH, the drinks were so good!
author: Rachel Y.

description: Great bar with a great vibe. Don't miss the maitai. Fun place in one of the coolest places in San Francisco. This is one of those hole in the walls that you stumble across once in a great while.
author: Dan E.

description:
Hands down a very interesting and cool dive bar.
We stumbled upon it from recommendations of fellow yelpers and when we saw that Anthony Bourdain stopped here, we knew we had to try it.

We ordered a lucky Buddha beer and a Tsing Tao.  I favored the lucky Buddha. It was light, yet it had taste to it. It def wasn't Bud Light...yuck.

Known for their unique jukebox, this place was pretty full at 8pm on a Friday night.  The bartenders were cute Asian girls with unusual clothing-it went with the surroundings. 

Filled with a crowd of white people, we enjoyed listening to unusual mash ups of Nikki Manaj and Lil Wayne with a little a little bit of 50 cent mixed in.

Def a cool dive bar and one I'd recommend to fellow Yelpers.
author: Kelleigh M.

description:
I like Li Po for the ambiance and for the historical reference in its name.  Li Po was a Tang dynasty poet who rumors say died because he drunkenly fell into a river while looking at the reflection of the moon.  When I studied Chinese poetry for a bit, I was a fan of his nature-filled poetry...so naturally I had to try out this bar and have been here several times over the years.

The drinks are reasonably priced but not crazy cheap and the service is okay.  The bathroom smells intensely of cleaning solution and strangely does not match the decor of the rest of the place.  The Chinese Mai Tai, honestly, is kind of meh in my opinion.  A little bland and it doesn't match their pictures.  I wavered between a 3 and a 4 in my rating for this place, but the historical reference and colorful decor are cool...so I guess I'll just say I'm a fan. :)  I'll be back, even if I don't order the mai tai again.
author: Kes D.

description:
The famous Chinese Mai Tai was ok. With all of the hype, I was expecting more.  Maybe with my recent travels, I've drank too many Mai Tais to compare with this with one.  Anyway, it wasn't that flavorful or potent to make up for the flat taste. 
Sorry if this offends any regulars, but I've had much better in Hawaii.
The place definitely has a nice feel to it though.  I liked it a lot. And, the bartenders were good. The next time I will order another drink (bartender's choice?) and enjoy the ambiance.
author: George S.

description: The Chinese Mai tai is amazing. Two of them @ $9 had me right for the night. And the bartender recommended THE BEST CHINESE FOOD I HAVE EVER HAD @ Nanking. He talked to us about the Grizzlies, earthquakes, and gray hairs, and was just so entertaining and welcoming. They had 2000s R&B playing. It was great. Can't wait to come back.
author: Trakela W.

description:
I sent a text to my friends late on Saturday night with the following wording, "Who wants to go to the best dive bar in San Francisco? There's a pretty good chance the majority of us won't get stabbed." 

Oh yes, this is my kind of place. 

The atmosphere is electric, just about any time of day. We walked in at 5 p.m. and people were already having a great time. I did see some complaints here about the bartenders being more concerned about making drinks than idle chit-chat. Yeah. That's what bartenders do. They serve drinks. Nobody is going to have a decent convo with you when people are hanging from the rafters. Sheesh. 

I have mixed feelings about Anthony Bourdain putting this bar on the Travel Channel. I mean, it was an awesome, hidden gem for a long time. But the secret is out. Which isn't always bad. I took the ladder (which doubles as a stairwell) down to the bathroom and saw that nothing changed. Well, the special room is gone. 

But this place still kicks ass. 

I implore you, if you are near Chinatown (and SF is just seven square miles so you are ALWAYS near Chinatown), you must stop in at least for one Tsingtao. That's right. I'd rather go with the bottled beer because it cuts down on the risk of getting Hep-Z at this place (though, you still probably will).
author: Adam R.

description:
This place is confusing in the best way. Super cheesy decor, super nice bartender, super delicious maitais over super old school hip-hop. I'm talking about Ja Rule old school. It's easy to have one too many maitais here but hey, it's five o'clock somewhere. 

TO THE CHINESE MAITAICAVE!
author: Kero S.

description: Three words: CHINESE MAI TAI. I swear they have a patent on their wall for the Chinese Mai Tai which is freaking hilarious. For $9, you get a tasty twist on a Polynesian classic that will hit you pretty hard and fast. Chill atmosphere with a friendly bartender that will occasionally play Liar's Dice with you if you ask. Cash only. Surprisingly lots of seating. Definitely somewhere to stop on your bar hopping adventures in Chinatown.
author: Stefanie C.

description: The Bartender Jackie is super friendly and the Chinese Mai Tai is GREAT!! Definitely recommend this spot.
author: Robert R.

description: The best damn bar in Chinatown period! I always come here whenever I'm in the hood for a Chinese Mai Tai. The bartender knows me and she always remembers my order. I'm kinda bummed that they raised the price a dollar up from the original $9.00 though. The Chinese Mai tai consist of dark rum, light rum, 151 rum, Chinese liqueur, and pineapple juice all mixed together with ice in a blender. This drink is a creeper so watch out how many you consume. It's an awesome spot and they even have a cutty underground room full of sofas, a bar, and room to dance. If you're in Chinatown, you definitely need to check this place out now. Go, go, go!
author: EccentricAura A.

description: Nice chill spot with some tasty Chinese Mai Tais. The special ingredient is a secret Chinese liquor which is an enigma. I haven't tried much else on the menu but with stopping in to try their famous offering.
author: Michael S.

description:
4.5

I walked in and the bar was playing 'Word Up.' Boom. Done. Drop the microphone. Cameo? In 2014? I love it. I freaking love it. 

Those opening moments were all I needed to fall in deep like with Li Po. I know, I know. He's sold out. He's been on TV. Things have changed.
