Well, considering the bathroom was straight out of a SAW movie and the bartender gave not one of any f--ks to the drunk girls who woo-hooed their way in and out of the joint (all the while staring them down with a sideways side-eye that brought tears of respectful joy to mine), I don't know that a mere mortal could have survived Li Po's before they went all uptown.

Then you have the drinks. Buddha beer followed me that evening but it was all about the 'Chinese liqueur.' What?? Whatever's in that bottle broke the space/time continuum. I have no idea how long I was there. I might still be there. I had a deeper understanding of Trainspotting for having drank of the Chinese liqueur cup. As I drifted between dimensions, I heard Janet Jackson, Lisa Lisa ('Lost In Emotion'; yaasss!!), The Jets (the motha-effen JETS!), and Cameo AGAIN ('Candy!')!!! The Spotify genie earned his keep that night. I'm sure that if I lived in SF and deigned to be a regular, I would end up in some horrible Requiem For A Dream situation but it would be a fun ride to get there.
author: Johnny T.

description:
Seriously, best Mai Tai ever!  No, I'm not kidding. Bartenders are friendly and inviting and the place is super chill.  Yes, the bar is divey and the decor is super cheesy, but if ever in Chinatown, just stop in and get a Mai Tai. You won't regret it.

So what's in the Mai Tai? Just Light Rum, Dark Rum, Barcardi 151, Chinese Liqueur, and pineapple juice.  Taste so good when it hits your lips, not so good when you stand up after two of them.

If ever in SF, I wouldn't hesitate twice to come back here.
author: Amanda D.

description: This was an awful experience! Fake bouncer in the front! Degenerate people as patrons. Unsafe and not up to code! If your looking for getting into a fight go here, everyone was looking for one!
author: Paul J.

description: Hole in the wall place on the border of Chinatown and North Beach. The cocktails that are their specials were amazing and were quite tasty. I liked how it was a local place and not overly touristy. Only downside is that they are cash only, but they do have an ATM inside if you need one.
author: Devika B.

description:
the bartender was awesome. sweet. we showed up and were like the only 2 people in there lol. had the mai tai of course. let me tell you, it's a creeper. so be careful.
tasty, sweet for my taste but the drink itself is.
she was sharing how they had to get a whole certificate because people will lie about where it was created. of course, the bartender will talk to you about anthony bourdain coming but you can tell she's tired of that. they have like pics of him at the front anyway.
it seems like a chill spot for HH after work, she mentioned how packed it gets. I'd check it out again!
author: francis c.

description:
Oh Santa Con, how you bring cheer to SF. Cheer and Mai Tais. Cheer, Mai Tais, and puking. Later. 

My crew started off our Santa Con pub crawl at Li Po on Saturday and had a fantastic time. It was crowed as eff, but that didn't stop us from snagging seats at the bar and mingling with all the other Santas around. 

The bartenders were suprisingly gracious, which I appreciated at such a hectic time. One even took a couple pics of us and all the other Santas which was cool. The place was packed, but I'd like to go back when it's more mellow and have a drink in an actual glass and enjoy some of the Chinatown mishmash.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Born and raised in SF, i'm behooved as to why I've never heard or came across this place until Anthony Bourdain did a small segment during his layover here. 
Dive Bar? Most definitely. Upon entering, I noticed that every one (and I do mean every single person) enjoying a Mai Tai. Between the mix of 151 and "chinese liqueur", I'd expected the mixed concotion to taste somewhere between foul and gag- worthy. However, it tasted quite pleasant- not too sweet (pineapple juice) or strong. Beware, the Mai Tai will quickly do you over, nice and slow is the way to go.
author: Ada C.

description:
Li Po's is a fantastic!  Order the Mai Tai (like everyone says).  It is delicious, refreshing and not too sweet.  Beware though, they go down easily and are STRONG.

Also, it is cash only so be sure to bring some!
author: Zara P.

description: Apparently, this is the only place in the city that can serve a Chinese Mai Thai (which uses Chinese liquor). The staff was friendly and they have TVs in case you're bored. The athletic endurance event "Warrior Race" was playing when I was there. Better than your everyday football, in my opinion. Seems like the place is mostly made up of regulars and is not the most touristy place in the city. If my memory serves me correctly, the bartender kicked out someone who was trying to pay with counterfeit cash. Pretty old place and the crowd is mostly men.
author: Jonathan A.

description:
Known for its mai-tais and named for a famous (and famously tipsy) classical Chinese poet, the Li Po walks the line between a local dive bar and a Trader Vic's style tiki bar. Nowadays, it's also become something of a tourist attraction in its own right due to the attention it has garnered since dive bars became trendy. That said, it's been here forever and however cheesy it is, however popular it becomes, it will always remain local and awesome. While Li Po lacks the underground status L'Amour Night Club had, it still impresses with those devilish mai-tais, the classic tiki cocktail based around rum and rum and some more rum. What's distinct here though is, they have been plying the mai-tai trade since circa 1997, making Li Po by far an early adopter of the tiki revival. 

Sadly, more American, typical, pop/soul from the 1990s now than Canto-pop here, but still, fun times.
author: Mike W.

description: Bourdain Effect pricing in full effect. But I will say, Mai Tais are on point. Great spot to start off your evening. Boozy but very tasty. Worth checking out if your in Chinatown or the Financial District.
author: Adrian C.

description:
When in SF, you must stop by this place at night to grab a few drinks. Chinese Mai Tai all the way... it's their special drink!! A couple of Mai Tais will do, because it is a creeper! 
This joint is pretty popular at night. It gets pack, so try to come early to get a seat at the bar.
author: Grace D.

description:
came here based on a recommendation to try the maitai from a nice canadian lady working at a bar in key west.  it brought me and my friends on an adventure here

atmosphere: a small seedy bar, there are a few locals and a lot of tourists from around the world.  the music is party music from the late 2000's including some bay area music, which really appealed to our group (26 year olds).  

clientele:  pretty diverse and there were lots of conversations to be had regarding travel and partying around the world

Mai Tai:  got served by the lady bartender and she made it very dilute.  came back and asked the male bartender and it was a heavy pour.  it tasted like an acute kidney injury waiting to happen, but hey, had to try it

overall a pretty cool place to check out if you're in chinatown at night to experience some touristy loval flavor
author: Tina A.

description:
Go there for the specialty Mai Tai's! There's five different kinds of booze within, including an unspecified "Chinese liqueur" that, by itself, could probably peel paint from the walls. But in a blended beverage, all of the flavors go together perfectly.

If mixed drinks aren't your thing, they also serve Buddah beer, which is similar to Tsing Tao. But really, get a Mai Tai.

Li Po is not fancy, but the bathrooms are clean and service is efficient. Love a well-run business like this. No fuss or muss, just great booze at an affordable price.
author: Abby S.

description:
I love Anthony Bourdain, but wow, what a liar!

I came here to try the famous chinese mai tai ($9) but it was all truly built on hype. When I saw the list of rum and chinese liquor that was incorporated into the drink, I was expecting it to be quite strong. However, mine was weeeeeaaaakkk. I think it was watered down too and it was definitely not because I was being a slow drinker. Maybe I came in on a bad day, maybe it's really all hyped marketing, or maybe i'm just an alcoholic who'd rather have a straight shot burn down my throat than drink watered down pineapple juice. Whatever it is, I don't think I will go out of my way to Li Po again.

CASH ONLY too.
author: Margaret W.

description:
The mai tais here weren't bad (nice mixture of juice and alcohol) but I thought that the AMF drinks didn't taste that great. They got me sufficiently tipsy sure but I didn't like the drink too much.

The inside is well divey so it's what you expect. They play a lot of hits from our college days so that was a nice throwback.
author: Danielle C.

description:
Been a fan of this place for quite some time
not sure I really like their remodel, thought it was better darker and bit more grungy

for years, it was one of the few places in Chinatown that actually had coors light...I know, I am a beer connoisseur....haha

beers and alcohol relatively cheap, they have a selection of others if you don't enjoy CL
fully stocked bar, good selection, they promote their Mai Tai, have not tried so can't comment

for those of you who are adventurous, do try some of the Chinese wine....straight out of ceramic containers just like in the kung fu movies!

their bathroom is like most in Chinatown, gotta go down narrow stairs to get to pretty much a dingy, dirty, graffiti laden pee room!....not sure what ladies room is like, probably similar.

in any case, I have always found this a nice DIVE bar to have a few drinks and relax
sometimes you get a lot of tourist types who get a bit loud, but it's all good

after the remodel, they seem to point out that they were used in the filming of Big Trouble in Little China, one of my all time favorite movies! Woohoo!

If you happen to be in SF Chinatown, be sure to stop by for a drink
they don't open til later in afternoon though, but if early, there is always Buddah Bar across street that opens early!

Have fun
author: Ken L.

description: Cash Only! Quick Service! Just about everyone is drinking $9 Mai Tai's. I loved the vibe and the current hits playing on the radio. The bar staff was very nice and offered to find us a couple of seats together so that my friends didn't have to stand around one chair. I highly recommend stopping by here if you are in Chinatown.
author: Bre P.

description: Cute and very divey. I guess Anthony Bourdain has been here and had the mai tais. There is dark rum, light rum, 151 rum, Chinese liqueur, and pineapple juice. They're a little on the sweet side if you're sensitive to that. Those mai tais go down easy--2 or 3 of those drinks and your fucked up. This has the vibe of a tavern if you're into that! And smack in Chinatown.
author: Megan T.

description:
Bourdain gets down. After the SF show we took note and  followed his crawl to Li Po. You order the Chinese Mai Tai, that's the THING and it's exactly the K.O. you hope for. The place is just as packed as you expect. It's good. 

So that's it. Best "High" Chinese Mai Tai for $9.00 and a fun night out. http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=JsI-tiNW89H_xgMRgFjUQQ&userid=Lu8y2ayxVlAzuJEVfVcH4w
author: Rebekah T.

description:
Get the mai tai all night long.  They're sneaky, taste so innocent, and will likely floor you after 3, the moment get up from your seat for the restroom.  BAM.  Great night started.  The bartenders won't tell you what's in it, but they did divulge that it has about 6 different liquors in it.  hooowhee!  

The decor is so kitchy you have to love it. Great energy; lots of hipsters.  A good place to close out the night.  There's another large lounge space downstairs past the bathroom, for more lounging space.
author: yuwi s.

description: This place is on point! My boyfriend and I were staying at an airbnb in San Francisco and our host told us we had to come here for the mai tais. So glad we did. The bartenders were so friendly and made the drinks extremely fast. They told us that the owner made a secret ingredient that goes into the mai tais which is what gives them their exquisite flavor. The only downside is that they only take cash. Neither my boyfriend or I had cash on us, but luckily there was an ATM just outside. The mai tais are $11 which seemed high at first because this place is a dive bar, but once you try them you won't regret it!
author: Briana B.

description: Saw this place on the list of best San Francisco cocktail bars - and I am still questioning why someone would put this place on there. They are known for their "Chinese Mai Tai" and literally that is the only thing this place has. The drink is $9, and tastes like a stronger version of a regular mai tai. The place itself is far from cocktail bar-like, and is in need of a remodel and cleaning. If you want to try the drink, stop by, but not much of a place to hang out.
author: Nikita K.

description: Get the Chinese Mai Tai for a good time! Dark rum + light rum + 151 rum + Chinese liquor + pineapple juice = tasty and dangerous. $9 per drink, bring cash. Anthony Bourdain approved.
author: Christine C.

description: If I could give this place negative stars - I would. It's a pretty horrid little bar with terrible service. A waitress here harassed us - we tried to ignore it but she came back to our table and continued to target us. Never. Ever. Come here.
author: Rashmi J.

description:
My friends and I had great service from the bartender.  We first started with the Shang Hai Mai Tai, cheesy as it sounds. But the drink was a very good one. My bestie ordered it as a double and it was the right amount that he wanted. For me, it was a good flavor of the the Chinese whiskey and other types of liquors.

The bartender was nice enough to offer us the taste of the Chinese whiskey used for the drink as well as other types of liquors that were hot and spicy.  My other drink was a chocolate martini with coffee.   A creation that I made at the spot.

A dive bar with character and friendly bartenders. Isn't that what a dive bar supposed to be?  (Plus the numerous tourist that came in to the bar to have the mai tai due to Anthony Bourdaine.)
author: Marck N.

description: Interesting place we stopped at for a drink because someone in our group needed a restroom. There are not many bars in Chinatown and the other one was even more dive bar...so we gave this one a try. They are "famous" for their Mai Tai so I tried it. Not bad but not worth $10 either, in my opinion. Like I said....interesting place.
author: Mary T.

description: This place a tourist spot- all thanks to Anthony Bourdain. Not necessarily a bad thing. Although I will say- I was a bit disappointed with the infamous Mai Tai. It was tooooo sickly sweet. And it did not get me that wasted! The bartenders said you have to drink 2 to feel the effects. The Chinese liquor is quite potent- like an Asian kumquat sort of flavor. Probably wouldn't get this drink again. Good place to experience at least once!
author: Vivian D.

description:
Was here about 7 pm Sat/4 Jul:
- $7 per Jack & Coke, made strong.
- Complete dive bar, friendly bartenders, fast service.
author: Chan L.

description: Fun, fun, fun. We stumbled across this place on Super Bowl Sunday and decided to stop in for a drink because it looked really divey from the outside and there was a big screen tv. Place has a funky run down interior. It was empty. Got a Chinese Mai Tai, because everyplace we looked was a sign saying they invented it. $9 a drink didn't seem so bad based on the prices we'd been paying in San Fran. Holy Crap - one drink and I had a buzz from all of the booze in it. The bartender couldn't have been nicer. As the game started the place began to fill up. Every single person was drinking the Mai Tais so of course it got loud. Add in the firecrackers on the street for Chinese New Year and the party was really rolling.  Glad we found it!!
author: Denise P.

description:
Oh man, Anthony Bourdain got this one on the head. Chinese Mai Tai with chinese liquor, yes. So I came here with my group of friends and we decided to drink. 

Walking in you can definitely feel the Chinese culture with the Buddha shrine and even the colors they portrayed inside. I ordered the famous Mai Tai that Anthony Bourdain got drunk off of on the layover. Then my friend said that the adios m****** f***** was one that really meant what it was named. I must say walking out of that place, I was warm. Even as I write this, I'm warm... My type of place to drink, strong good tasting drinks.

I will definitely come back here.
author: Bruce K.

description:
"usually we only give you water, when you order a drink" - they said to my roommate who asked for 4 waters, when we only got 2 drinks. Ouch. 

I know Anthony Bourdain came here on the Layover, but I didn't get what the big deal was. The mai tai is strong, and true, it wasn't too not bad for $8. It's an ok divey bar to stop by in, or during a pub crawl but nothing that exciting! Just remember, cash only, mai tai, and don't expect cleanliness or friendliness.
author: Joanna S.

description:
The oldest bar in Chinatown, and one of the 5 oldest bars in San Francisco.  Li Po has been open for just over 100 years.  It is decorated with large Chinese lamps that are nearly a century old, and are famous for the 'Chinese Mai Tai'!  
The drinks are delicious, the bartenders tell you stories of old Chinatown and they encourage you to take pictures!  Prices are fair, both the bar and bathrooms are clean.  I'm glad we stopped in to check out this landmark!
We'll be back for sure!
author: Jim P.

description: Cheeky interior and deliciously strong Chinese Mai tais make this place worth a try after some cheap Chinese food. If it's good enough for Anthony Bourdain, it's good enough for me! Cash only -- $8 per Mai tai, $4 for a Buddha beer (not good beer but a cute bottle).
author: Shirley L.

description:
Giving this place a 1 star mainly towards their chinese mai tai. My date and i had seen this place on a tv show and they made the mai tai seem so extraordinary! May i say it was no where near. not sure if it was the bartender lady that made them or if its the original recipe but it tasted like a regular not so good mai tai. Maybe they faked it for the show but we were not impressed at all. And 9 bucks for this thing. Not worth it at all. We also watched her make the 2 drinks in one and it seemed like she poured a little over for one but not enough for two. We even tried to make small convo and she didnt even say more then 2 words.

If possible and you go let me know who bartended for you. Had a short haired asian lady. Couldnt even catch her name cause she didnt want to talk

Waist of time. Im sure its probably a good place other than that. Just saying, I'd never go back again.
author: Jackie B.

description:
Seriously as far as dive bars are concerned, Anthony Bourdain's visit to this dingy spot has turned the establishment into hipster nirvana.  While I love dive bars.. I love them because of the low foot traffic and minimal amount of dbags and hipsters to deal with.  Thank you Mr Bourdain.  While I absolutely love everything you produce, I hate you for ruining some really great spots for me.

While I hit the bar with some friends, it was completely flooded with loud obnoxious guys and girls sandbagging their Mai Tai's.. which apparently the bar is famous for.  We plopped ourselves down by the bar and ordered a few to see what the hype was about.  Our bartender, who I can only describe as an Canotonese Tom Selleck, quietly went to work mixing our drinks.  Utter garbage, but in my defense, I don't drink anything sweet or fizzy when it comes to alcohol.  It either comes brown and aged or it doesn't go in my body.

While admiring the mustache on our bartender ( I feel terrible that I don't remember his name ) I did my best to spark some conversation.  He was quick to brush me off, but since we were probably going to be there for a while, I decided to buy him a shot of "Chinese Whiskey".  He politely obliged and poured two shots of what I can only describe as tasting like Chinese medicine.. just burny gingseng and other roots.  It was disgusting, but it got him to talk.

He proceeded to be f'ing awesome company all night, pouring us shots after shots.  He basically explained how the mai tai has turned into some douchy hipster drink and how he was glad that I was ordering real drinks.  We continued drinking for the next few hours where I eventually got him to the point where he had to tap out or he wouldn't have been able to continue serving drinks.

All in all.. I love Li Po and I love that the bartender hates hipsters as much as I do.  Do yourself and don't bother dropping by if you're going for a mai tai.  If you're looking for a good time and a man's drink, drop by and buy the bartender a shot and prepare for a sea of frustration and ultimately good company.
author: Allen C.

description:
Was making plans for bashing around Chinatown with my fella, so as always, to Yelp I go!
We do love our libations, so I am always on the lookout for a good bar when we are gonna be oot and aboot.
Li Po intrigued me. Chinese Mai Tai. Dive-y. Anthony Bourdain. Those exact words pretty much unlock magic.
When we first stepped in, I heard the gangster rap and my heart sunk a little.
But, then we got IN the bar, and I smiled. 
We were greeted by a lovely lady who turned out to be one of the nicest bartenders we have ever had. And did I mention we love our libations? Yeah, that means we meet a lot of bartenders. This doll was top shelf ;)
I ordered my Chinese Mai Tai, he got his beer and a shot, and we were off! 
The bartender asked us what brought us in, and we talked about Yelp and Anthony and that we like booze.
She was so incredibly sweet. She explained that Li Po was the oldest bar in Chinatown, which I shame myself for not knowing, and was so excited to find out. The pointed out the lanterns and Buddha shrine that were original! She even welcomed us to take photos, which was so sweet of her to do. It's not always welcomed in establishments in Chinatown.
She even invited us to the Chinese New Year parade, told us what time it was, and how fun it was.
She couldn't have been sweeter. We couldn't have had a better experience. Had the Mai Tai's not been $9, I would have stayed for a few more. 
But I don't really know how many of those bad boys I could have handled anyways lol.
It is delicious, by the way. If you are of age in Chinatown and have a spare $10 bill on you, go to the oldest bar in Chinatown, meet the sweetest bartender you ever will, and have a damn delicious drink.
CASH ONLY, KITTENS!
author: Kat R.

description:
Only stayed for one glorious Mai Tai, but it was everything I thought it would be. Delicious and boozy. A must-try while passing though Chinatown, but you didn't need to hear that from me.

Do yourself a favor and head a block over to grab a quick bite at New Hollywood Restaurant & Bakery before/after. If you are only looking for a snack, ask for a Green Onion bun to go! You won't regret it, and you'll likely want something to soak up that Mai Tai if you stayed for a few!
author: Katie S.

description:
That "original chinese mai tai" is not a drink to be trifled with. Sure at $9 it seems kind of expensive but for as much booze is packed in to that plastic glass (is that an oxymoron?) it's a good value (if getting tanked is your goal).

Anthony Bourdain came here in his show once and he was slurring on national television to give you an idea of the potency of one of these babies. So maybe start the night here but end it at your peril.

Also i like the look of the bar. It's kinda old and tacky but in a way that things are never old and tacky anymore.
author: Misha T.

description:
Li Po is one of San Francisco's hidden gems. I've been coming here for years and it never disappoints. 

Mai Tais are amazing, but you probably shouldn't have more than one (two at the most). They only play pop music from the years 2004-2012 and the place hasn't been renovated in at least a decade. This simply adds to Li Po's charm. 

It seems to attract a lot of tourists since being featured on The Layover (Anthony Bourdain's show) but it's still worth checking out. You will not regret it!
author: Lauren T.

description: Must stop in China town!!! It's a hidden gem.  You must order the Chinese mai Thai!! I swear the drink is very strong.  One of these got me and my boyfriend very wasted.
author: Vanessa V.

description:
I went here for my 23rd birthday celebration and, oh dear.. Those Mai Tai's sure do come in like a wrecking ball, don't they!?

Don't let those delicious, fruity and refreshing drinks trick you - they are packed full of Chinatown's finest rum. I learned that the hard way. 

Li Po used to allow for for small parties to rent out their small basement room. I attended a few birthday celebrations at Li Po before where the downstairs area was reserved - it was a nice little get away from the group of Mai Tai chasers upstairs. Apparently they don't offer the room anymore.. And when I asked about it, the woman I spoke to made it seem like this was common knowledge and I was ridiculous for asking. Missed a memo, perhaps?

I have to say, the staff is never.. entirely friendly. Which is okay, their business is slowly being overrun by San Francisco's finest. But when I'm spending $10 each on 4-5 Mai Tai's, a smile would be nice.
author: Alex G.

description:
Bottom line up front: A great bar in chinatown with an extremely eclectic and unique feel, but a bit overpriced and over hyped. Cash-only is a really annoying way of screwing your customers just because you want to cheat taxes and avoid credit card surcharges. If you are going to play that game, share the wealth and have more reasonable prices on your must-try house drink that 95% of your patrons are obviously going to order.

-----

I deducted 1 star because it feels like a greedy cattle call; sit down, drink your overpriced mai tai, thanks. Nothing particularly bad, but this happens a lot when places get publicity; price often goes up and quality down for a specific in-demand item. The drink was good, but not on par with the price. It's too bad, because this place has a lot going for it in other good ways.
author: Lee S.

description: The Mai Thai here was reaaaallllly weird tasting and it seemed like there was barely any alcohol even in the drink. We went out of our way for this place and were sadly disappointed.
author: Nicky B.

description: had a great time here. cant believe it took me almost 5 years to check this place out since im a huge bourdain fan and have seen his SF episodes like 80 times. very close to buddha lounge too. the chinese maitai is like a weird concoction that is blended - i just saw the bartender pouring in a variety of things into a blender seemingly at leisure.. but it was delish. cash only. i'd go back.
author: Christina L.

description:
I really want to give this place a NO star, the bartender attack me and my friend verbally for no reason at all. 

We've just walked in and walked up to the bar when I noticed the cash only sign, I turn to my friend and said "oh, cash only" and the bartender said to my friend and I "yeah, welcome to the city!" In a tone like we were two dumb bimbos that's not worth his time, like if he was trying to show off to a group of collage kids he was just talking to. Yeah he was a 50 some year old, dressed in 20 year old clothing, so I shouldn't have been surprised, but we're just patrons who've JUST walked in, what he could have said was, "yes, but there's a ATM a block away". So I told him, "yes, but thank to this gentrify of SF, mostly just Chinatown areas are 'cash only'" That apparently upset him and he use the same condescending tone and told us.  "no most every where in SF is this way, from here (Chinatown) to the Mission!" And that we can take our 'out of town' ass elsewhere.

Never going back to this awful place!

BTW, I grew up round here. What an ass of a bartender.
author: Charlie M.

description:
This place is seriously overrated, and the Mai Tai's are nasty. 

You walk in and its blaring loud, and a bunch of people are screaming loudly inside. Almost gave me an instant headache. Everywhere you look, everyone is drinking a Mai Tai. I think this place just got a good rep from Anthony Bourdain, but its seriously undeserved. Maybe, it use to be better.  

The staff is friendly, but they take care of you and just move on.

You can try it if you want, to say you did. I wouldn't come back.

Bring cash.
author: Mina C.

description:
LI Po was an occassional stop when i made the rounds in s.f. chitown decades ago. back then only chinese oldsters and youngsters came here. the only non chinese were tourists or seamen drinking up the town.

LIpo was a nice place to hang out with friends, smoke, amd play a few rounds of cards,  without the hassle of bar girls hustling you for drinks. (here, only the bartender(s) did that.

another plus: Lipo's  was open almost all day and night, so one could drink anytime one wanted too.

Lipo's has changed now. the tourists and out of towners have "discovered" Li Po's.
there goes the neighborhood!
author: Victor G.

description: We walked in at 2 p.m. in the afternoon and had the place to ourselves drinking Chinese Mai Tai and talking with the bartender.  The drink is delicious, potent, and goes down way to smooth. The best part was the bartender, Jackie, gave us unbelievable recommendations of places to see and eat in the city.
author: William C.

description: Heard about this place from Anthony Bourdain, so I figured I'd give it a shot. Man, am I glad I did. I stumbled onto the bar quite easily while exploring Chinatown. Good thing I was thirsty because the pours are quite generous. I opted for the Chinese Mai Tai, a powerful concoction that knocked my socks off. The place was pretty empty (it was about 3pm on a weekday) but soon started filling up as people started to get off work. The bartender was amazingly friendly which I liked as I was traveling alone. I talked with him about the history of the bar and how Chinatown (and SF) are changing. He was very entertaining and gave me some great tips on where to find more locals-only action in the city. The prices were reasonable for SF and totally worth it given the potency of the cocktail. I could easily see myself back at Li Po in the future.
author: Carlie D.

description:
We stopped in here to sample the famous mai tais. Super friendly lady behind the bar. It wasnt crowded in the early evening but there is an upper level with a dj area sound system dealie and I can see it getting busy later in the night.
The mai tais? Frothy, not too sweet, a little too much ice in the glass, a bit of a "bite" on the backend. Worth checking out while your in Chinatown.  Cash only but pretty sure there was an ATM at the front.
author: Lisa A.

description:
There's only one way to describe this place, hidden in the depths of Chinatown.

Gangster shit and Mai Tai's.

*Drops mic*
author: Nathan L.

description:
IF WALLS COULD TALK...

I'd want to hear the stories of whatever the hell has happened here in its 75+ years of existence.  I didn't look for its hidden rooms, but I wasn't here for long.

Get the Mai Tai because it's what everyone on Yelp and the Li Po website recommends.  Try something else if you're brave (:  I'd like to come back again!
author: Jennifer L.

description: This is must stop when visiting San Fran. The Chinese Mai Tai is no joke! Just make sure to bring cash and get their early or there isn't any place to sit!
author: Lexy S.

description: Mai Tais to die for! And a fun, low-ceiling, unpretentious atmosphere; complete with friendly bartender and cash-only policy with ATM outside. Enjoy, friends!
author: Viv R.

description: Well known for its Mai Thais! Can be loud and crowded but the theme is really unique and cannot be found elsewhere
author: Jin N.

description: This is one of those awesome places in SF that you hope never get priced out of the city. It's grungy but full of personality and a unique identity. The thing to get here are mai tais. They're delicious but dangerous as you don't realize how much alcohol you've taken in. It's a great place to start the night, and just wander around chinatown checking out other cool bars or making your way to north beach
author: Derrick W.

description: Went in last night with friends and family, the Mai tai's were amazing. Better than what I had in Honolulu. Interesting ambience, need to go back and check it out again.
author: Shivaji D.

description: I just LOVE me a good dive bar and this place delivered. The Mai Tai's we amazing (I had reservations about Chinese Mai Tai's) but it actually wasn't too sweet and it hit the spot. The music was fun and the bartender (Vanessa) was great....but she wouldn't give it up....(the recipe). Would definitely go back. Is now too soon!?!?
author: Mel M.

description: So, I visited Li Po Lounge with my cousin in a Sunday afternoon. Besides two other obvious tourist and someone who I assume is a regular, we were the only ones. The female bartender was nice enough but didn't try to make any conversation other than our initial drink order. Apparently the Chinese Mai Tai is the drink to get so I did. Never again. There was something off in the taste. Just not good. I sucked it down an on to the next thing. I wouldn't go out my way for this place.
author: Megan T.

description:
LiPo coctail lounge ! In the Heart of Chinatown...Truely a Hidden Gem!Aww Dive Bar.lots of Tourists mixed with locals.
They used to have live music downstairs but now rent it for Birthdays and what not.
Great Vintage Decore, fabulous Bartenders.  They serve very Yummy Original Chinese Mai Tais with Chinese liquor in them..no frills.They Sale Bottled beer, nothing on tap! I recommend the Buddha beer, its light  tasty in a Cute bottle and of course full bar Liquors.
Been comming here for years.Still a Cool place to bring out of town Guests. 
They dont Sale or make food, but the ladies and gentleman there will steer you to great Chinese eatery s close by.
Glad this place has survived. Oldiest chinese Bar in the area.
Thanx Li Po ....You Still Rock
author: Connie B.

description:
I 
Am not
A mai tai
Man but early
90s R&B jams went well with rum.
author: Justin L.

description:
I spent most of my childhood in Chinatown and never in my wildest dreams would I have thought that my adult self would actually want to come to Chinatown for drinks. Never.

What I love about this place is that it's not like every other overcrowded, rowdy, maybe-I-won't-get-shoved-if-I-just-squeeze-into-this-crevice-here type space. You'll appreciate their music if you enjoyed 90s hip hop / R&B / high school ratchet times and if you want to cut to the chase and get crazy, those strong Mai Tais will transform you.
author: Sandy T.

description:
Sometimes you gotta be a bit adventurous and try new things, such as going to a dive bar deep in Chinatown.  

Not much atmosphere other than some Chinese decoration covering up an old dive bar.  You'll notice pretty much everybody there drinking one drink, the Chinese Mai Tai.  It's a good drink made with the typical Mai Tai ingredients (including 151), but what makes it Chinese is the Chinese Whiskey.  It packs a punch so be careful! 

I would come back for the Chinese Mai Tai!  Staff is also friendly!
author: Veasna H.

description:
Feels like a must to try the Chinese Mai Tai, which is delicious.

Fun ambiance, but nothing too special here.
author: Eric B.

description:
If you're looking for a hidden gem than you'll strike it rich with Li Po. 

What says fun in China Town like a Mai Tai with some interesting chinese whiskey in it?

Make sure you bring cash, they don't take cards. And make sure you're not driving, because the Mai Tai's will sneak up on you!
author: Kipper S.

description: All I've ever gotten is the mai tai here, but then again there's no other reason to come here. The mai tai's are strong, delicious, and cash only. Walk in to find yourself in a Chinese-themed bar with an out of place giant plasma screen TV. You'll find an Asian man manning the bar, deftly making mai tai's and whatever other drink you need to live up or forget the night. One of my favorite places to start out the night. Apparently there's a dance floor downstairs but I've never seen it.
author: Philip W.

description: I love little places like this.  But first- CASH ONLY!  I guess I didn't read enough reviews and didn't realize this.  There is an ATM inside so besides paying the fee its not that difficult.  But anyway just FYI.  The mai tais were 9$ and perfectly delicious.  I really dislike regular mai tais so to say that I was hesitant is a real understatement!  These drinks were perfect though- barley any sweetness at all!! From what I understand its a pretty strong drink- but with all the flavors it worked together great.  It was light and refreshing and was exactly what I was looking for.
author: Kate F.

description: A glorious dive bar.  The Chinese Mai Tai will knock you out.  No pretension here, just a no frills place to get your drink on.
author: Kasey M.

description: This place is solid for a dive bar.  Get the Chinese Mai Tai, you will love it.  The bartender is super sweet and there was good dive bar music on.  Tip~ Bring cash
author: Sarah S.

description: Great dive bar for cocktails and cold beer , great little hidden gem to not be found. Chinese  Mai Tai are the best and put you on your Ass.
author: Robby A.

description: What an awesome place! Doesn't look like a lot from the outside but they truly have one of the best Mai Tais I know! Also cool atmosphere.
author: Martin H.

description:
Hey, Dive bar with a 1930 Chinatown decor feel. Its like traveling back in time. lol.
I haven't had a chance to try their Chinese Mai Tai. But, heard that it was really good. 
We came here in a small group of 8, got shots. The old man bartender who dresses like a 20 year old was very energetic and  screamed in Cantonese "Gon Bui," (Cheers). He was fun. lol.

FYI, they do cash only. That's why i didn't have enough for the Mai Tai. :)
author: Kevin K.

description:
Super great dive bar in heart of Chinatown ! I really do mean dive! It is old and kind of dirty but bathrooms were clean once you finally got to them. The famous Mai Tais did not disappoint and our group had a couple and I had a Buddha beer too.

The waitress was super friendly too.
author: John A.

description: Cool dive bar. Dark and a little mysterious with nooks and crannies. Kitschy decor but nothing should change. I wish they would restore their classic sign outside.  Fun place.
author: Osama B.

description: This place was amazing!!! The front of it is worth seeing and taking a picture of. Our bartender was amazing as well. She decided to talk to us pretty much the entire time we were in there. We were walking around Chinatown and decided to stop in for a beer. Then we found out about there Mai Tais. My fiancé and I don't generally drink liquor, but since this place is known for them we had to try. Very good!!!
author: Shannon B.

description:
I'm a tourist in town for a few days and normally wouldn't post a review but feel the experience warrants it. This place is a bit of a dive with Chinese characteristics and a playlist of early 2000s pop-RnB hits mixed in with some classics of my childhood.

It has a bit of hard drinking appeal for everyone: locals, tourists, students. We had three rounds around midnight on a Saturday night and in that time the tide went from halfway to full and back out to halfway. Depending on the time and day, it feels like you could get a very different crowd.

Sometimes you just know you're dealing with the owner. Whether it's the very generous, free pouring of your $9 long island iced teas, or the surprised reaction to getting a halfway generous tip, or the fact that aforementioned tip goes straight into the register, or when they give you a couple of pieces of bar decoration to take home.

Most potent and cheapest Long Islands I've had and I'd rate myself a mid-level connoisseur. My wife, like all the other ladies in the bar, enjoyed her mai tais.
author: Burger K.

description: Not even 5 minutes after we sat down at a table here, a waitress starting harassing us to order drinks immediately or we would be kicked out. We explained a few of friends were already ordering at the bar, but she continued to tell her we would have to leave if we didn't order from her. She was incredibly rude the rest of the night even after we showed her we had drinks from the bar. It's too bad because otherwise it seemed like a cool bar.
author: Adt S.

description:
Weird is an understatement when it comes to this place.  

My husband and I were walking across the street looking for something to eat and he just started walking towards this place like it was a magnet drawing him in.

I said initially"I don't know if we can go in there."  

There was maybe 5 other people in here and we happened to sit right next to the drunkest one.

 Actually the bartender tried to get us to move away from him but we know how to handle drunks.  Especially small old ones.  The bartender finally just told him to leave, and he did.

The juke box is freaking weird.  Another patron came in and was trying to get some music going and it was not happening.  

The bartender just stood there with his arms crossed shaking his head.  He never said a word or explained how this juke box could possibly be a time portal to the worst 80's music you have ever heard.

We only had one drink because we were starving.  My Gin & Tonic was really strong.  I pussed out and put some water in it.  Then my husband finished the rest.

The bathrooms, one labeled "Woman" in Sharpie on a piece of cardboard, duct taped to the door.  I really didn't want to get a good look at the place but it was dark and scary in that bathroom.

This place is just one of the most unique bars I have been in.  Weird might be the better word.  You just need to go and sit and take it all in because you will never forget it.
author: Ivy R.

description:
Believe what almost everyone else has said about this joint.

Very friendly service, incredibly strong drinks, fairly priced & a totally unique experience with interesting characters abound.

Don't go changin'...
author: Miguel S.

description:
What's better than a hot date?? One that takes you to Li Po for a Mai Tai.

I don't normally think of Chinatown as a prime spot for Happy Hour, but Li Po did not disappoint.  These Mai Tai's are legit, and for this little MinPin, one was more than enough booze.  

Besides the stiff drinks, this place was A-OK.  Chill vibes, and a great playlist of 90's rap.  Will be back for sure.
author: Lindsey G.

description: Good enough for Anthony Bourdain, good enough for me! I honestly probably would have never heard of this place if it weren't for Bourdain, and my friends dragging me. but Im really glad they did!! as most people have mentioned, its all about the Chinese Mai Tai here. Usually I'm not a main tai guy, but this place is definitely worth the exception. The bartenders were really cool and talked to us for a while. The other thing I really liked about this place was the music. They play some throwback hood jamz which was completely unassuming. The main point about this place is just that, it is completely unassuming and will surprise you. The ONE drawback is that it is CASH ONLY, which still amazes me there are cash only places in SF. After li-pos we continued in Bourdain's steps and headed over to Sam's to soak up our chinese mai tais. Definitely recommend.
author: Thielson D.

description: Great dive bar in Chinatown. Mai Tais are always on point. Bring cash though.
author: Nestor G.

description: This be a dive. With jazzy music. A table section. And a big curved bar. The drinks are cheap, the bartender is polite, and no one is checking you out in a creepy way.
author: Em L.

description:
This place is the absolute best! Good vibes all around. I have been coming here for months now and it definitely deserves a review. I have never ordered anything but the mai tai. I don't know how they do it, but the mai tais are dangerously delicious. They taste like heaven, but will have you stumbling in minutes. It has the local vibe and my favorite time to go are on weeknights where you can sit with a group of friends get drunk off mai tais and basically have the entire bar to yourself. The record is 7 mai tais, and if you are able to set a new record, please let me know I'd really like to buy you another one. 

Li Po's is just a dive bar where you can hangout and chill without being harassed by a big bouncer or large crowds. Not to mention their music playlist will make you want to get up and start dancing immediately.
author: Alex L.

description:
Duke ordered the Chinese whiskey

They told duke to relax

Drink slow. 

Duke don't listen. 

Duke got drunk but at least his diq got 

Hard.
author: Duke B.

description: This place is weird and wonderful. The Mai Thais are strong and delicious.
author: Claire H.

description:
Last year, after roaming around the city and splurging on random food during a street festival, my friends and I somehow ended up at Li Po. Usually, I avoid Chinatown like the plague unless I'm here doing a quick stopover to snag some bakery goodies or dim sum to go. Nonetheless, somehow a bar ended up in the rotation. 

To put it best, Li Po is a dive bar in Chinatown. This place is dim and has that old school look. You're definitely not coming here for the decor and ambiance. What you're coming here for is more or less their famous Mai Tai. I'm not exactly quite too sure what they put in these Mai Tais, but they're decently strong to say the least. As advertised, they have this so called Chinese liquor inside. From what it looks like to me, its a cheap bottle of Chinese liquor that you can buy for under $10 at 99 Ranch Market. However, when everything is mixed together, it's not too bad. 

Don't expect their Mai Tais to change the world, but if you're looking for a spot to grab a quick drink in the Chinatown area, Li Po can be that place.
author: Michael W.

description:
Following cocktails in The Redwood Room, Ana and I hailed a cab off to Li Po! 

What a gem! Right out of the 1950's movie, Flower Drum Song, the decor is very... weird and in a strange way, pretty sexy. Ana said the Chinese Mai Tai was the best and it was. Poured  in a really weird goblet w/flex-straw, the potent elixir creeps up on you and before you know it, we were going down a slippery slope of The Great Wall of China. Sure another round.

The bill is $44. Oh no, they take no plastic. Me with $10 in cash and Ana, sporting only Hong Kong Dollars (HKD), I'm envisioning the Triads are going to abduct us! 

Ana explained our sorrows to the bartender and offered to pay in HKD. Mind you, Ana is a 5'-10" Brazilian knock out and she's speaking in Cantonese. 

$465.88 HKD = $60.00 USD. Bill paid. I kid you not.
Shénme shì ygè widà de ycì widà dì dìfng!
author: David N.

description: Thought this would one of those gimmicky places that is overhyped but it is definitely the opposite!! Their Chinese Mai Tai's do not disappoint. I've watched them make it a million times as I sat at the bar and there is a decent amount of alcohol in it. Not sure how a cocktail with so much alcohol can taste like candy but it's no wonder why this drink is so lethal. Great place to start and/or end the night. This place is a little small and gets pretty stuffy in the back, definitely recommend sitting by the bar. It's not dark and dim like most bars so the atmosphere seems a little more lively. They also play pretty good upbeat music which is always a plus.
author: Maryann S.

description:
Shady business practices!

Met here on Thursday night with two clearly drunk friends, I just came out though so I was dead sober. I ordered three Mai Tais, and watched as the bartender went off to the side to make them... and was extremely upset when I noticed that he was faking putting booze into them. He just tipped the bottle and pretended that he was pouring, wtf... Drank it afterwards and yep, just a mix of juice.

As I was paying, the guy stiffed me on the change I got back, shorting me by $10. I called him out and he gave me the correct amount - but it was pretty obvious that it was intentional.

So I guess this business tries to take advantage of drunk people, not cool. I'm not coming back - I'll stick to Buddha Bar across the street.
author: Justin P.

description:
What can you say about this place that Bourdain hasn't already?

Plenty! He was slithering drunk when he came here and probably had to review the tape to figure out what the hell happened. 

Wife and I went on a whirlwind weekend in SF to getaway.

We love walking down empty creepy Chinatown streets at night after we took a ghost tour a few years back. This place is located in the creepiest of empty dark streets. 

On a Sunday night this place is empty.

A thin, Chinese, well postured bartender in his 60s hooked us up with the house special...the Chinese Mai Tai. 

What else would you order here?

All the ingredients are predictable except for the Chinese whisky. 

I asked him what was inside of Chinese whisky.

"Herbs...it is healthy," he said. 

He looked pretty good for 60, so I tried one with my wife.

After a large dose of this I was mentally transported back to Shanghai (although I have never been there). 

I think this was at the drink they used to subdue unsuspecting people to passing out and then shipping them to China the next day from the underground dungeon. 

I'm not sure about the "healthy' part, but this is a pretty easy way to get all bus'.

"I'll have another!"
author: Michael M.

description:
A couple of friends took my wife and I here for happy hour. They explained that it was one of Chinatown's many hole in the wall gems, with great service and a friendly atmosphere. This is a dive bar with some character and friendly bartenders. One that I definitely enjoyed my time at and would love to go back again. 

Located in the middle of the block, you can't miss this bar because of its unique design and style. The exterior looks like the entrance of a cave, which I thought was a pretty cool design. When we arrived we had two bartenders. The first bartender I didn't get his name, but he was very down to earth and made us feel welcomed from the moment we stepped inside of the bar. The second bartender was an older gentleman named Peter. Peter was great and had the spunk and vibe of a 21-year-old. Cracking jokes and even challenging us to see sports trivia. He clearly knew a lot about the liquors he was serving and even gave us a brief history of each one of the drinks we were interested in.

The two popular drinks served there are the mai tais (which can sneak up on you if you're not careful) and the Chinese whiskey that is aged and comes in a really unique and awesome looking bottle. The layout of the bar is pretty simple and it wraps around to the back to revile bench seating & booths for larger parties. The Decour however is cool. It's a combination of Chinese artifacts and historical items combined with a flat flatscreen TV to watch sporting events on. However the bar is pretty dark and you can lose all track of time if you're not careful. Also because it's in Chinatown is strictly CASH ONLY, that means no credit cards, no debit cards are excepted there. Another issue that I had with the bar is the fact that they don't serve any meals there. So it's strictly only for drinking. Finally the fact that the back area is for seating bigger parties can me seen as a flaw in my eyes. Because if they replaced the booths with a pool table, it would make things there even more fun In-between drinks.
author: Donald W.

description: Fan of the decor and the vibe...another chill local dive bar. I am suspicious of their claim of making the first Mai Tai. While it was tasty, it was a bit light on alcohol and I've certainly had better.
author: Greg K.

description:
While wandering around Chinatown, we decided to pop in for a drink.  There were quite a few people, so that was a good sign.

Sadly they didn't have any happy hour specials.  We ordered a Maker's on the rocks and an apple-tini.  The bartender was nice and made a good drink.

The atmosphere is unique, and the further you go into the bar the dirtier it gets.  I was fine staying by the bar!
author: Greg S.

description: Just like everyone else I stopped by here due to Anthony Bourdain. I got the Mai Tai just like everyone else as well. They definitely hit you pretty hard, but I hope so since they're $9 in a dive bar. After 2 of them I called it a night. The atmosphere is alright but the bartender pretty uninterested. He was on his phone quite a bit or talking with his friends and it was hard to grab his attention unless you walked up to him. I think this place just lives off of tourists due to Bourdain & doesn't care about service.
author: Arthur K.

description: A must see dive bar stop if visiting Chinatown in SF. Drinks are amazing and atmosphere intriguing. You're sure to have a great time at this bar!
author: Sabrina S.

description: The music was good but the Mai-Tai is not what I expected ( strong wise ). I had 4 and I should have had 4 Jameson shots instead and save more money.
author: Jsphn T.

description: Mai Tais for $9!  Cash only though.  A great dive bar in the middle of Chinatown.  It's a great place to either start or end your night ;)
author: Tammy N.

description: This place is pretty cool but they ran out of rum (how?) and made us a whiskey and coke instead which was not good. When we asked for something else they absolutely would not accommodate under any circumstances. Ridiculous to lose a customer over a six dollar drink. Buddha lounge across the street has better drinks and service.
author: Bridget B.

description:
This might be one of the oldest bars in China town.  It's a dive but there are opium den style fixtures and decor that must be antiques and bring you back to a bygone era. 
Anthony Bourdain was there in 2012 and he liked it.  

The Mai tai is the best you ever had- not too sweet, nice and tart, with a Taste that is deceptively non-alcoholic.  Be careful not to drink too many.
author: M S.

description: Honestly, this place will make your Chinatown drinking experience! The Mai Tais are delicious-and absolutely lethal! Very much worth the low, low price of $7. It is a party up in this joint. Here for a good time, not a long time? Lo Pi got you covered.
author: Michael G.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE!
Reminds me of that movie Big Trouble in Little China with Kurt Russel!

Yeah the decor could be a touch off putting and the crowd can get a little colorful but time and time again this bar has gotten me more drunk than I care to admit. Its the same place as seen in Bourdains show. Him getting drunk while at that place was an eye opener for me and compelled me to at least try it out... at least once. After having gone several times I have come to the following conclusions of what one should do when ones goes to Li Po:

Go in... 
Get a Mai Tai... 
Drink Mai Tai... 
AND THEN REPEAT! 
Repeat as often as humanly possible till you cant repeat anymore. 

Thats what I do every time I go and I end up having a great time! I love it! Went there for gatherings, bdays and for future SF events. Its always a great time!
;D
author: John-Michael C.

description: Best MaiTais ever!! They do a delicious combination and they are addicting.. The bartender is always so friendly and talkative, everytime I've gone here it has always been a great experience in ChinaTown. Following Anthony Bourdain's footsteps :) I love how every person at this bar all sip on Mai Tais and nothing else..
author: Julie R.

description: I happened to be walking through Chinatown after dinner and Yelp directed me here. If there was a definition of "Chinese Dive Bar" in the dictionary it should have a picture of this place. I'm not sure how clean it was or the last time they updated any decorations but it was pretty awesome. Once you sit down and rest your elbows on the sticky bar, you'll see a menu written with Sharpie and the front page says, "House Special Chinese Mai Tai." Order it. Not sure how much booze they added but it was extremely strong. Still tasty, but very strong. After 2 of these I was done. At least until the next bar.
author: Andy P.

description: The legendary Chinese mai tai lives up to the hype. It's by far the best rum drink you'll ever have. I don't know if they are as potent as some say. I had 3 and was happily buzzed but certainly not walking in a blur. The place is VERY clean oasis in the middle of mostly gross Chinatown. Bartenders are friendly and have the mai tai down to a science. Seating is mostly at the bar. You might have to wait 10-15 for other people to clear out to sit closer. It is CASH ONLY but they have 2 ATMs on premises.
author: Heath H.

description:
Li Po is a great bar for many reasons.  It's got a borderline cheesy decor that I can't get enough of, they play Giants games on HUGE TVs and the drinks are heavily poured.  The man and woman who work here (and I assume own it) are hilarious.  They love to talk to you while they make your drink and the man always wears the best (cheesy) hawaiian shirts.  We get the signature maitai and rarely order more than 2 each before we spill out into the Chinatown streets because those bad boys are STRONG.

We saw that Anthony Bourdain came in recently because, of course he did.
author: Carmel U.

description:
After a long day at work, we love to just chill here for a nice strong drink! The Mai Tai's are killer! Simply a great blend of Light Rum, Dark Rum, Barcardi 151, Chinese Liqueur, and pineapple juice.  

Sounds dangerous because it is! Lol It's so refreshing that if you're not careful, you can easily drink 4 and leave there drunk as ever! It does creep up on you! 

Most my boyfriend and I have drank is 5 Mai Tai's!  Love the bartenders as they are so friendly and funny!  

This place has many tourist as it is right smack in the middle of Chinatown.  

After a few drinks, so many choices to eat in Chinatown...but after hours, you'd have have walk towards North Beach!  Not too bad of a walk...you won't even notice because you'll be feeling yourself, enjoying the SF breeze, and ready for whatever the night brings you! Enjoy! Remember it's cash only, the do have an ATM at the entrance.1
author: Candice V.

description: Not really a fan of dive bars. Gross toilets usually turn me off.  The atmosphere is a little weird. It has the vibe of an old Chinese brothel. I was waiting for the mama-san to come out over the balcony and parade her merchandise. But the bartender here was really friendly and as we sat there that afternoon, the bar started to fill up.  I guess Anthony Bourdain put this place on the map because its seemed like it was all white tourists. We were the only Asians in there. In any case, try the Chinese Mai Tai, it was pretty delicious.
author: Kenson K.

description:
Imagine that you are in a crowded chinese inner city and you wanted to stop in for a drink.

You walk in and you see a bunch of other tourists located in the same area. You can feel the excitement and the small talk floating around you as you listen to 90's pop rap and R&B.

Overall, great experience. Bring a date or some friends or you will die of boredom.
author: Enpo T.

description: When you walk in it smells like urine . But just go to the back and order the best Chinese  Mai tai! Everyone drinks them !
author: Cheryl W.

description: Hidden gem in China town the bartender Amos was so nice and the Buddha beer was real good as well
author: Karen L.

description: Dark, general location with some of the most generous pours & friendly people Chinatown has to offer. The music was on point too! Didn't see that coming. It was fun to take a regular breather & step out into one of the best Chinatowns in the country! San Fran baby! San Fran
author: LaDarian D.

description:
one star for the bartender which was a asian lady who was nice and talks really politely and gives lots of smiles out to patrons ... good attitude 

2nd star for the convenience a bar in china town to grab a quick drink 

3rd star for the fast service as soon as I walked up the bar she asked what I wanted and it wasnt a full house but it was filled on the bar area.... 

4th star for the chinese mai tai it was sweet drink lots of pineapple flavor and its pretty strong with all the rum and 151 in it too just on the pricey side for it 9 bucks guess its in sf so cant complain 

one star down for the restroom. it was dirty and the mens restroom had no paper towels or a door if someone has to go poo poo .... 

overall I think I would come back for a quick drink or need to hangout and meet some friends to chat because there was like no loud music where u have to yell....
author: Alex T.

description: TV sensation turned one hit wonder. Anthony Bourdain must have missed the fact that once you're famous, pineapple juice and ice are the cheapest additive to water down a Mai tai. Go across the street for a stronger, more 'authentic', cheaper fun time.
author: Alex L.

description:
Came here after I was forced out of the house from recovering over the stomach flu.  My best girlfriends were all off that day, and celebrating a birthday at it, too.  I had to get out, just promised myself to stick to water.  After all, I had to call in sick.

Well, I think that day marked the first day to eat solids and drink non-water liquids with comfort and ease.

Bar was pretty empty, only a few random tourists were in here.  

We had the frothy mai tai with the chinese whiskey and 151 float.  Gulp.  I drank half- and was drunk already. Granted, I hadn't eaten in four days, it was still delicious and I still remember paying my tab.   

Bartender was friendly, and my girlfriends and I had a blast before heading to R&G Lounge.

Thanks for the good times, guys.  Apparently Bourdain came in here during The Layover. Well, shoot.  If Bourdain digs it, you KNOW i'm there
author: Cat A.

description: We were staying for a few days right near China town and came here a few times. It was a lot of fun I mean China town is great and this is no exception. Tried the Chinese Mai Tai but not my thing, still great environment.
author: Todd W.

description: Alice's the Chinese Mai Ti. Our bar tender was funny as hell and very helpful. Some of San Francisco's finest from SFPD were ripping it up and stumbled out after fallowing off chairs at the bar funny shit!!
author: Micaela S.

description:
Li Po's Cocktail Lounge is a dive - with a miraculous Chinese Mai Tai well-worth the trip. This place has become a frequent stop for me, one that I share with most of my friends visiting from out of town. 

As stated by Anthony Bourdain, the mai-tai's are lethal. Deceptively tasty for the amount of light rum, dark rum, 151, and chinese rice liquor that goes into the crafting. Two mai-tais are usually all you need.

A word of caution, if drinking mai-tai's no additional shots are needed. I've observed more than one acquaintance suffer the next day after failing to recognize the power of the mai-tai.
author: David G.

description:
The bartenders were nice and friendly. They like to talk to their customers, especially on the Thursday night we went out, when it wasn't too crowded. 

I ordered the Chinese Mai Tai, and the lady bartender said, "What kind? You have to choose a liquor!" So, I read the list on the sign: Dark rum, light rum, Bacardi 151, Chinese liquor. I didn't want 151 or Chinese Liquor, so... "Uh, I'll have the Chinese Mai Tai with light rum, please," I asked the other bartender. He says, "You no choose! All inside! All inside!" Haha, still makes me laugh.

Cool dive bar with chinatown flair. The Chinese Mai Tai was indeed strong and sweet. It was easy to drink, but you will definitely be drunk after drinking a whole one.

There is a lot of character here, and it is a fun must try experience--at least once, if you live in SF. If not, it's not a big deal. Just go if you're already in the area.
author: NY C.

description: Cheap, fun, and really chinese.  I like it.
author: Jon Q.

description: This place is so skanky but if Anthony Bordain likes it then it's great in my book. The Chinese Mai Tai was...like a Mai tai. In fact I wasn't the one who ordered the drinks and when I took a sip of it I blurted "this tastes like a Mai Tai" lol and like the whole bar got quiet and everybody looked at me and all these crickets were chirping then I saw that "Chinese MAI TAI" was written everywhere all over this bar lol. That's my story.
author: Emma H.

description:
Like everyone here, I came here for the mai tai. It was advertised by Bourdain as being "lethal" so I had to see for myself.

I don't by any means consider myself a mai tai connoisseur, but I really freaking enjoy them. It's a taste of Hawaii for me, and real good one always seems to evoke a slight moment of island fever for me.

So was it "lethal"? Yes. Drinking one of these certainly gave me a certain hightened sense, knowing that in an another drink or two I would be on my way. Did it taste "lethal"? Not at all.

The difference here is that they incorporate a Chinese Liqueur into it (I don't remember what the name was). While the bartendress decribed it as tasting like gasoline, I certainly wouldn't describe it that way. She poured us a sample on its own to taste what it was like, and as best I can remember it was like vodka but slightly sweeter and fruitier. 

But overall, a REALLY tasty mai tai that I would come back for if I'm in the area.

As far as the place itself, it's definition of what a bar is and should be. Not a lot of frills, makes you question whether you've made the right choice in being there, and all about drinking.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Jeffrey J.

description: The location is easy to find and uber will drop you right off in front. Check out China town it's a good time and definitely go here. Start out with a beer then move to the traditional Mai tai and enjoy the simplicity of the drink! It's quite a buzz from the drink and would make a return trip for both the suds and Mai tai
author: John R.

description:
Stopped by on St. Patty's Day for a green mai as I heard they were great. They were not bad but I am from Hawaii. Perhaps Bourdain should visit the islands.

The crowd and staff was great and had lots of good convo. Bathrooms were nasty. This is a dive but I would go back.
author: Russ S.

description: Always a great stopping point in the city of San Francisco. The Buddha beers are a great mid day drink. The Mau tais keep things classy as you continue to drink more. Always a good dive spot.
author: James C.

description: I'm so sad I didn't catch my bartenders name. But he was soooooo funny and charismatic. Exactly what I needed in San Francisco! He even gave me a great tip on a place to eat. I was there Wednesday afternoon:)
author: Swlabr X.

description: Chinese Mai Tai's. Try them. They're delicious. The inside is cute in its own way. Definitely a dive bar. The music was great and made the time spent here enjoyable. Seriously, we were jamming. The bathroom downstairs is a little scary but we came in to try these mai tai's and they were certainly worth the trip into China Town. Definitely a place to try if you're in San Francisco.
author: Karina M.

description:
Li Po = reminds me of a OLD chinese movie
Bartender wore a hawaiian shirt and even had those curled up mustaches?!
Ok drinks
Didnt realize Li Po was so small. It seemed bigger in Anthony's Layover episode.
Cool, laid back feel.
Good place to just hang out if you are around the neighboorhood but i wouldnt drive all the way there just for drinks.
author: Carol Y.

description: THIS IS TH WORST BAR I HAVE EVER BEEN TO IN MY LIFE!!! DONT DRINK THE "CHINESE MAI TAI"!! It's fucking $10 and it tastes like fermented melted cherry popsicles but not in a good way. I ordered a mai tai NOT a Chinese mai tai, when I got it is was so undrinkable I tried to exchange it for something else and they literally pretended my to understand my English when I asked politely for something I could actually drink! I don't normally write reviews, I consider myself a kind person and it takes a LOT to push me to the point of writing such a negative review but this place is exceptional. This is my one night in San Fran and I am soooooooo disappointed!!!  Also the basement is a bad frat party, just don't, if you value your night go anywhere else!!!
author: Heather P.

description:
Having some SUPER STRONG Chinese Mai Tai's , this place is a Legit Chinese Dive Bar.....
A must see when in San Francisco's china town. 
It will actually be featured on upcoming Layover show in SF.
author: Michael S.

description:
Oh my gosh - I found a Chinese Dive Bar!   I love dive bars!

I didn't even know it was 'famous' until writing this review, Anthony Bourdain really went here?! Cool, now I like it even more (if that is possible).

My first item to note:  CASH ONLY!  Be prepared.

This place is so cool, the decor is so kitschy, but not since it is very Chinese cultural looking, Buddha behind the bar and everything.  Just neat, you have to experience it yourself.  Then you have Justin Bieber playing overhead and giggle a little...music certainly didn't fit the atmosphere, but it is a bar, so its cool.

My party of three all ordered the Chinese Mai Tai by recommendation of the lovely bartender.  Wow - rummalicious.  Whatever Chinese liquor they pour in with the rum is very good too.  I think the bartender said it was made with roses??? Or maybe I just made that up, I can't remember.

the guy next to us ordered the Adios...it looked good and I almost ordered another but I was out of cash and wasn't about to use random ATM and pay fees.

I caution you on the bathrooms - yuck - they are hot little dungeons and a bit scary.  Hold you bladder for the next stop.
author: Jasmine B.

description: Like many, I came here because I saw their Mai Tai featured on Anthony Bourdain's show. It is such a hole in the wall with old worn down handwritten signs that you wouldn't really think to go in there. So glad I did. Their Mai Tai is delicious. It's not overwhelmingly sweet. It's a reasonably priced one at $9 by San Francisco standards. The bartenders were very nice and welcoming. I didn't try anything other than the Mai Tai so bear that in mind. You should know that this place is cash only. They have an ATM inside. I saw someone else drinking a beer I really like. It's called Lucky Buddha. If you like beer, give this a try when you're there.
author: Karine K.

description:
Not many redeeming qualities.  Pretty basic neighborhood dive bar.
The facade is interesting, and it has the benefit of staying open on all the normal holidays - like christmas eve.
author: Ric S.

description: The Chinese Mai tai that they serve has changed, different liquor and weaker. I used to love this place.
author: Nick A.

description: I saw this place on Best Bars in America and had to give it a shot. I love a dive bar and the idea of a dive bar from my favorite show with cool history and exotic charm put it on my list. The fact that Anthony Bourdain likes it is a bonus also. We all ordered the Chinese mai-tai and it was damn good. The place looks so cool, it's got this old school, 30's look outside and inside. They have this cool old lantern over the bar and the bartenders were super cool. We went downstairs where my body said "this has to be a triad hangout" and for all I know, it could be. I can't wait to come back.  Sidebar: it's still a dive bar. You wouldn't want to take a girl here on your first few dates. This is definitely a dive bat for friends and regulars. The interior is a bit tattered and that's not a bad thing, just know what you're in for.
author: Kevin D.

description:
After hearing about the hype of the Chinese Mai Tai's at Li Po's, I decided to try it out before the Chinese New Year parade.  The Mai Tai's are indeed delicious, but I was not really feeling the buzz.  They have a huge sign on the wall that says the ingredients are dark rum, light rum, Chinese liqueur and pineapple juice.  I was excited because orange juice makes me sick and was excited to read that they didn't put it in their mai tais.  I went to sit in the back booth area and there were boxes that were placed for recycle.  Guess what was in the box?  Bottles and bottles of Mr. & Mrs. T Mai Tai Mix.  They are using pre-made mix and saying it is their famous Chinese Mai Tai!!  That is pretty shady and a blatant lie to their consumers! 

Their music is good 2008-2009 playlist but it's fun!
author: Moni K.

description: $9 Mai Thai's with barely a shot of liquor in them. Nope Ill save the money next time and stick with the Buddah Bar across the street.
author: Madie H.

description: That Mai Tai is delicious!! Totally lives up to the hype. I just had one, but could drink more... Don't bother ordering anything else. Quirky spot, fun music. Not as diverse of a crowd as I would've preferred- maybe would've stayed longer. Destination spot for sure, though.
author: Christina R.

description: I grew up in SF.  Been going to Li Po before it was hip.   Still maintains it core coolness.  Great drinks great vibe and great service.
author: Johny O.

description:
CLASSIC Asian bar and one of my favorite bars in SF.

Mai Tai's are suuuuuper strong. Bartender is a character. Hardcore West Coast rap playing in the background. What else could you want?

Drinking game: try to make the bartender laugh. Achieve this rare feat, everyone else chugs their Mai Tai. Drunken antics ensue.
author: Billy A.

description: This place is amazing! This dive bar serves the best Mai Tai's I have ever had.
author: MEF F.

description: Coolest bar in SF! Best Mai Tai I've ever had!  Great atmosphere and awesome dance music which is totally random!
author: Alex B.

description: By far the best bar in San Francisco! Had a few mai tis with my boyfriend. We both thoroughly enjoyed them. There are 4 different types of liquor in them, so they are definitely not for lightweights but they are so delicious. I think the best part of the bar though was the bartender, Amus, who was hilarious and very welcoming. If you're ever in the city you gotta come here.
author: M W.

description: Great spot to grab a cocktail when in Chinatown! Their Mai Tai is AMAZING! We try and stop in at least twice a month!
author: John D.

description:
Really cool.  Definitely stop by for a Chinese Mai Tai which is the house specialty.  I love what my half drunk wife said, 'It was dirty, it was fun, and I would go back in a heartbeat!"  

No chinese were there, only anglos, but it was fun
author: David J.

description: The Chinese Mai Tai was great but the vibe was not what I was expecting. The decor is the kitsch I figured would be there but the main lights were on so it kind of felt like hanging out in someone's basement with their mom upstairs.
author: Jason S.

description:
From the outside, this place is somewhere nondescript - not that it's plain or blank on the outside, but it's got a design and decor that you would pretty much expect to find in Chinatown.  There's a sign outside that reads out the name, but otherwise, you can't really tell what lies beyond the doors until you actually get inside.

Once you do cross that threshold though, you find yourself in the middle of what you would imagine a typical Chinatown dive bar would look like.  Kind of dirty, yet homely sort of feel, relatively cheap drinks, Chinese alcohol galore, Tsingtao in hand, and a Buddha statue behind the bar.  Yup, that's right...a Buddha statue hanging out behind the bar, watching you as you order yet another round of drinks.

The bar definitely has an aged look and feel, with the worn vinyl booths, and the aged appearance of the walls.  Obviously, the place has been around for a number of years, like the rest of Chinatown, and you kind of wonder what kind of characters and people this place has seen pass through after all these years.  There's a dimly lit, narrow little booth that's tucked into the wall towards the back, and you start to think of the types of people that might have made that their regular table.  

Awesome little place in Chinatown to grab a few drinks, especially if you're in the mood to try your hand with something like Chinese whiskey.  I had a fun night chilling with friends, enjoying a few rounds, playing cards, and having a good time.  The Chinese Mai Tai seems like their specialty, and one of my friends really enjoyed hers.  Even if you're a guy and you're curious, go ahead and order it...the Buddha statue won't judge.
author: Mike L.

description: Went here for my birthday on a Wednesday afternoon. The atmosphere and decor is really cool. There was no one in here but it was 3pm. I tried out the famous Chinese Mai tai... Delicious!! And the bartender was a very nice woman. We will be back.
author: Sylvia L.

description: It's a bit grungy..so definitely not a nice or fancy place for a date. But it is a great place for a casual hangout or a round of drinking games! Their Mai Tais are super effective lol 1-2 will keep you on a good level all night.
author: Cheri K.

description:
Me and my friends always hit up this dive bar first when we visit Chinatown. The bartenders are aways friendly, providing us with fresh popcorn (sometimes burnt!) to soak up some of the alcohol. 
"HI JACKIE & WINNIE!" :)
author: A C.

description: Try the Mui Kwe Lu or  Ng Ka Py liquor or the chinese mai tai.  It would seem they've raised their prices since Anthony Bourdain's televised visit.  Go figure.  They also have buddha beer and your standard well drinks.  Overall a nice place to drop in to.
author: Theron L.

description:
Worst service. Rude owner. Highly suggest going across the street for a drink. 

Extremely Rude
author: Gareth L.

description: The Mai Tai was good but place was kind of rough around the edges and I found a large cockroach upside down in the women's bathroom.
author: Bethany B.

description:
This is a hole in the wall in the best way. It feels like a chinese speakeasy and the Mai Tais made with that herbal alcohol, are powerful stuff...seriously, after 2 you might as well say good night to your friends because you may not remember the rest of the evening.

I really like the ambiance and friendly service. I've never seen it on a weekend but the weekday patrons and bartenders are funny and never forget a face. Makes me feel like a cast member of Chinese  Cheers.  As the terminator says "I'll be back".
author: Courtney L.

description: 5 stars just for their Chinese Mai Tai. Besides, Double Fine used this place for one of their game code names!
author: Joe G.

description: Strong Mai Tais! Greatest $9 spent!
author: Audrey C.

description:
Liked the Mai Tai. Didn't care for the roach that skittered across the wall. Pretty sure there are more rooms underground that just keep going down and down into opium dens and slave trade hiding places deep into the underbelly of Chinatown...
I was here at 1am on a Thursday and we were the only customers. Music ranges from Lion King to R&B to Chinese pop.
author: Kelly R.
