description: I really like this little dive bar in Chinatown. Bartenders are great and attentive. Good cocktails and a cool little lounge area downtown. Great alternative to bars filled with tools in the marina.
author: Ry B.

description:
I checked this place out after seeing it on The Layover. It is a very cool place with interesting decor and friendly bartenders. The Chinese Mai Tai's are strong!--  contents include Bacardi 151 and some sort of Chinese liquor from a ceramic bottle!

Cash only.
author: Garrick L.

description:
After searching for a good dive bar in San Fran, I read several reviews telling me I had to try LiPo. Everyone suggested the Mai Tai and the Chinese whiskey. 

I wandered through Chinatown passing 30 Asians crammed into a small store scratching off scratchers like the world was about to end. I knew I must be close. I finally found the place (after challenging a small Chinese man to a scratch off) and ordered a Mai Tai and a shot of whiskey. The prices were decent, $6 for the whiskey and $9 for the Mai Tai. My friend and I conversed with the bartender, Jackie, about opium and happy endings (isn't that what you are supposed to talk about?). She was very friendly and even gave us a free shot of Chinese liquor, which tasted like shit. 

The bathroom in this place is downstairs and is pretty creepy. I am fairly sure there is a another hidden room right next to it where they have bands sometimes. 

Everything was going good at the bar and I was on my way to a 5 star review. However, things took a turn for the worse when we paid our bill. They take cash only so we gave the bartender $60 for $42 worth of drinks. We received $12 back in change. Some may think it was an honest mistake. But, after speaking with Jackie about it, I am 99.4% sure she tried to play an ancient Chinese trick on us. You know the one where her English and math skills all of a sudden deteriorate into 4 year old level when money is involved. I asked her for the rest of the change and her reply was, "oooooooh my math no good." Now, this may sound stereotypical, but I have never met an Asian who is bad at math. I mean, she even had a calculator out. 

Anyways, if you are in Chinatown and want a good Mai Tai, stop in. The drinks were really good and the vibe is cool. Just make sure you don't fall for the ancient Chinese secret.
author: Jared M.

description:
Divey, Chinese mafia type establishment. 

I came drunk. I got even drunker. Those f'ing Mai Tai's will kill you. Strongest in town apparently. Of course cash only.

Oh yeah and Anthony Bourdain came here? Hasn't made the place infested with tourists. That's a good thing.
author: Paul B.

description:
I'm a fan, not of the bar, but of the event they hold in the basement.  It's hot and sweaty and awesome.  Sweater Funk is held every Sunday night in the basement of this dive bar.  Located in the middle of Chinatown, if you get there a little early, it can be hard to find parking.  After all the shops close, you can pretty much park right outside.  The bartenders are pretty laid back and make decent drinks (a little overpriced).  The security guy was awesome, hung out with us before we headed downstairs for the festivities. 

The music is AMAZING.  If you're tired of listening to the mainstream hiphop/rap/club banger/house music at the typical clubs, PLEASE COME TRY THIS PLACE OUT.  They play funk and soul music that will cleanse your audio palate.  It gets PACKED.  Body up against body.  That's the only downside, other than that and the fact that its on a Sunday night (for us working people) I pretty much love this event.  No cover.  No need to be on the guestlist. The crowd is really MIXED.  Younger hipsters, older folks, people out the cuts.
author: Richard N.

description: Came here for the famous Chinese Mai Tai. It is definitely a dangerous drink. Initially, it tastes like straight pineapple juice but once you get to the middle of the drink, you taste a little bit of the alcohol. All in all, the taste isn't as strong but you  feel the effects of it fairly shortly. 3 of those and that should suffice for the evening. As for the bar itself, it's located in the heart of Chinatown but if you looked at the clientele on a Friday night, it definitely did not feel like a Chinatown bar. It's a fairly small bar with some seating but you do feel cramped inside. The ambiance felt like any standard Chinese restaurant, dingy lighting and walls, etc. I would come again with a group just to try the Mai Tai.
author: Jimmy D.

description:
Bring a ton of cash and just get Mai Tais... 

overall: the bar is really small, the type of crowd varies drastically every day, price are reasonable

other: there is really bad cell phone service (random, but true).
author: Rocky C.

description:
There is only ONE reason to come here - Mai Tais. They're pricey in my opinion ($9) and they only take cash (sucks if you're that sucker in the group, me, that is the only one with cash for several rounds). Delicious none the less. 

Discovered this place after a local swore by it. He said go to the Empress of China's top floor bar (right down the street) and get a Mai Tai there just for that experience since that bar is famous and has been around since the 50's. Then he said meander over to Li Po to taste a real Mai Tai. 

This place attracts a really interesting crowd, very easy to talk to whoever is next to you. Quite hilarious if you look down the bar, all you see are Mai Tais.
author: David P.

description: My recommendation: grab a few drinks at Buddha Lounge and then hop across the street here. The payphone has no phone, there's an ATM, and a mix of a divey/Marina crowd on a Friday night. I think coming back here during the day may be a better choice. But all in all, good times.
author: Mel G.

description: One of the best bars in San Francisco. Great service, excellent Mai Tais with healthy doses of bai jiu. Folks here are generally very friendly and it's a great place to escape from some of the crowds on the street. Would recommend it to anyone visiting San Francisco. Check out "Good Mong Kok" bakery just up the street from here whole you're visiting.
author: Michael L.

description:
Everyone should try the Chinese Mai Thai here at least once. It's made by friendly bartenders, even though the price has gone up thanks to Anthony Bourdain going there on his show (thanks for that, asshole). 
I've seen many things in this bar, including little kids sitting at the bar, insanely drunk guys playing Donkey Kong, and a woman falling on her ass down the stairs that lead to the bathroom in the basement. 
One of the other great things about this place; it's right across the street from Buddha Lounge so you can walk back and forth between the two!
author: Roxanne R.

description:
The Chinese Mai Tai is the shizzle!
Popular little spot in china town.
Been there for a very long time
author: Antoine V.

description: Interesting experience for sure!! After exploring Chinatown and munching on some dim sum we stopped here for a Mai Tai. It was great!! The friendly feel of the bartender and fellow patrons, coupled with the Asian dive bar atmosphere and Flo Rida on the playlist made for a fun afternoon break!
author: Julie M.

description: This place sucks now that Anthony Bourdain was here and ruined it for the locals. They added terrible bright lights, crappy loud music and a crappy wall and door at the entrance. Not to mention the price of the Mai Thai's is ridiculous. Like most things in SF now it was better before anyone knew about it. Stay away from this place.
author: Joel F.

description:
San Francisco's best kept secret

Apart from the Antony Bordain thing...

But seriously, you will not find a better Mai Thai in the world.  Ask for Jackie who is there almost every day... I've been there several times and she makes them the best.  

Spoiler alert: you only need 1, so its a good place to start your evening.

Anyway, go along, its seriously worth the $9 for a drink.
author: Julie B.

description: A friend heard of this place in Chinatown so we had to try it.  It's a bit of a dive bar, but the Mai Tai's made with Chinese liquor were really good.  I only tasted my friend's cocktail as it would have knocked me on my bum.  The bartender was great!
author: Marcia B.

description: This is a fun place.  We didn't know about it being on Anthony Bourdain's show until we overheard the other patrons talk about it.  Anyway, our bartender Amos, was hilarious!  He definitely made the place very lively.  The Chinese Mai Tais were very good!
author: Gc L.

description: Horrid!! Do not come here. They are racist. We said we want to fix our drink cuz it did' t taste right and the bar bitch said " thats not my problem". Excuse but you just made us a horrible drink and you r gonna give us attitude. Chinatown altogether is a bad place with rude people. They have tape to cover the holes in there sofas. Terrible place. Please don't go there.
author: Dimp M.

description:
Mai Tai Mai Tai Mai Tai Mai Tai Mai Tai Mai Tai. I sat around drinking that until I couldn't tell the Mai from the Tai and the Tai from the Mai, and could barely raise my finger high enough to even order another.

But god damn it all to hell is it ever good! From a heavy Mongolian drinking style, this is the only mixed drink I've ever had that gets you that good swirl.
author: John L.

description: Buddha Beer!!! You can take the bottle home as a souvenir! This place attracts alot of tourist but a good spot to go during the week.
author: Rosanna T.

description:
We mainly went here just to try the Mai Tai that everyone raves about. Definitely worth stopping in for a drink if you are visiting Chinatown.

We were here on a Saturday afternoon and easily found two seats at the bar.
author: Jason K.

description: I have had so many good times here and it still never gets old. I love Li-Po lounge. Their Mai-Tai's have a strange way of hitting you all of a sudden which always leads to  good time when you are with a group of friends. They have seating all around the bar, a large back room with tables and a small booth that seats up to 5-6 ppl. If you're looking bring a larger group, they have a huge space below that they rent out every so often.
author: Andrea R.

description: Everyone comes here for the Chinese mai tai, but whatever. The drinks are pretty expensive, but it's a warm dive bar with dice for Liar's Dice. You do have to pay a deposit to play, but it's not a big deal. I love how this place is big and has plenty of chairs and counters. I'll take that every day of the week. So long as I'm comfortable and warm while drinking beers and throwing dice, I will not really complain too much. The clientele isn't terrible either, but the door guys are creepy. The one last night hit on my girlfriend right as we entered the bar.
author: Danny C.

description:
Carolee M. and I went to experience the Chinese mai tais ($9 each, http://s3.amazonaws.com/foodspotting-ec2/reviews/2383288/thumb_600.jpg?1347340621?1347593799), but my goodness, it was cloyingly sweet from the first sip. Bleh, I am feeling horrible just thinking back on how ridiculously sweet it was. We also tried asking what the mysterious "Chinese liqueur" was that goes in the mai tai, and we got a not-very-helpful answer of "rose liqueur" without any indication of which bottle it came out of. Oh, well: what did I expect from an Asian bar? We entertained ourselves instead by reminiscing over Carolee's recent Japan trip. Sometimes the company is all you need to come out of a mediocre bar with a smile on your face.

The verdict: Eh, I could live without going back to Li Po. There are much better places to get cocktails.
author: Tiff T.

description:
Don't get fooled by the poorly lit entrance in the very center of chinatown. As soon as you see the Li Po sign board, stop right there and get in. 

Take a seat at the bar and order one of the best Mai Tai you ever had. Not too sweet, not too dry just perfect, and they make it with an authentic Chinese liquor, something they are very proud of (they'll probably tell you ;-) ). Just make sure not to drink it too fast or you'll start seeing double. 

Another drink for the non-Mai Tai fans I'd recommend is their electric lemonade. It's a refreshing blue cocktail that just looks cool (almost glows in the dark).

So next time you're in Chinatown or even nearby, go to Grant and have a cocktail at Li Po (preferably the Mai Tai - did I mention it's made with true Chinese liquor?), you won't regret it!
author: Nicolas S.

description: Don't let the somewhat shady exterior fool you. This place is awesome AND is the oldest bar in Chinatown! Great Mai Tai (dangerous! tastes like juice, but is loaded with multiple types of booze) - which takes them barely any time to make. We were lucky enough to get a picnic style table in a little nook close to the bar. Cash only.
author: Lauren C.

description:
It's a happy dive bar that could only sprout in Chinatown.  For a legit dive bar, you could do a lot worse. There are no strange odors here and they even have electronic gambling stations for 65 year old dyed-in-the-flammable-wool alkies (you know who you are!)  

On a Friday night, it didn't get overly crowded and seemed frequented by a lot of regulars.  Yes, it is an odd mix of people and seems to attract people celebrating birthdays and engagements.  There is a not-so-secret back room near the bathrooms where a private party with lots of sleepy people was going on.  Oh, and they had one of the most laid back and friendly bouncers I've seen.  Then again, this is Cali!

Maybe I'm used to drinking straight liquor, but the Chinese Mai Tai was not too strong at all and for $9 I think it's a fair price.  I'm also familiar with the wide range of 'Chinese liquors' that can strip the lining from your esophagus so my baseline comparison will be different from, you know, gwai los.
author: Czarina B.

description:
Woah...didn't even realize this is the place that Anthony Bourdain hit during his Layover show! Damn then where was that place where he had that cheeseburger!?!?

Loved this dive bar for oh so many reasons. It's got an interesting vibe going. It's smelly and the drinks are cheap. The crowd is mixed, age and color wise (is that even safe to say on Yelp without sounding like a total ass?) Definitely glad we hit this place first to get our night our drinking started!!
author: Gabby A.

description: Order the Chinese Mai Tai like Anthony Bourdain did. It is $9, tastes delicious, and it gave my friends and I all a solid buzz. I will definitely go back.
author: Kelly B.

description:
If you are walking around Chinatown browsing the bazaars, and feel like resting your feet, why not drop in to this dive-y bar to rest your feet AND re-hydrate yourself? 

Some of the things to look forward to inside: 
Respite from the crowds outside
Nice strong Chinese mai tais
Friendly bartender
author: Raul S.

description: Who knew this place even existed? I've been in SF for over 4 years, and spend a good amount of my weekend nights out and about. My friends took me here and from the outside, it looks like a tiny little place. Low ceilings and crowded, it is a great local spot with lots of space as you wander back. The oldest bar in Chinatown. Their signature Mai Tai is potent, delicious, dangerous, and quick. There was actually a dog in there with us. Good but loud music. Great booths for groups. Cash only. FUN!
author: Wendy K.

description: I passed by this place while driving thru Chinatown after the Giants game.   I remembered it from Anthony Bourdians show, Layover.  Nice crowd. Definitely would go back.  The Chinese Mai Tai was as delicious as everyone says.   Fast and friendly bartender.
author: Kisha Y.

description:
As everyone has said before, get the Mai Tai special.  Guaranteed to mess you up after the 2nd one.  We went here on a whim after dragging our feet up and down the mighty hills of San Fran.  It also hasn't help that we were hungover from hanging out Napa, but I digress...

The bartender happened to be on Anthony Bourdain's layover.   She was extremely kind in letting us use her outlet to charge our iPhones.   We also highly recommend the Chinese Whiskey (infused with Asian herbs).  The place is super divey, but super clean.  Love the Buddah statue boo...
author: Christian L.

description:
Chinese Mai Tai.

This is probably the weakest mai tai I've ever had. 

I was watching her make mai tai's. No matter if she's making 2 or 3 at the same time, she puts the same amount of liquor when she does 2 or 3. The only thing that makes this "chinese" is the chinese whiskey. And they just put a splash of it in the mai tai. If I'm correct, that bottle of chinese wine is some cheap stuff. (I'm not too sure, but I've seen it at grocery markets)

This place is old and dingy. Only nice part is that they have a big screen tv. 

Yes, I have seen this on Anthony bourdain's show, and I wanted to come here, but this is pretty disappointing.
author: Erica L.

description:
One of my favorite dive bars of all time. I've been in several times and figured that most of the bartenders must be "cougars." Vanessa is my favorite. She'll joke with you if you have a big group and throws in a few free songs. She'll also sing along with a few songs you wouldn't think she would know if you buy her enough drinks, haha. Love that they also serve you free bar snacks like nuts and popcorn. Not many places do that anymore. 

I went in on a Thursday night and an older gentleman was serving drinks. He was very accommodating and sweet... He humored me and spoke with me in Cantonese even though I was drunk and I know my Cantonese is pretty terrible while sober... So who knows what I was saying that night. I always get their special ingredient mai tais... While the other bartenders make it pretty strong, this guy loaded my drink up! Not that I'm complaining, I like a drink that'll put a little hair on my chest. 

Love the ambiance. It's laid back and talking to fellow tourists is always fun. 

Another reason why this plus gets five stars: The jukebox has trance! Love love love!!
author: Lynn H.

description:
Delightfully divey. I came for the infamous Mai Tai, consisting of 3 different kinds of rum, the "special Chinese liquor," and pineapple juice.. It was the kind of drink that's tastefully misleading. I felt that thing within an hour. I stay wary about paying $9 though, but still it's pretty good. The bartender that evening was really friendly and nice too.

I took a nod (much like other Yelpers have said) from Bourdain's The Layover. Glad I did.

I'd come back. Woo!
author: Alison A.

description: I came here (as did a million other santas) on Santa Con. The place feels "divey" but don't let that scare you away. I tried the Chinese mai tai which has whaler's dark rum, castillo light rum, barcardi 151 rum, chinese liqueur and pineapple juice to disguise all the alcohol. The drink was a bit hard to drink because it wasn't blended well but given the popularity of the place, I'll venture a guess that normally its made a bit better :). The drink wasn't that strong, tasted yummy and was only $10. WIN! The back part of the bar also has a booth to sit in and some tables to stand around.
author: Emily C.

description:
While on one of our dinner dates, Sara P. and I decided that it would be a tremendous amount of fun to take a Friday evening bootcamp class at the Chinatown Y, then get drunk afterwards.  If anyone knows the definition of random (and fun), it's us.

So we ended up at Li Po, where two rounds of $9 drinks, an apathetic bartender who didn't know how to make the drinks but took out his glasses, squinted at the menu, and made some STRONG drinks for us, and some really awesome 80s and 90s music later, we were pretty sure that if we didn't leave, we wouldn't make it back home.

But that's what friends are for, right?
author: Tori S.

description: This place provided a pleasantly weird diversion from the usual Mission-bar-crawl fueled weekends we typically have. Meet strangers, strike up random conversation, and enjoy their famous Mai-Tais. The bar could use a facelift but the retro feel is part of the charm.
author: Katie H.

description: Bartender was a douche and didn't offer change (33% tip? No.) the Chinese whiskey is something awful. And there is shady shit being guarded by a slight Chinese man in the back. SUPER COOL!
author: Kay R.

description:
An awesome place to drink Ng Ka Py surrounded by the feel of kitsch and subterranean opium dens.  It is impossible to avoid a place named after the author of:  

"If Heaven weren't fond of wine
Wine Star would not be found in Heaven. 

If Earth weren't fond of wine
There could be no Wine Spring on earth. 

Since Heaven and Earth are fond of wine, 
In Heaven being fond of wine can't be judged wrong. 

Clear wine, I've heard, is compared to sages, 
Also the unstrained wine spoken of as worthies. 

Since I've drunk both sages and worthies
Why must I seek out the immortals? 

Three cups penetrate the Great Truth; 
One gallon accords with Nature's laws. 

Simply find pleasure in wine: 
Speak not of it to the sober ones. "
author: Orin B.

description:
Oh my.
I don't even know where to start with this one. 
It has a certain je ne sais quoi...
After sweating out the week, Vicky L. & I decided to go on a Chinatown bar crawl. When we first walked in, it was packed with Marina-ish types. Thankfully they left after a little bit. 
We headed towards the back and snagged a booth. There is a really creepy booth in the back we called a rape booth...it would be perfect for that. 
The drinks were strong. Strong is probably an understatement. I had 2 drinks and had a good buzz. 
It's a great place to start the night :)
author: Sara P.

description: Ancient, beautiful, friendly, and you can entertain yourself for an hour trying to penetrate the patina (visually) on the murals from the 1940s. The mai-tai sounded too sweet, but the Chinese whiskey special was fine, and the bartender was charming, polite, gorgeous and articulate.( I have no idea how many languages she speaks but her English is heavily accented but fluent, subtle and expressive.)  At least on a weekday evening, this for all its crazy decor is basically a pub--score!
author: Suzanne E.

description:
Stop #2 on our China Town bar excursion, Li Po Cocktail Lounge.
It must have been a slow night in CT because only a handful of booze goers were held up here. The BF wanted to give it a try since he seen it on an Anthony Bourdain episode. Place was a feast for the eyes, something to look at every way you turned your head. The bartender was fast and attentive but could have lent a smile every now and then. 
We went in for the Chinese Mai Tai and never looked back. Perfectly concocted every time. It's obvious this was probably the specialty, or one of them since the bartender seemed to know the exact measurements without even looking. 
I've never been a fan of mixed drinks, blended ones at that, but it was quite tasty. Definitely lots of alcohol, but surprisingly not overpowering. I had two and called my limit. 
Not sure what the ambiance is like on other nights, since we were just passer-Byers. Can't say this would be one of our main stops on a return trip to SF, but if in CT...might as well.
author: Valerie S.

description: Place is dirty, incredibly loud, and the service is poor. I literally had to leave because I couldn't get served. Don't bother, this place is a dive and not in a good way.
author: T P.

description:
The mai tai is sickly, sweet, amazing, you have to order it.

Secret chinese liquor.

Bring all your friends, in drag.
author: Mark P.

description:
Style: Kung Fu Hustle meet Marylin M. meet Andy Wharol.....pretty Kitsch but cool
Service: very rude waitress earns the place 2 stars
author: M S.

description:
I asked the old Chinese bartender how to say "Kung Pao chicken" in Cantonese. Instead of answering my question, he handed me a glass of water. 

Huh?!?!

I have blonde roots. Help!
author: Suany W.

description: Zero stars. This place doesn't allow service dogs. Which is against the law! Also, Mai tais suck. Service is horrible! They have a lawsuit on their hands!!!
author: Chloe H.

description: Haven't been here in ages!! Stopped by for a quick visit and my usual bartender Winnie isn't in! BUT Amest (no idea if I wrote his name right) is really chill and talkative. So stop in and say hello!
author: Jay K.

description: This place is rad!!  Been here a handful of times and always loved it.  Beer selection is no big deal but they make an excellent Singapore Sling.  I've usually been too intoxicated to really measure the price to value quotient but I'm satisfied.  I love the cave-like feel and look of both the outside and inside.  I love to go with my friends and get that booth that's all covered and secluded near the stairs to the bathroom downstairs.  This place is rad!!
author: Sin F.

description: Mai Tai was the best I have ever had! I paid nine dollars a drink and I think it was a good value considering how much booze was in there. The bathrooms were not great, but not the worst. I hear the iPod DJ plays sweet 90s songs on weekdays.
author: Amber S.

description:
I'm sorry. Huge fan of Anthony Bourdain, but the owners got a hold of that video of him coming here and thought of the amount of business they will get from it. The point is that their "Chinese mai tai" is a joke.  Sitting at the bar watching the Bar tender make these things and she is pouring max 1 shot per 2 mai tai's and charging 20 bucks.
Next stop...somewhere else. 
The sign on the wall describing these things screams "ill get ya drunk!"  Turns out it's just a whisper.
author: Mike G.

description:
Awesome dive bar in Chinatown. Jackie (bartender) is a sweetheart. Order the Ng Ka Py (Chinese Whiskey)! DO NOT TOUCH THE TREE ON CHINESE NEW YEAR, YOU WILL GET SCOLDED!

They've got the best music and dancing in the basement on Sunday nights (SweaterFunk!!!).

Cocktails are a little overpriced because the cups are small & I hate using the bathrooms here -1. Other than that, I wish there was better bus access, cause I'd be here all the time!
author: Harold C.

description: We saw this place on the Anthony Bourdain Layover show and it was more than what we expected.  The Mai Tai's are unbelievable and the bartender's are awesome people.  Can't wait for my next trip to china town SF.  Until next time Jackie and Winnie.
author: Tim B.

description: great place - divey, seat yourself kind of place. Very chill. drinks were strong, people nice and music a little loud. Would come back again but going to try to not walk away with glue from duct tapes on the seats again.
author: Ruby C.

description:
Great dive bar in Chinatown.  It was featured on Anthony Bourdain's Layover.  The Mai Tai is a must have.  They are a bit strong, but for $9 they better be.

The bartender was friendly and made a great drink.  What more could I ask for?
author: Jeff P.

description: This place was AWESOME!!! Got a Chinese Mai Tai, the guy behind the counter was HILARIOUS! It's not trendy, or hipster, but it was PERFECT for our last drink of the night! Cash only, so be prepared for that!
author: Cassie O.

description:
We were recently in SF for the day and decided to recreate Anthony Bourdain's Layover San Francisco.  So we decided to stop in here and get a Chinese Mai Tai.

We had never explored dive bars and Li Po did not disappoint.  Total dive with cheesy Chinese decor.  Awesome!

We only had one Mai Tai each and that was enough.  Pretty strong and tasty. Not sure we would go out of way to come here, but if we have out of town guests and visit SF this will definitely be on the list.
author: Stewart B.

description: Dark and Divey just like Anthony Bourdain said it would be. Our bartender was friendly and created those Chinese Mai-Tais expertly. The decor is interesting for sure and the drinks are incredibly strong. You'll want to walk out of this place my friends - no driving for sure afterwards.
author: Deb S.

description: Blended mai tais are exactly what you should go for and always keep some cash on hand, maybe you'll even run in to tony b!
author: Amy V.

description:
Best Mai Thai you will ever throw down your gullet. Guaranteed. 

And the bar staff? AMAZING. So friendly and quick--we love sitting at the bar and making conversation with them. The last time we went, it got really packed with only one bartender. She never quit smiling and busted her ass to make sure people didn't wait long. 

After a nice dinner in North Beach, go have a Chinese Mai Thai!
author: Marit S.

description: Cash only! The Mai Tai is deadly. It's way too tasty! Great bartender and awesome atmosphere.
author: Alexis M.

description:
Friends are like it's time for Ch-ch-ch-change. So I'm like let's got to Ch-ch-ch-Chinatown! This dive is kinda' creepy on the left side but that's the reason to rave it up here.
We got our sugary drinks and had a blast with the staff and the other young ones who poured in through the door. Happiness in others, happiness in a glass, that's what it takes for met shake my ass! Romance could be better but that's 'cause I got bad habits of selection.
Serious though, I loved it here enough that I know goin' back will be a let down.
Li Po Cocktail Lounge deserves to be on the wall of fame for my nights of massive insanity, dig?
author: Alexander R.

description:
The interior looks just as crappy as the exterior. What I did not expect is the clientele that this place attracts. When I was here, this dive was overrun by hipsters and drag queens. Seriously, it was like a crazy mishmash of Urban Outfitters, neon wigs, hooker heels, dirty hair, and the air was heavy with the scent of smugness and sweat. Apparently, the downstairs of this place is the hot place to be. 

I'm not even a drinker but the mai tai's here are amazing. I couldn't even taste the alcohol in it and I'm very picky with drinks. Seriously, try the mai tai.
author: Nancy C.

description:
If I lived in SF, I have a feeling I would live at this bar. It was dark like a cave when we wandered in at 3p on Friday. It had an Asian theme (duh, since it's in Chinatown) and looked like it had been around for a while. I don't know what it was about the place, but I immediately felt at home. It reminded me of Time Out or Yucca in Tempe.

Bartender was a pleasant young lady who didn't seem too chatty, but was quick to start up the jukebox when two more couples wandered in (I found it touching and mildly amusing that she chose "Stayin' Alive," "Hotel California" and then a Whitney Houston jam - like she thought that's what us white folk/tourists might enjoy).

I was also mildly amused to see that the bottles on display behind the bar were conveniently marked with a Magic Marker with their price for a drink (simply "8" or "6" or "5"). Pretty smart, really - every bar should do that.

The bartender at Bliss Bar mentioned that this place also hosts small shows in their basement. I got a glimpse of this area when I ventured down the steep steps to the bathroom (scary bathroom winner, with it's dim lighting that becomes near-darkness when you shut the stall door and cheap, tissue-piece-style paper like your elementary school had...it's also what they had for paper towels too: wha?). Anyway, I don't know that she specifically said "punk shows" but that's what I'm going to assume and therefore declare this my favorite dive in SF (though it's a close tie with Zeitgeist).
author: Lauren V.

description:
Probably the best little dive bar I've been to since...ever. My girlfriend & I didn't get that "locals only" vibe - it was a party atmosphere & everyone was invited. We didn't even need to get the bar tender's attention. He was attending to our orders within two seconds of our bottoms hitting the bar stool. Of course we ordered the house special - two Mai Tais - which was prepared with such skill & precision as to amaze. To put it perspective, the folks at Jamba Juice measure their ingredients & still have leftovers in the pitcher. Our bartender, Amos, eyeballed all the ingredients & poured two perfectly measured glasses with nary a drop left to waste. Which was good because the house special's fame is well earned. They tasted great. 
Overall it was a great experience in a fun & historical location. Anyone visiting San Francisco would do well to make a quick stop for a Mai Tai. You won't regret it.
author: Daniel B.

description: In the heart of Chinatown this has a great dive bar atmosphere.... authentic & charming. Well priced local beers and Mai Tai's. Played fun music. Definitely worth a stop when visiting san francisco. Cash only!
author: Julia M.

description:
Mai Tai's! Kinda pricey but very good! the long island was good too!

they have booths in the back where you can sit and just hangout. Downstairs they have dodgy restrooms but whatever. and if you walk around the corner, there's a dark room where a band was playing, literally, an underground band!

this is my kind of bar.. friendly people, good drinks, and a chill atmosphere. so much better than that snobby ez5 bar. 

head to sam wo after. :)
author: Lara P.

description:
Who would think a dive bar in Chinatown would be so much fun? This has become a staple in our dive bar rotation, especially when we're over the mainstream bars of North Beach. Jackie, the owner & one of the bartenders, is amazing! Super friendly, and makes very strong Mai Tais. In addition to the Mai Tais, you must get the buddha beer, which is an Asian beer bottled in a buddha shaped green bottle. If you want to have a true Li Po experience, make sure to grab some dice and play liar's dice!

A few items to note:
* A huge mix of people visit this place; everything from a random tourist group who happened to walk by to local residents who speak chinese only. 
* CASH only, but they have an ATM at the entrance and there are also several banks nearby.
author: Kevin C.

description:
HA
This place reminds me of any one of those stereotypical Disney Channel/Original Movie scenes where a sweet little old Chinese lady tempts you with a fortune cookie and consequently turns your world upside down. Maybe some mix of Freaky Friday and What Women Want. 

Except this time it's a feisty middle aged Chinese lady and she's pressuring you into some hangover-in-a-gulp mai thais. 

Came here for a birthday party so I can't assess the regular crowd, but this was my first bar in Chinatown and it was a nice switch up of the regular going out scene. The downstairs basement feels like a frat basement (really dark, some random couches which might have been placed there or there just wasn't space upstairs) and is the perfect place for impromptu dance parties with some hip but anti-top 40 friends.
author: Joanne S.

description: crappy bar - GREAT mai tais - we ended up getting two rounds for 5 people for less than 40 with tip each time. there was room to seat us all together and the bathrooms weren't bad.
author: Nicole S.

description:
My friends and I came here last summer to kill time before we went on a Chinatown ghost tour meet up.  We loved everything about the place- the old school vibe, friendly bartender who served us up some STRONG mai tai's and the red booths in the back.  *We sauntered in because I'd always been drawn to this bar from the outside.  We were very lucky to have experienced the Li Po before the recent Bourdain blessing.

I feel like we all made our personal connection with this special Chinatown bar and we enjoyed our time talking with the bartender about the history of the place.  Thanks for the mai tai's & the memories!  If you're hanging out in SF's Chinatown you MUST come in to have a drink and experience the awesomeness of the Li Po Lounge firsthand.
author: Kristina F.

description: Terrible drinks with a bartender who doesn't really care about you. I gave the extra star because it seems like a great place to watch people get hammered off 7 dollars drinks made from a 7 dollar handle of tequila, stand near the stairs and they will fall.
author: Michael W.

description: We fall in low with bartender: she's amazing! Thank you so much for putting on Spice girls for us! And yes, their Chinese mai tai is a must have )
author: Katie K.

description: A divebar in the heart of China Town, Li Po Lounge is a great place to catch a quick drink if in the neighborhood. After being visited by Anthony Bourdain, this place has likely become more popular, but was rather quiet during my visit. They have a large selection of beer / liquor, however, their specialty drink is the Chinese Mai Tai. Service was good and prices are fair.
author: Michael B.

description: Bartender was the sweetest thing ever.  Didnt catch her name, but you can tell shes been there for awhile.  She talked with us, took our picture, she was just the most friendly bartender ive ever experienced.  She warned us how the Mai Tais sneak up on you and she was right!  HAHA.  My boyfriend and I had one on our own, and then shared a second and that was enough!  We were good to go for the rest of the day.  DELICIOUS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  Cant wait to go back to the city and stop by this place again.  A must if you are in Chinatown!
author: Chelsea A.

description: Best bar ever! Oldest bar in Chinatown!  The Chinese Mai Tai are amazingly delicious!!  They're $9 but Totally worth it!!  Ask for Jackie!!  She's awesome; makes great drinks & is suuuper nice!!!  She could make a Mai Tai blindfolded!  I'd fly to San Francisco just to come here!  Cant wait till my next trip!!
author: Jaye V.

description:
I guess this place just wasn't my cup of tea. However, I could totally see why this place is very cool to some people. I went to this place to see a show in the basement which was really stuffy and claustrophobic. The service wasn't even that good at the bar and the cocktails weren't that great. 

Interestingly enough, I did have a great time here but it was mostly due to the people I was with and not the establishment. I even remember saying throughout the night that this place made me feel dirty.
author: Rylan C.

description:
Divey little bar where you can get a slightly pricy, but undeniably tasty, house Chinese Mai Tai in Chinatown after a dim sum dinner. 

Didn't realize Bourdain visited here, but it was a chill place to have some drinks. There are stools along the bar and a few booths in back to sit. 

Cash only.
author: Andrea B.

description: The place and people here are so odd. You walk down Chinatown to get to Li Po and once you get in, it looks like a dive bar meets tacky Chinese gift shop. I think there was a special event because all these hipsters were dressed in traditional Chinese silk robes drinking their mai tais (which were on the pricey side). so weird. Place is cash only.
author: Cindy A.

description: I saw this bar on Anthony Boudain "the layover" I decided  to try it out when my buddy flew into town from Denver. The inside of the bar is really cool. It feels like a bar in Hong Kong or Shanghai. I tried the infamous mai tai, it was really good! I just had one and I was little drunk. This place is fun. My friends and I had fun at Li Po. I went to go back soon!!!
author: Brian B.

description:
Saw this place on THE LAYOVER, and then accidentally found it walking through Chinatown. We sat down to a Mai Tai and the last quarter of the 49er's-Saint's playoff game. Not sure what the place is really like as the atmosphere was poppin because of the game. 

The drinks were strong and the bartender was funny.
author: Trevor S.

description: This place is amazing.  Random music from the 2000's that are stuck in limbo and amazing Chinese Mai Tai's that will F you up.  Awesome bartenders and great janky vibe.  A unique and must go see if you're in town.
author: Jay H.

description: Bartender had a major attitude, very rude!  A friend told her today was my bday and she immediately assumed I wanted a free drink.  Sorry to burst your bubble hot head...I don't drink.  She also refused to give me a refill on my soda.  She definitely scared most of the customers away with her attitude
author: Brittani H.

description: Friendly staff.  Great mai tai.  Can't go to China town without at least a quick stop in.  A lot of love for regular s too.
author: Kyle F.

description: Awesome stop on our tour of San Francisco.  Chinese Mai Tai was good and strong.  Bartenders were very friendly and if it wasn't for a long day of being a tourist I would have spent the entire night yacking it up with locals and drinking Mai tai's.
author: Matt H.
John G.

description: We came here right after work, and it was pretty dead (though I'll admit, I was somewhat surprised to find rather attractive patrons at the bar). It's super kitschy with its stereotypical chinese decor, but I dug it. We tried only the mai tai, but it was tasty and strong, just the way we like it.
author: J J.

description: My 1st time at Li Po after a while of my cousin telling me, you need to go here! I was introduced to Vanessa, the bartender who was very nice. And I had my first Chinese Mai Tai! That sucker was so yummy and soooo strong! That sucker tasted so good I think if I sat there a little longer I would be wasted from only 2 drinks! What a Deal! Want to get shit face for cheap go to Li po!! The atmosphere is very cool too, feels like you transported to a movie set. Oh and side note: I dare you to go next door and take a photo of their storefront, there are signs that states, "no photos" (because they are selling bootleg products). Old man RAN outside and Screamed at me, kinda funny, try it!
author: Karen T.

description: Friendly bartenders, interesting atmosphere, and delicious Mai Tais (don't have too many)!
author: Abby S.

description: We'll most definitely a dive. But the Mai tai are amazing, they import Chinese Liqueur Music is pretty entertaining if you're into usher and tupac from 1995. Cash only
author: Ashley B.

description: this place is a dirty, old, stale looking dive in chinatown... and guess what.. i love it!  you really good some good bang for your buck here.  $9 for a mai tai that will get your night started off right.
author: Tina L.

description:
*review for SweaterFunk*

I WANT to give this spot 5-Stars for the SweaterFunk dance party alone, but my big-boyness won't let me rave about a place that made me perspire that much.

SWEAT, much. Thankfully the FUNK refers to an illmatic hip-hop soundtrack rather than odoriferous aire.

Set in the low-ceiling'd basement with no windows and a solitaire electric-fan struggling to cool the room, SweaterFunk felt like one of those "below the radar" gigs: once a month on the last Sunday(?), an anti-"ultralounge" decor, music more rhythm than rhyme, and a patronage/vibe that brings all its heart to the dancefloor. 30 minutes of a hyped dancefloor in a stifling hot room, walking out into the deserted Chinatown night was a refreshing breath of air.

We didn't stay very long (it being the end of a long, lush Pride weekend), but its definitely on my list of "must" for hip-hop, dance, and good vibes...
_____________________________________
I'm very self-conscious, but it was so hot in there, even I rocked down to a tanktop. 
*farmer tan shame*
author: Mikey U.

description: Beware of Ken! He is a Mai-Tai ninja. you won't know what hit till you wake the next morning.
author: Beth K.

description:
Oh My Gosh.

Take me back about 4 years ago and it would place me in the basement of this bar listening to a punk band perform.

A nondescript location other than the large sign hanging outside with the works L I P O written in stereotypical Asian scroll style and a bright red color, of course.  Reminded me of those seedy bars in old movies, complete with the sewer grate near the curb blowing up foul smelling steam.  

The interior of the bar is actually cozy, with stools up against the bar and surrounded by rounded booths done up in worn red vinyl.  Lighting is dark so be ready to stumble if not careful.  Off to the left of the entrance, is a stairwell leading to the basement of this bar.  Here, it opened up into a small concrete room, big enough for a small band to perform.  Here, I stood for an hour or so, listening to the music amidst the whirling curtains of smoke.

When I left this bar, I had to send everything to dry cleaning the very next day.  But for the experience, I'd recommend a drop in for everyone  :)
author: Miika M.

description: Only came here for the Mai Tai's and came out feeling good and happy. Trance music is an interesting choice for this spot, but somehow it works. The bartender was really friendly and the Mai Tai's were well priced for the amount of alcohol in them. We had dim sum before so to have felt the drinks after the first round says it all. Uber out of there before too many and go home to take a nap.
author: Fran E.

description:
Walking around in Chinatown on Friday morning my friend and I spotted Li Po and wondered why we hadn't noticed its cavelike facade before...... it looked cool... THEN LO AND BEHOLD it's one of the dive bars we're stopping in Saturday night during the Yelp dive bar Pub-Crawl.

I did have to deduct a star because although the decor around the bar in Li-Po is super the jukebox sucked. I put in a $1 and had trouble finding 3 decent songs.... then once I put in my selections and they started to play.... we could barely hear them... Booooo!!!! 

Next time you're in Chinatown and need a drink pop in to LiPo and admire the decor while you enjoy a drink, but bring your headphones : )
author: Lori K.

description:
I love happenstance. Here's a Tsingtao toast to fate's crafty ways!

A year ago, a random night of barhopping in North Beach and Chinatown lead me to discover Li Po, a bar that my Grandfather was once part owner of--only my Dad had forgotten to tell me! "What?" you say. Exactly my point! Life never ceases to amaze me. Anyhow, let me paint a figurative picture for you, ala 80's Golden Girls style...

Picture it. San Francisco, 1939. The Chinatown nightclubs had officially taken off with all its glamour and zest for living it up! We're talking hot babes in skimpy outfits and tap dance shoes, men in dapper suits, lots of drinking, gambling, and of course right in the middle of it all, was my Grandfather. He was quite the Ladies' Man, so I'm told. Sort of a Chinese baller from a bygone era. He was such a frequent customer at Li Po that he decided to buy into the whole scene.

Walking though the arched rock facade of the doorway, it is more than easy to imagine what it must have been like. It hardly seems like a moment has past in its deep-seated red and gold flecked existence. I'm sure that many a big gambling games have gone down in the darkened booths that are so well hidden in the back. Perhaps it was even frequented by rebel gangs like The Tong, back in the day. The dimly lit Chinese lanterns hide a lot of history--who knows what else my Dad "forgot" to tell me! 

Once a dive bar, always a dive bar! These days, Li Po's basement holds Free Sunday 80s Funk shows and also a bit of Punk and Rock. The relic of a bar upstairs is an intriguing mix of older Chinese men, hipsters and bar hoppers with 2 things in common: a yen for good, strong drinks and a place with character. You don't have to go very far inside to realize this is the Real Thing. From the timeworn wraparound bar to the gold alter quietly swirling incense into the air, everything about their decor says "Authentic."

Don't be afraid to take a dive into a little history with a bar that doesn't try to be "Chinese themed." It just IS!
author: Kira R.

description: The Mai Tai was awesome! I then had a Buddha Beer that was tasty as well. I wish we could have spent more time here but maybe next time we visit San Francisco.
author: DJ V.

description:
A friend of mine turned me onto this place and it was love at first sight.  I can't imagine a more charming dive bar absolutely slathered with character.  What a perfect place to take someone who is new to the city.

There's not much of a scene here, either, which is exactly how a dive should be.  It feels almost as if you're discovering someplace wonderful for the first time.  Every time I've been here (week nights) it's nearly empty, just me, a friend, another couple at the bar, and the sweet, quiet bartender.  

Belly up to the bar and have a shot of Ng Ka Py.  You won't regret it.
author: Amanda R.

description:
I love Li Po. I've had one too many drinks here one too many times. Usually pretty quiet, except for the one time I was there and a (no joke) busload of people from Santa Cruz came stumbling in on a pub crawl.

What I really like are the Mai Tai's, even though I'm adverse to 151 in most any other circumstance. Yeah, they're pink and look a little foofy but they pack a solid punch.

-2 stars for how cold it is when you sit near the door.
+1 for Jackie because she's awesome.
author: Mr. C.

description:
Li Po was an 8th century Chinese poet who wrote "Drinking with friends washes away the sorrow of a thousand years".

This bar was a popular hangout for the beats and apparently has not changed much since Jack Keroac, Alan Ginsberg and others drank here. I've never seen a band or whatever it is they do in the downstairs basement but as a bar it does its job quite well.
author: Bart C.

description: solid chinatown dive bar with cracked booths, affordable and predictable beer selections, and good cocktails
author: Sonya Z.

description: The Chinese Mai Tai is well worth the trip. Our party of four all really enjoyed it and craved more the next day. I recommend visiting during off hours - we were there at 2:30 on a Monday - so that it's not crowded and you can get to know the bartenders. Amos makes a mean Mai tai (obviously) and is a huge basketball fan. I also ordered the Lucky Buddha beer which was also vey refreshing.
author: Marisa C.

description: Good atmosphere for a very casual bar. We found the mai tai very weak despite what some have said in their reviews.  After watching the mai tais being made we would have been lucky to get one nip of total spirit in our drinks. For $9 we felt a bit hard done by although they were refreshing.
author: Luke B.

description:
This is a dive bar with personality.  Think expat bar from Chungking Express.  You've got the waitress hamming it up with the locals - smiling, flirting, trying to convince to us to get the special Mai Tais.  You've got the locals coming in to play the video card games or lounging at the bar in Tommy Bahama shirts.  You've got the Chinese neon signs and huge lantern over the bar.  It's great!

Tsingtao beer is $4 but the special Mai Tais are what to get here.  $8 and they will knock you back.  I recommend not having more than 2.
author: Jean K.

description:
I never would have guessed this place existed right smack dab in the middle of Chinatown!

I wish I took pictures but the place was so jam packed that I could barely breathe.

We went in a Sunday night, which was apparently "sweater funk" night. There is a dance floor downstairs which I heard gets hot and stuffy as soon as the break dancers let loose.

I didn't have anything to drink here since I was the DD but I heard their Mai-Tai cocktail is nice and refreshing. They have a good selection of Chinese liquor and beer. The bar is cash only but that shouldn't be a problem if you hit up the ATM beforehand.

I will say the crowd is a good mix. I think I saw every spectrum of clothing that night. I would like to come back when it's slow, then I can really take in the essence of the bar.
author: Bernadette A.

description: MAI TAI. Served by a lovely bartender in a cool neighborhood in an interesting bar - one of my favorites places in SF
author: Meenu K.

description: This place was a little different than the other places in Chinatown. The clientele was the fanny pack wearing, safari hat sporting type. Needless to say , besides the crowd that say Anthony Bourdain's pic in the window, the Chinese Mai Tai will mess you up. It isn't cheap, but it is strong. They remodeled it, and the back part of the bar is a little boring and just dressed up with Ikea sconces and not much else. The bar seemed to have all of the obnoxious patrons and wild behavior. It is a fun stop on the tour, but make sure to see some other places as well. Staff is nice.
author: Chris S.

description: eww! these bathrooms are so gross! you have to walk downstairs, and then the bathrooms are there, with the doors open! guys can hear girls peeing! and vice versa! well, at least these bathrooms aren't filthy.
author: Fzarond K.

description: Came due to Bourdain's experience here.  Don't really like Mai Tais myself so I was pleasantly surprised how good they were here.  A lil sweet but that's probably to hide the taste of alcohol.  For a stiff drink it remains enjoyable sip on.  The ambience is interesting as well.
author: Stephen V.

description: Nice place. Was told that its like a caricature of Chinatown and the place did not disappoint. Would come back for sure.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Dive-bar to the max.  Here are a few "I seem to remembers" :
Late at night when the dice come out
It's a dive bar with a photobooth, who doesn't love that!
Renting this place out for halloween was a smashing success and a great way to avoid the mobs of castro.
Drinks are cheap and stiff...Chinese Whiskey?
They've got a funky basement area that's great for dancing, or for rocking out to a french punk rock band.
author: Nikki M.

description:
Pros: 
  * only bar I've been to in SF with an HSBC across the street (my bank)
  * Pacman table gaming system
  * PBR

Cons: 
 * Reeks of cigarettes
 
It really depends on what you're looking for. If you're heading from SOMA to North Beach then I guess it's along the way but there are better pit stops.
author: Adam D.

description: did anthony bourdain cause this?! who are all these asshats that go here now? and they raised prices! oh well...this seems to be a theme in SF now. see: the owl tree. :(
author: Kate W.

description:
I love this bar. I've been here on a dead Sunday afternoon and again during the Chinese New Year Parade. The atmosphere, decor (and sadly bathrooms) are exactly what you'd expect in a dive bar. For the full Chinatown experience drink their mai thais (3 kinds of whiskey including 151!) and some Chinese whiskey, which tastes like jager and bourbon mixed together. I noticed the price of the mai thais varied depending on who ordered and which bartender we got. Even the signs on the bar conflicted, some said $9, some said $10. 

On my first visit I didn't realize there was a back area with booths, which is great if you're there with a few friends. You will probably make some new ones too, like the gaggle of gasians screaming "TWINSIES" who made me take a picture with them because we were all wearing red plaid shirts. Fun place, but don't come here for beer because it's all $5 whether you order a Bud or an Anchor.
author: Beth D.

description:
I have been there twice now, and each time I met a different bartender. The first bartender was an older gentleman name Peter. He was a really friendly & easy going guy. I really felt welcome because of his peaceful demeanor!

The second time I went there, was earlier today! Today, the bartender was a sweet gal named Jackie. She was super friendly also!

The bar's decor seems like an old 50's diner that has seen a lot of parties; with a few chinese decorations thrown in there too :) I think it is charming in a non-pretentious sort of way, which I really appreciate. They have cozy booths for small groups of people and high bar stools like you'd see at a classic milkshake joint from "Leave it to Beaver". Oh, and the parking there at night is easy!

In terms of clientele, I might suggest meeting some friends there the first time, unless you feel like meeting some random locals; which can be fun too :) Any way, the people that work there are cool, the bar is cute, and you don't feel like you are in a frat-house marina/northbeach joint at all.
author: Wayne N.

description:
For those who prefer pounding Chinatown flair by the frosty gulp-ful; Li Po makes the finest (blended) midori sour in town, served up more often than not in concert with a toss of the dice at a bar that (fun fact!) boasts the largest built-in Buddha in Chinatown. If you love kooky hole-in-the-wall joints where the odds favor the most unlikely of events (i.e. the live shows I've seen in Li Po's basement, especially the Ariel Pink extravaganza, are like experiencing a near-hell pleasure ride within the confines of a moist, blackened lung) then Li-Po is the place for you, weirdo. 

p.s. there's a sit down Pac-Man table too!~
author: Kelly O.

description: Favorite bar in the city. I try to come here anytime friends come into town to give them the Chinatown experience! The Mai-tais are pretty outstanding, and I always gulp them down. Amos the bartender is the man and as friendly as they come.  Downstairs can always be a fun little boogie-sesh if you are so inclined. Really a great place to go for a couple powerful drinks!
author: Tighe B.

description:
used to be great before the hipsters took it over..
spent many an evening here...liquored up many times here...
would stop after gigs in san francisco..sometimes i wonder how i got home.
went here with my brother bruce many times..(Twin drunks)
I think Kerouac would have liked this bar...
author: Brent P.

description: Great atmosphere, amazing Chinese Mai Tai, and even better service.  So friendly, we felt like family (by the regular female bartender--she was there last time we were there too).  Love this place.
author: Dean H.

description:
Growing up in San Francisco, my parents would take me and my sisters to Chinatown every freakin' Saturday and Sunday to buy groceries and eat lunch. Li Po had been around all this time. I knew it was a bar, but it was always dim when I walked passed it, so I never quite saw how it looked on the inside. 

I finally had the opportunity of a lifetime this weekend after my family dinner to check this place out. Man, this place looks like it came straight out of the movie Rush Hour, except more janky. They had a huge Buddha in the corner, and Asian crown moldings all across the top of the bar. There was a Chinese diner-ish seating area in the back. 

Maybe I'm spoiled in Sacramento, but our two bottled Coors Lights and one cranberry vodka came out to $13! That's a little steep for a dive bar, I would say. And it's certainly divey, since the floors didn't look all that clean, and I was scared some rat or cockroach would jump out at any moment. But it's alright. I've finally experienced Li Po. That's all that matters.
author: Diana C.

description:
I "discovered" Li Po when I was walking back to work after lunch in Chinatown.  My co-workers were on the hunt for custard tarts and were bummed that the bakery was closed for the summer (vacation). 

I was immediately intrigued by the big red doors of Li Po.  Once I saw that it was a bar I knew that I would venture back.   And I will again.

I went here with a large group of co-workers and I had a great time.  Drinks were good, stiff, and inexpensive.  Special Mai Tais were flowing, but I stuck to the cheap beer.  

The decor is classic dive bar with a Chinese twist.  A big ripped lantern hangs over this dark predominately red bar.   Buddah watches over you, the bar and the res vinyl booths.  The jukebox had Happy Birthday in Cantonese if you feel so inclined.
author: Katharine A.

description: This place is freakin' awesome!!!  My favorite bar hands down.  Really no other bar has a vibe quite like this. It's always well populated but not too crowded.  They're always playing the BEST Hip-hop jams, I mean to the point that you're singing along, yet it's not clubby.  It has a real neighborhood relaxed feel where you can just be yourself and everybody knows your name.  Kinda the Cheers of Chinatown.  It's a great place to go either by yourself, on a date, or in a group, it works every which way.  I'm lucky to have this as my neighborhood bar, it's a less than 10 minute walk from my apartment, and when I have friends from out of town, I take them there and it never disappoints.  And did someone say "Mai Tai"??!!  It's the perfect combo of a boy and girl drink.  Girl b/c it's fruity and sweet and cute, boy b/c it'll knock you on your a$$!   And the way they make it is so cool, with a blender, and somehow they know exactly how much liquor to pour in no matter how many people you're ordering for at once.  If I'm in a bad mood, one trip to Lipo and I've forgotten my troubles!!!
author: Ginger R.

description:
We truly got the full Chinatown experience when we strolled into Li Po Cocktail Lounge on a Saturday afternoon.  It was everything you expect from a dive bar with the addition of a Buddha shrine.  The bartender was welcoming and friendly and she mixed up an awesome Chinese Mai-Tai, which apparently used to be $7 (according to the other Yelp reviews) then $8, 9 and $10 for me.

They were playing traditional Chinese music when we first got there, then made the smooth transition to playing nothing but Janet Jackson, excellent!

It's a great place to hang out to escape the chaotic streets of Chinatown, the dark atmosphere makes you feel like you're about to have a rendezvous with the Chinese Mafia. 

+2 fans of Li Po lounge.
author: Chris-tal P.

description:
2 part review:

1) Came up to SF to this lounge from Long Beach just to go to the SF equivalent of our weekly monday nite funk session Funkmosphere at Carbon in Culver City. We arrived early to check out the bar. It looks amazing inside and the female bar tender was SO welcoming and let us know the haps around town. She made some drinks that knocked my boyfriend on his ass which was great since we were on vacation. 5 stars for the bar.

2) Sweater Funk- The bay area's sunday nite FUNK PARTAYYYY. Way awesome. All the selectors were great and kept me sweating all night. Everyone in this joint was having a great time. It is located in the basement of Li Po Lounge (another thing we don't have in Southern California..way rad!), I noticed that the moment people entered Sweater Funk, they were dancing! Sweater Funk is EVERY Sunday and I would really suggest going esp. since it is free!
author: Lauren B.

description: Typical Dive bar with rude servers.  We went after seeing Anthony Bourdain's visit and wanted to get away from the typical bar scene.  Asked to play Liars Dice 3 times before the aged bartender gave us the dice, he was straight up rude.  We asked for some general rules of the game and he gave us a death stare.  Finally after getting instructions off of our phones, a younger. pleasant woman/bartender helped us out a bit.  The game is pretty fun and the drinks are stiff which is always a good thing.  I won't be going back as the service was terrible.
author: Kyle B.

description:
Li Po is one of those special places (they tend to be bars) that make me trip out on urbanity.  There's this tuckedawayness, a feeling of submersion in the bowels of a civic monster that I'm psyched to have been swallowed by.

The bar looks like it's been burrowed rather than built, salvaged instead of designed.  The use of space says "This is the bone that the city gods threw us."  Cave-like walls, an awkwardly accessible downstairs, and a seating area with no light but that which reflects off the red plastic-upholstered booths.

But perhaps none of this would be all that impressive if not for Li Po's mai tais.  They're made with a Chinese rice whiskey that's somewhere over 80 proof, but you would never know it from the taste.  You know it, however, when you just have two of these things and you start getting excited about shit like civic monsters.
author: Daniel A.

description: Nothing like your neighborhood San Francisco Chinatown dive bar to get you through your first cold and rainy trek throughout the city. My wife and I vacationed in San Francisco together for the first time and we decided to explore the wonderful expanses of the city. We walked and trekked through neighborhood after neighborhood, explored many wonderful small business, and ate at some great establishments. We tirelessly walked up and down steep hill after steep hill, and we enjoyed a couple rides on San Francisco's various forms of public transportation. But all of this was done in the drenching San Francisco rain and chilly weather. Chinatown was one of the last spots on our self-guided tour of San Francisco and needless to say after a day of walking through the rain and in the cold we were a bit tired and feigning for a stiff drink and a place to rest our weary feet. We of course Yelped a place in the area and we found Li Po lounge. We read that not only had Anthony Bourdain visited Li Po Cocktail lounge but we also discovered that they were known to have great Mai Tai's. Score and Double Score! So we waltzed ourselves into Li Po and sat down at the end of the bar. We were greeted with a smile and a warm welcome by a young energetic bartender. Now there were only a few patrons in the bar at the time we went but the bartender was one of the nicest guys we met in San Francisco. He told of stories of his family, his time living in states, he talked sports, politics, religion, and pretty much whatever topic came to mind. So in the time it took us to enjoy one incredibly strong and legendary Mai Tai, we were graced with great conversation, and much needed rest. By the time we left we were dry, relaxed, and functionally intoxicated. So thanks you Li Po Cocktail Lounge for the great Mai Tai, great conversation, and the much needed rest from the relentless elements of San Francisco.
author: Wesley C.

description: I still like this place, but it has changed a bit since I first went in there many years ago . The whole Anthony Bourdain thing is a guarantee to raise prices. I have watched his show, but I still think he is a semi d*rk with that northeast attitude. No Californian, he.
author: Timothy C.

description:
This was stop number 8 for my friend's birthday bar crawl, at this point some people in the group started to drop out, some forfeited the hole, others had just to flat out retire for the evening...  Still Im glad most of us that remained decided to play through.  Walking in we were warmly greeted by what had to be one of the most friendly/chill bouncers that I've run into during my misadventures in the city. When we came in it wasn't to crazy inside, we were able to grab a couple seats at the bar and got settled into a couple of rounds.  

The man behind the bar set us up with the house's specialty drink, their Mai Tai.  The drinks came served to us in plastic cups, it didn't bother us that much, considering it's what was inside that counts.  The Mai Tais were pretty tasty, but be warned these concoctions are a creeper, before you know it, your mystical effects will catch up to you.  After a few drinks the night was coming to an end, so we closed our tab and made our move to the next bar.  Still considering the chill atmosphere, good drinks and friendly people are all the things I look for in a good dive bar.  Ill definitely be back.

Where we've been and we're were going on this birthday bar crawl...
http://www.yelp.com/list/lillians-birthday-crawl-san-francisco
author: Chris T.

description: OK, I came in here because of Bourdain.  I would keep coming back here because it's awesome.  Small, dark, dank hole in the wall with strong drinks and friendly people.  Mostly tourists, but everyone was having a good time, bartenders were very friendly.  Have a Mai Tai, there good and strong.  Drink some of the Chinese whiskey, it's stronger.  Buddha beers are great also, brought home the bottle for my souvenir =)
author: Steven H.

description:
I would have never known about this bar nor ventured into it to have a drink if it were not for a Solstice Chinatown Scavenger Hunt I was on.


 Li Po also known as Li Bai was a famous Chinese poet and we needed to find out how he died for the question.


 I love the gold paint and red decoration on the outside. The bar is fairly large on the inside. We sat at the bar but I saw that there are tables in the back for groups of people.


 My team and I had a few shots and mixed drinks. Good fortification to continue on the hunt and win.


 I would definitely go back and check out the downstairs.
author: Infodiva B.

description:
This place is my favorite to go to when I'm in the Chinatown area. I don't even drink anymore, but I take friends here who do because it's so much fun.

The Mai Tai's are superb and a great value. They float a little Chinese whiskey on top which is their "secret ingredient". They also have the usual bar video games and a music machine. There's a pretty decent sized flat screen that they usually play sports on.

Probably the thing that brings me back every time is the staff. There's the presumable owner who's a pretty old Chinese guy who's either doing something in some back room, or playing free games on the the machines. The bar is staffed with only Chinese women who can only be summed up by the word "cougars". They dress moderately provocative and will really be friendly in order to get a good tip. They're very funny and if you have a group all drinking and tipping they'll credit you some free songs on the machine.

All in all it's a really fun dive to hit whenever you're even remotely close to Chinatown. Plus it's great to hit right before or right after Kan's for some cheap dim sum.
author: Mike N.

description:
I love this place.  No frills and completely unpretentious.  The jukebox is full of old love songs and cheesy Chinese love songs.  No joke, last time I was in there I heard the Best of Air Supply in it's entirety.  Sweet.

When you walk in it feels like you're walking in to a tripped out 70's Chinese Disneyland.  The basement is kind of freaky and Pulp Fiction-esque, but if you ask me this just adds to the charm.  Drinks are also strong.  Get a Mai Tai; it's the best one you'll have in the city.  Apparently they have music in the basement on the weekends but I have yet to check it out.
author: Shawna S.

description:
Oh Li Po Lounge....
I love that you have that Chinese Shrine in your bar, makes me miss my grandma and going out once a year to pray for my grandparents. 
It's SO WEIRD I LOVE IT! 
The drinks come in this teensy cute cup. My mama always says, "it's not quantity, it's quality that matters" 
It's pretty strong and good!

I like that Li Po has this chill-vibe. You come, order a drink, and go to the back to sit on this restaurant booth with your friends and talk the night awayyyy. 
That was not the case with me though.
I went for Blood, Sweat and Queers, but came too late.. 
I saw one of the leaders for the volunteer teams for Soiree 8 there. HA! Bustedddd! LOL. 


naw. I'm just joking. it's cool. it's cool.
author: Miss C.

description: Thia place reminds me of a crummy bar you might find in Wan Chai in Hong Kong. Always fun to see who the hell is in this place, as the interior decor hasn't changed for years and years and years. Not much reason to stick around here for more than an hour or so, sadly...
author: Jim B.

description: Either $5 for TsingTao or $10 for this crazy Mai Tai (tasted like your typical jungle juice). Simple as that.
author: Oriana C.

description: Total dive with strong drinks and scary bathrooms. It was worth checking out but I won't be back.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
Presumably named for the famous Chinese poet, the Li Po could well typify what happened to Chinatown in the 70s. From the days when Chinatown bars and lounges catered to tourists seeking the "exotic" (we're talking around 1939), the Li Po features an artificial cave entrance and a decaying gate lantern (big!). 

That's where the show ends sadly, as Li Po becomes a dive bar. Cheap bar posters, overbearing jukebox, pinball machines, and curt service. 

So why am I so keen on the Li Po? 

Cheap drinks, of course, and the dark booths help, but it's that while you sip you can see the history of Chinatown as no other bar. From the glory days of tittering tourists, to the mass exodus of Chinese in the 60s and 70s, to the for-profit 80s, up until now, when hipsters come looking for magic in the dust. Whether it's a stop on your way to the Buddha or North Beach, the Li Po is a San Francisco experience worth every sip.

Trivia bit: There's a glimpse of this bar in the film "Lady From Shanghai," with Orson Wells
author: sketch f.

description: Li Po is an amazing dive bar.  So it's not a Smuggler's Cove or Trader Vic's mai tai, but it is a tasty rendition that will knock you on your ass with a little help from some Chinese whiskey.  They have so many kitschy things here, like torn paper lanterns and Ms. Pac-Man machine, that you'll just have to check it out yourself.  Bring cash!
author: Sally L.

description:
I'm sorry but I don't think there's a "right night" to go here. The awesome cave-like dance floor everyone's buzzin' about is everything but the dance floor. I know it's a dive bar but the tiny clear dixie cups, wow.

Ok, ok, it is in Chinatown.. but I don't think I should set my expectations reallllly low, right?
author: Jamie Q.

description: I'm ashamed to say I discovered this bar on "The Layover," but man did Bourdain get this one right or what?  I love this bar so much.  It's rarely ever crowded and the music and lighting is unobtrusive and sets a nice, chill mood.  The bartenders are attentive, friendly, and welcoming.  And the "Chinese Mai Tais" will get you F---ED UP, so much that you'll be rolling yourself home down Grant Street with a huge stupid grin on your face.  Love it, love it, love it.  I'm taking everyone here.
author: Matt Y.

description: The Chinese Mai Tais here were awesome! Very strong, but tasted like a fruity tropical drink - we thought it was the secret Chinese liquor that they put in at the end. We also tried the AMF and the purple rain, but they tasted too much like straight alcohol. In addition to the drinks the bartender at Li Po is very friendly and helpful. If you are in Chinatown and want some drinks, then this is my choice.
author: Julie C.

description:
I went to a friend of a friend's birthday party last night in the dungeon underground basement... which was super cool. They made it especially pretty with twinkle lights and streamers. The stairs are pretty treacherous, scary steep stairs. I suggest taking the first door on the right and going down those stairs if you're trying to get to the basement. 
The bar was descent, no beer on tap, mostly just miniature mixed drinks for $5 but they're tasty enough. 
The bathrooms are pretty gnarly, avoid them if possible.
I heard that the friend of the friend booked the basement for $80. They had a DJ, disco ball, fancy lights and seats for everyone. 
the staff are friendly and it seems like a cool place to "get away from it all" - away from the hype and routine of the North Beach scene. I really dug the decor and eeriness of it. 
Li Po reminded me of  that one time I was kidnapped and smuggled to China.
author: Mary Ella D.

description:
I came here tonight - the night of the Chinese New Year Parade. 

Everyone, EVERYONE (except the bartenders) were white. Any reason to party - they're here. Gotta love that.

This was a great stop on a little bar crawl - it was pretty dirty and crowded outside with kids and adults alike playing with the pop rock things in the street (I have a serious fear of those..) so Li Po was the perfect place to take refuge in.

The bartenders are nice - they make sure you are taken care of. The 2 bartenders tonight were busy. this place was packed with locals and tourists demanding only the best beer - TsingTao. (NOTE - I hate beer, but I did manage to gulp down half a bottle of TT..I mean, I couldn't order a cosmopolitan there -- it just wouldn't be right..)

Super dive bar, fun/mixed crowd - definitely a great spot in Chinatown.
author: Vanessa W.

description: I am not exaggeratin' when I say they have the best Mai Thai I have ever had. The customers and bartenders are always friendly and provide a welcoming atmosphere.
author: Ellexa B.

description:
Apparently I went on the "right night." I'm talkin friday the 17th, midnight till 2am. If the guy who was dropping beats downstairs comes around every week, you know I'll be there. Awesome jungle house and outrageous dancing, all performed from dual floppy disk decks.

Daniel's mai tai is all it is cracked up to be and then some. I really can't ask for more. I had a *fantastic* time.
author: Alex B.

description:
"A hidden gem in Chinatown."

This is where the bad guys from any Hawaii 5-0 episode hang out in between takes.  Miyagi-Wanna-Be in a pisspoor Hawaiian shirt tending the bar in between snorts of bad blow.  The jukebox is finally playing a set of songs that were selected some 19 years ago.  The shots of whisky are served in wine glasses and the television's remote control is a poolstick.  

Every night is ladies night.  They feel as welcome as a bunny caught in a bear trap.  The amphetamines they've been taking with their cold cans of beer make the boys look prettier and the broom closet seem like a delightful, romantic getaway compared to the usual makeout crapper sessions.  The john is downstairs.  Follow the smell of the aftermath of last year's chinese new year's parade and don't slip on the sweating steps.     

Smiles aren't to be trusted.  Watch the bartender's eyes.  He knows where the danger is...  He profits off of these people's ridiculous sense for dirty excitement.  Barbed laughs are never free.  Someone is paying for them.  

The yellow light paints the wall a dead avocado green in the welfare jail minds.  Gotta get out of this joint before I become one of them.  The ace on the beer list is flat anchor piss and the bar stool moans when I scoot it away from the counter during my escape attempt.

The girl at the end of the bar comes near smelling like alcoholic cigarette butts.  It's her birthday and she needs a pretty drink.  I like her style...  she can shake it like nobody's business.  Suddenly, I want the music to be louder and the drinks to be stronger.  I want big conversation!  The ugly people that were stinking up the joint are now the hip crowd.  I've never done speed before... but I don't think they'll notice.

"* * * * *"
author: Kenny R.

description: Li Po is so mysterious, in a totally accessible sort of way.
author: Esther G.

description:
I love getting drunk and playing dice. I am a midnight gal. I like to bet one dollar at a time because I am way too cheap to play some crazy $5 rounds. 

Too bad the clientele here play liars dice, and hide in the back cafeteria style tables drinking their cocktails out of the plastic cups they serve you your drinks in, and speak Cantonese and won't let you play with them even if you ask nicely, 

Go here with someone else who speaks Cantonese and you will find yourself drinking shots with the bartender that he bought for you just because you were with someone who speaks Cantonese.

Oh, and bring a flashlight because the dungeon like bathrooms in the basement are dark and you wont be able to find the toilet paper dispensers without one.
author: Drue C.

description:
Dear Li Po:

I'm sorry we snuck whiskey into your scary basement rental space during our Prop 2 party, but we really didn't have any choice, because you charge $4 for Bud Light.
