We really are good people. Good, poor people. Trying to raise money for a good cause. That's why your basement was chosen to hold the party in -- because it's cheap (and okay -- you'll always be our bar of choice in Chinatown, okay?). 

So, I understand why you had to throw Amir out and end our party, and I wish I could say we won't do it again, but... 

We probably will.

And just so you know -- the rats didn't scare us. Rats in Chinatown will always be far less shocking than $4 Bud Lights.
author: Lisa T.

description: I'm not sure what ancient artifacts were hanging from the ceiling in this strange bar, but I loved them.  But, they weren't nearly as impressive as the Mai Tais, made with special "chinese liquor".  I could have done without the $9 price...it's a little steep for Chinatown...even bud light was $4.50.  I went here on a Friday night at 9p, and the place wasn't too busy.  Perfect pre-drinking bar before I night out in North Beach due to (a) it's good location (b) mellow vibe and (c) Mai Tais that sneak up on you --- quickly
author: Joel F.

description:
I used to frequent Li Po a lot. No, not bar-fly frequently, but enough to know this place gets pretty rowdy and fun late into the evening and early into the morning. 

The place is a work of Asian kitsch art. The bartender is very nice in a "World of Suzie Wong" kind of way, down to the exaggerated accent and honey-sweet smile that hides the I'm-going-to-suck-the-dollar-bills-out-of-you-by-plying-you-with-super-strong-drinks-until-closing-time look rather well.

Our large group manned the red pleather booths in the back of the bar and we listened to Canto-pop and 70's garage rock over the PA. 

Interesting mix of local bar flies and tourists early in the evening. The magic starts working in this establishment AFTER the tourists go back to their hotels and restaurant reservations.
author: May T.

description:
This is a very cool dive bar.  Whenever I stay at the Ritz Carlton in San Francisco, I usually drop by here for a few drinks and hang out.  It has a very diverse crowd....... of all ages.  I think there is a live band that plays here on Fridays.  They have your usual dice, cards, and dominoes here.  Thank God they don't allow smoking here anymore.  

Came here last night with a few friends and it was good cheap fun.
author: jason g.

description:
Li Po was a poet and celebrated drunkard. According to legend he drowned trying to embrace the reflection of the moon in a lake. This sort of thing doesn't happen to non-drunkards.

So they named a bar after him. Lets do the math. 

The kitsch is worth at least one star off the bat. The semi functional neon sign, the red carpet and lighting, the cave like appearance will out-cheese the most ridiculous tiki bar, only it's generically chinese instead of generically island themed.

The bouncer is really nice and drinks are served quickly and with a smile. another star.

If you grew up in SF you probably heard all sorts of stories about how there are networks of tunnels underneath chinatown where contraband was transported and bought and sold back in the day. There is such a tunnel here: down the back stairs, past the restrooms, left, and right again, you'll find a large room that sort of resembles your grandparents' basement. One more star for keeping childhood legends alive.

But minus one star for the unreasonably high drink prices; I'd expect to pay 4.50 for a bottle of beer at a place like Harlot, but not at a seedy chinatown dive, and if I'm paying that much for a vodka soda, I'd generally expect to get in in a glass made of glass. Reserving your grandparents' basement for a private event is dirt cheap, though.

And minus another star for the bartender singling out a member of our party and completely overreacting. Granted, we probably shouldn't have done what we done, but the outburst was uncalled for.

And plus one star for each giant rat that ran by outside.
author: matthew r.

description: Definitely yummy Mai Tai specials!!!  But be careful...they'll hit you later! Don't be discouraged by the dive bar that it is. It's worth the visit. Everybody's friendly! Can't wait to come back!!!
author: Michelle T.

description:
Cheesball madness.
White chicks on bad speed.
Air Supply looms under your breath.
Photobooth storage locker.
vampires not welcome - 
help cause I'm lost in love and i'm sooo lost without u!"
author: Sasha P.

description: Cheap and trashy :) It looks like a place where prostitute from "Full Metal Jacket" would have a drink after hard work day.
author: Vladimir P.

description: Exactly what I was looking for yesterday afternoon while shopping in Chinatown.  A friendly bartender served me a cold beer at a relaxed bar top.  I'll go back next time I am in the area.
author: Maxwell M.

description: My favorite dive bar in San Francisco. Affordable, Friendly and over the top in a way that is lacking in East coast Chinatown bars. Jackie is a hospitable and kind bar tender who will give you the ins and outs of where to eat and what to do in San Frncisco. Try the Mai Tais :)
author: Mo A.

description:
Excellent bar to just hang out or to see live bands in the basement. It's a lot like being in someone's garage down there, hot and sweaty with no ventilation. However, they seem to get fun bands that make you want to shake your ass, so it's worth it!
If you just chill upstairs with the locals it's fun too, the bar staff are nice and know now to pour with a heavy hand. Cozy red leather booths in the back make for a conversation friendly environment.
Don't forget to toss a dollar in the jukebox, which is half 80s and disco and half stuff written in Chinese that looks like pop and/or sappy love songs.
author: Colleen B.

description:
I will argue that Li Po may feature the worst bathrooms in San Francisco.  However, I do not care.  This place is crazy fun if you go on the right night.  If you go on the wrong night, it is what you make of it.  The right night is when they have the basement opened up with a DJ.  The wrong night is hanging out with a few old people who do not speak English upstairs while they play tiles or dice games...whatever.

The place isn't very big.  They have a few booths in the back of the upstairs and some seats at the bar.  That is pretty much it.  When the downstairs is open, it adds some space, but the ceiling is low and the place feels claustrophobic.  This would normally bother me, but not when they have a cool show taking place like Lazersword!

The last time I went, the bartender thought I was a promoter.  She kept insisting that I have free drinks.  My friends were cracking up.  I tried to pay, honestly.  I look forward to my next visit...maybe they will let me serve some drinks.

I have heard stories about the basement and a secret passage that leads into the underground city that lives beneath Chinatown.  Apparently, this is where you would find opium dens and a tunnel to the Bay where they pushed the dead bodies back in the day.  Fact or fiction?  Who knows.  Go check it out.  Cash only.
author: Ryan W.

description:
This place smells like an armpit.

The most enjoyable part of my evening was drinking my Sparks out front before stepping foot in this sweat gland.

Also, be wary of douche bags posing as doormen trying to taking your money.  

What do you take me for a FOOL?!?!?!? 

I don't think so.
author: Catrinel A.

description:
Make sure you get the Mai Tai when you come to the Li-Po. They put a small drop of something mysterious in them from this dusty bottle they keep on a back shelf. I don't know what it's called, but the bottle is shaped like a gourd, or maybe it's a dried human stomach. Possibly poisonous, but delicious. 

Cons: Until you get used to it, the slamming dice sound makes you hit the ceiling every time. And the only way to get used to it is to get drunk/poisoned off human stomach Mai Tais.
author: Tim S.

description: You'd never expect anything below the surface of this bar in Chinatown. At first glance, a divey cocktail lounge, but every Thursday night, downstairs in the basement and past the bathrooms, there are live music shows. Colored lights and fake vines on the wall contrast sharply to the vinyl booths and bright lights upstairs. A veritable basement venue, the music here is literally and figuratively underground. Small indie/experimental/avant garde bands play for coffee money covers. An unexpected creative space.
author: Netty L.

description:
Wow, I know I was here because I was on the pub crawl, I have a vague memory of the dungeon bathroom and strange people around, and the jukebox that you couldn't hear, but I honestly I couldn't find my way back here... I know I had a tasty beer here. 

Thank you DYL!
author: Jessica R.

description: I've been coming to Li Po's since the late 80's. My friend Terrence introduced me to the place (his Dad use to gamble downstairs in the '40's while the prostitutes hung out in the balcony). I've introduced many folks to this place and it seems it still is the "hipsters" hang out in the evenings (don't be put out by that cause it's a gem on Grant).
author: Googie G.

description:
I half expected Jack Nicholson to bust in here in a white suit and hat. Stay out of Chinatown, Jake.

I'll have to admit that I was a bit incoherent (see also, intoxicated) at my visit here, so I may not be terribly accurate in my feeling this place has an air of film noir meets swingers while carrying the 1970s Kung Fu mystique (not quite classy, not quite trashy, but advertismetn themed Chinese decorum.) This is not to put against Li Po, and the booths in the back maek for a good area to carry a convesation. If you can get the darkened, secluded booth in the back it may make for more than good conversation if you bring someone.... friendly.

Selection of beer is minimal, the drinks aren't mixed the best, and prices are a litle on the high side. Not something I'd make one of my regular haunts, but good for a change of pace.... so long as I can get the back booth again.
author: Keith M.

description:
Sometimes the downtown happy hour scene can be a bit tedious. Taking a walk through Chinatown to the Li Po is a great way to break the routine. 
Order a whiskey and take in the decor.  Check out that crazy jukebox selection.   The booths in the back are perfect for that secret office romance, or meeting fellow master minds to plot and take over the world (one shot at a time).
author: Lisa R.

description:
One of the best dive bars in Chinatown. The bartenders are surly, the bathrooms are scary and you can bring in food from outside restaurants and nosh away while you sip on a way too stiff drink. 

We logged in quite a bit of time at Li Po after the Chinese New Year Parade this past weekend. We took over two booths and had a great time. By the time we stumbled out, the place was packed.

Be warned, like many dive bars, they are a cash only establishment.
author: Lee H.

description:
Interesting place. Me and the band did a show here awhile back, and the accoustics definitely weren't that bad. Their sound system leaves alot to be desired though. "But Rich, if the sound system sucks, why are the accoustics not bad?" Well person reading my reviews, its because that place is like your grandma's basement. Dank and dark. The stage is definitely small to rock a crowd. But I will say this, it doesn't look pretty, but the vibe is great. The small space allowed us to interact with the folks there. Since the accoustics were so great (small basement type settings will do that for you), our sound just bounced around all over. 

Upstairs wasn't much to look at. Its a small bar with regulars. I could've sworn I heard some "Norm!" cheers. 

PS.
Parking is a b1tch. Good luck with that.
author: Ritchie L.

description:
As a dive, Li Po has an interesting mix of regulars and hipsters that make up a relaxed vibe. I actually wouldn't have known it was down this street in Chinatown if I wasn't told. We went on a sunday night for their sweater funk party, which is held below the bar. Very "garage party" feelin', but I'm into subculture so I liked it. The dj was awesome and played great funk beats that my friends and I have never heard before.

What else can I say? At an average of $6 the drinks are reasonably priced. Jackie, one of the bartenders was super cute and chatted it up with us while we were there. She seemed so positive and really friendly, which was cool for me as a newcomer to the place.

Perfect for groups, and on a more low key night for a date.
author: Geralyn Y.

description:
The drinks were strong, poured liberally and Vanessa the weekend bartender is the BEST!  

If you're in China Town, this is the best spot to pop in for a mid afternoon drink.
author: Sunny D.

description: Friend and I were talking around Chinatown, saw this intriguing bar, and decided to start the night really early. Got to talk to all kinds of interesting people, strong drinks and good experience overall.
author: Lonny Y.

description:
This is everything I love about a bar:  a lovable hole in the wall with cheap drinks and great atmosphere.

Before you go to this bar, I recommend watching the San Francisco episode of The Layover with Anthony Bourdain which features this bar.  Then you will know exactly what you are getting into.
author: Matthew D.

description:
Maybe it's the red booths or the red walls or the feeling that you're in downtown Shanghai. I really don't know, but there is something totally lovable about this bar. 

It's a lot bigger than you realize upon first entry. I immediately felt a little claustrophobic until I got to the back of the bar & saw that there was another spacious & nearly empty wing complete with booths just waiting for us to sit in. I sat around with three buddies for awhile (guys night, woo!), & then four girl friends of one of them (girl's night out, woo!) met up with us. The sexes collided in a whole mess of whiskey & tsing tao. After awhile I got up to use the restroom, only to find ANOTHER undiscovered cove -- a system of underground caverns, if you will, anxiously waiting for explorers to...spelunk them. Too much? Yeah, sorry. 

Anyway, apparently there had been a band playing earlier in the night, & there was an unsupervised drum kit just sitting there. Begging to be played. I tried to resist, but I just couldn't. I really had to demonstrate that I knew how to play the intro to "So Fresh, So Clean" by OutKast. Annd then the band showed up.

"Get up, dude. Not cool."
"Ehhh, sorry man! You guys were great, by the way. Do you have any CDs for sale?"
"Get up..."
"Okaybye..."

I made a fast exit back to our crew, who were preparing to leave as well, so it all worked out.

Thanks Li Po, I had me a real good time. The Communist PARTY, indeed.
author: Pete J.

description: After getting off a bus which included a man claiming to be the Jesus and a man getting into a fight, a beer is what I needed.  When choosing to go right or left the choice was easily made.  The front of this bar is amazing, you cannot miss it.  The bartender was wonderful and even gave us recommendations of a good place for peking duck and directions to our dinner reservations.  I would live there if I could.  What's not to like a bar with a shrine and gong?
author: Megan P.

description:
Pretty small bar, but cozy and friendly~
Winnie and Jackie are awesome and great bartenders!
A nice break from the busy sidewalks in Chinatown.
author: May L.

description: Two words Mai Tai's!!!!!!  Prices are steep at $9 a piece, but a buzz is guaranteed here.   Get some!!
author: Douglas D.

description:
i was first lured to Li Po by the story of a "secret" opium-derived drink that sent my friends to cuckoosville after consumption. one friend woke up the next morning in Washington Square with a chess board on his chest and the other one found himself half-naked on the floor of a friend's flat.

when i finally tried the drink, it tasted like guzzoline - the most horrendous thing i ever drank - but i remember feeling a bit strange afterward, a little loose in the limbs. i'm not sure if i can attribute that to the several rounds of drinks beforehand or to the drink itself. i felt pretty happy either way. in the end, my buddies probably made up the story (they're quite the raconteurs) to see the face i made after throwing down that nasty-ass drink. but then again, they drank it too...

if you're into the dive thing, this is the place.
author: Art O.

description: What a cozy and friendly little place!  I was happy just to find a parking spot but it was a nice, clean place with a TV with sports and great drink options and specials.
author: Jack L.

description: I went there with my parents for a drink before dinner in Chinatown and the adorable bartender girl was so friendly and made me a strong special mai tai. Loves it!   It's a great kitschy dive feel, and the locals are friendly.
author: Mark S.

description:
The booth in the middle of Li Po, the one in its own little room? If I were putting a hit out on someone, that's where I'd do it. 

A great place, even if they have done the impossible in figuring a way to water down a Miller Light. Further, I mean. Weak drinks and rude treatment in this charming hole are a time honored tradition here, and are considered part of the ambience.

And that Good Fellas booth? While I've never hired a trigger man in it, a really hot girl I did make out with me in that self-same booth. We had just come from seeing Y Tu Mama Tambien, so it really did seem like the thing to do in that moment. And you have a bit of respectability making out with someone in this booth. I mean it's still a PDA, and thus lame to all who are in effect riding shotgun to your necking, but only to the people at the bar. To everyone else in the place, you could be doing something repectable in there. Like planning a murder.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
Visiting with a group of San Diegans - decided to take a shot at every bar on the way from Little Italy to our hotel at Union Square.  Randomly went into this one.  Despite my foggy memory, I do remember we got waved in from across the street by some chick who seemed very friendly, that it was in Chinatown, that the decor was dive-y Chinese, it wasn't cheap, that were a lot of younger "urban-looking" white people, and there was hip hop playing.  

We took our Jamesons shots and moved on... we ran into no bars after that.  Just ended at the Urban Tavern @ the Hilton where my friends were staying...
author: Suz K.

description:
The bathroom says a lot about a place and this one was screaming at me, YUK!  The disco music playing "Night Fever" was strange but the patrons seemed to enjoy it, heck they probably played it and a bar seemed like a strange place to see a Buddha alter but why not.
This was recommended on a TV Show, I just didn't get it
author: Dianne M.

description: I'd heard such great things about Li Po Cocktail Lounge that I dragged some friends there to give it a try. We did not last long at all though as we were not impressed. I usually love dive bars but this one felt a bit dirty/dingy to me. We were there on a Friday night and the bar was almost empty. They were cash only also which was a bit annoying. The highlights were playing one game of PacMan and quickly moving on to another, more exciting bar...
author: Meghan P.

description:
***Half-Assed Limerick***

It's a Cool Dive
It's Very Kitschy
It's Drinks Are a Little Pricey

It Has Tables in Back
It Has a Basement for Bands
It Has a Cougar for a Bartender, Spicy!

Thank You.

4 stars cause I like dives, but minus a little cause the bathrooms are small and weird (even for most dives).
author: Garrett C.

description: Pretty standard dive bar. Generous pours with bartenders spewing witty banter.
author: Roger H.

description:
I arrived at Li Po on a blustery night for a birthday party/punk rock show.  The show was played in the basement, which was really creepy & fantastic.  I made my way up the stairs many, many times to get dee-licious drinkies.  Of course, I was wasted pronto.

I ended up making a whole batch of new "friends" & had a rip roaring good time.

The night ended badly, however.  It seems the management had pretty much had enough of s, so we were unceremoniously tossed out on our respective ears.  Problem with this was:

a) rainy night=no cabs
b) we realized lots of the bad equipment was still inside.

Our friend Hal (whose birthday was being celebrated) walked back into the bar.  Apparently, the door was lightly latched & he unwittingly broke it off.  This didn't please the owner because he started screaming at us to "Get fuck out".

Good times.
author: Charlene E.

description:
The More You Know About Li-Po (tm):

This is the very bar where sci-fi author Philip K. Dick sat down to write "Do Androids Dream of Electronic Sheep?"*




*This might be a lie
author: Patrick K.

description:
I've only ever been there to go to the downstairs room.

Oh. my. god. You hear people talk about "underground" bands - well, what's more underground than actually being underground? The stairs are at the back of the bar. Go down the stairs and past the furnace (!) to bare concrete room. Cliche as it sounds, it's very rock and roll.
author: Natalia M.

description:
Wow, what a fun place! The two enormous red booths in the back are quiet because they're way in back, and are huge, roomy and unlike any place else in the city.

The songs on the jukebox are not matched with their numbers, but oh well, and I suspect San Quentin has nicer bathrooms.  

The elderly Asian bartender makes a mean Mai Tai and runs the entire place single-handedly.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Oh, man, are you kidding me?  This place is another San Francisco classic... anything less than five stars is sacrilege!  Be thankful that you stumbled by accident upon one of the legendary watering holes deep in Chinatown.  

Best viewed with a heavy buzz.
author: H.A. ..

description:
the dirtiest basement in san francisco.  small shows and when the moon is low dancing until sleep.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hGU6fFWSM5c
author: Noel J.

description:
When you enter Li Po Lounge, you can't help but feel like you're in some sort of a David Lynch movie. It's dark, cavernous, and totally bizarre. Which is why I LOVE it.

My boyfriend and I spent an entire afternoon drinking and playing the adult photo match game. Such a lovely way to spend a Saturday...
author: Brianne K.

description:
I've been to quite a few good shows here, otherwise, I probably wouldn't frequent the place. Mixed drinks come in a kiddie cup, but are adult priced. The upstairs consists of the usual bar and stools, some yart drunk video gambler games, and then some awkward booth setup in the back. Tiny entry way gets pretty clogged as the night goes on. The real magic begins downstairs in a basement straight from some midwest college town kegger. It's dank small and smelly once the people start pouring in. There's a back stairwell that allows for easy escaping if the band is terrible. 

Cross the street, and you can schlurp on some bubble tea.
author: Brittany L.

description:
I have limited experience in going out in this general area but I like this bar.

I'd call it pretty close to a legitimate dive.  The bar area kinda feels like you're in someone's living room.  If you happen to venture down into the spooky basement area, it definitely feels like your uncle's creepy basement.  There's usually dancing and couches down there although it can get hotter than a camel's nutsack and the ceilings get low in a few places.

Probably the clincher for me was the excellent service.  Despite the fact that the bar was about a layer deep with people, the bartender was consistently right there to get me another drink when I came up to the bar.  I know a bartender always likes to chat with a regular or wash glasses but it's nice to have someone ready and anxious to get you another drink, especially on a busy Friday night.  The language barrier made it a little awkward at one point since I thought I was getting charged $13.50 (which actually was $20.50) but hey this bar was a good time.

Oh yeah, and if you complain about a dive bar not taking credit cards, you clearly don't go to enough dive bars...
author: Steven R.

description: Friday night visit.  Red and gold and shiny chinese kitsch on the walls.  $6 punk show cranking from the basement, 80's hair music upstairs.  Had to shove through 3 layers of leather jackets, neon makeup and t-shirts for bands like "Lyin' bitch and the restraining orders."  Got a big smile with my Tsingtao from the bartender lady.  My friend said the red vinyl booths and diseased carpet reminded her of a roller rink.  Great place for conversations about dumpster diving.
author: Pat L.

description:
I drank the secret Chinese liquor and I feel like I'm a better person because of it.  

I also feel confident that this is a pretty legit place to hang out.  The barkeep is friendly enough and the decor is everything you'd want it to be.  I don't know why you'd want to chill out in the red booths when you could bask in Buddha's glory.  I honestly don't know.
author: steve m.

description: I came in here with some friends looking for a beer after a major walk around the city that included lots of the typical tourist spots. It was around 7pm on a Monday and we were the only ones there. The bartender was so incredibly nice! She gave us a tour of the place, hooked up free credits on the jukebox, took photos with us and even let us try some of the Chinese Liqueur that goes into their world famous Mai Tais. Speaking of the Mai Tais, if I had a running list of the best drinks I've ever had, this would rank somewhere near the very top. At $9 it seems expensive at first, but with all the booze in this thing its really worth it. Plus they are insanely DELICIOUS!  We drank 3 a piece and had a pretty amazing night afterwords.
author: Eddie S.

description: A-one, perfect dive bar.  So happy to find such a joint while wandering through Chinatown on a visit.  The bartender, originally from Hong Kong, was a delight and provided good insider info on restaurants and other points of interest in the vicinity.  The jukebox is, um, eclectic, and the bathrooms are terrifying - just as you might expect.  A large Buddha overseeing the bar is a nice touch.
author: Kent K.

description:
As soon as I saw this place from across the street, I knew I would be setting foot in that mysterious cave. 

Turns out, there's beer and basketball on tv. And a rice cooker behind the bar. Mystery solved!
author: Kimberly C.

description: I consider this place, to date, the most dive-barriest dive bar I've been to in SF.  With the old tattered china-town decor it feels like a throwback to what you'd find in old faded Chinese speak-easy-style cigarette advert posters from a century ago.  Kind of neat.
author: Mike S.

description:
Dance party/live music in the basement?  Totally awesome, hot, sweaty, cross- cultural mindfuck of fun!

No dance party in the basement but drinks in the evening in Chinatown in a nearly empty bar? Kinda Weird Vibes.
author: Ben V.

description:
Not sure what got me started, but I really wanted to do a pub crawl through Chinatown.  Surprisingly, there wasn't much convincing on my part.  We were all in!

1st stop, Li Po.  

And this place definitely didn't disappoint.  As we expected, they had the necessary divey red decor, cheap, but strong drinks and a surprisingly friendly bartender.  Too bad, she only spoke Cantonese.  I was ready to practice my Americanized Mandarin on her. 

Instead, we decided on our possible options for entertainment.  And it looked like there were a few. 

OPTION A: Play liars dice with the old, grouchy Chinese dudes in the corner.

OPTION B: Take the Chinatown dungeon tour of the bathrooms and some other hidden rooms.

OPTION C: Play photo hunt. 

OPTION D: See what was behind the noisy red door.

After some discussion, none of us appeared to be in for an adventure, so we opted for OPTION C or as my friend calls it the Lady to Lady game.   And thank god she picked the ladies cuz I wasn't going to be spending all night figuring out which dude on the right looked different from the left.
author: James C.

description: Went here last night, had a great time, wonderful people, very attractive ladies. Drinks are a little hard to get since its packed but worth the wait. Definitely my kind of place.
author: Jey P.

description: be careful with the amazing mai tais or you'll not remember you went here the night before.
author: Courtney H.

description: Great place to people watch and hang out with the hipsters.  We had a gin martini served in a plastic cup.  We sat on an old red vinyl booth and enjoyed the scenery.  Great dive bar.  Cool place
author: Alexander B.

description:
I have been to worse bars in SF, but god damn I can't remember when. This place looks like the biggest dive in the world, yet somehow they can charge 5 bucks for fucking tsingtao without doubling over in laughter. If you want to economize, you can get a Bud for 4.50 and sit at the bar near the trashcans. 
There's a dank basement where they have shows, and thats the only reason I won't give this place negative stars.
author: Travis H.

description: When I first arrived, I noticed there were lots of people outside.  It wasn't a line and the bar wasn't too packed.  I didn't know why.  Then I saw the basement.  Its a dance club for those who do not want to dress up.  The whole dive bar feel continues down to the basement where its dank and hot and people are dancing.  Minus points for the prices of booze in this cash only bar, they would be reasonable if they took credit cards.
author: Joel M.

description:
So, it ain't dirty cheap, but too few places are.  The best bang for your buck is going to be the mai tais and not the beer.  

I think its better when its pretty empty.

Atmosphere is seedy without being dangerous or sketchy.

I like to drop mai tais and play dice on the bar here.  I think that's because sucking down mai tais and playing dice at a seedy bar is kind of what I think Chinatown is all about.
author: Matt R.

description:
This is a joint that I always wanted to go into but never really did until recently.  It looks like a secret cave den that only special members can get into but then it's magically another dive bar in Chinatown.

The bartender looks like someone my dad would hang out with at a coffee shop and speak real loud Chinese with.  

Overall, the place looks like it was designed in the 70s with whatever Asian motif that was popular at the time.  It has it's little charm and there are a few booths in the back.  Not the sexiest joint but at least I can say I went there and enjoyed myself.
author: Jason Y.

description:
Too many mai-tai's with that strange secret ingredient, and the stench of firecracker smoke wafting in through the door on Chinese New Year parade night damn near killed me.  

Ah, the perfect Chinatown dive.
author: Chrissy S.

description:
Wow, I had no idea the entrance to Li Po was so decorative! Hell I sat next to one of the statues next to the door and never even really looked at them. I am however intimately familiar with the inside, from the nice big bar, to the cozy booths in the back room, to the downstairs dungeon where the music was, which reminded me very much of the cave rave scene in The Matrix Reloaded.

Anyway, the bartenders were very efficient and generous in their distribution of alcohol. The bouncer at the door knew me by sight and waved me in while most people had to have stamps checked. Guess I went in and out a bit much, but god was it hot downstairs! Li Po is definitely a great dive bar with its own unique vibe, and a welcome respite from bars in other parts of the city. Should you ever be looking for entertainment I suggest starting out in the Marina and ending up here.
author: Will A.

description: It's like going to frat parties all over again.  I was pleasantly surprised that I didn't have to trek through 2 inches of jungle juice in the downstairs basement.  Oh that was a dance floor?  You guys are so silly, confusing a little girl like me.  I also thought trading in the red cups for clear little dixie cups was pretty classy.  If anyone wanted to roofie me I would definitely have seen the reaction occurring right before my drunken little eyes.  Frat parties are movin on up!
author: Justine D.

description: What a lovely little dive bar to escape the mid-afternoon commotion of Chinatown. While Li Po is famous for its mai tai, at $9 a pop, it's a wee bit expensive.
author: Chris L.

description:
I really honestly thought that at some point I'd been in here before...but once inside, I didn't recognize it at all.  But I'm sure...  Maybe I was drunk?

We were here around 2pm on a Saturday.  The bartender was super nice and friendly.  She did a good job of selling us the special mai tai.  It was sweet and sour and very refreshing.  The hubban' had two!  I might need a bottle of the secret ingredient. The bartender said it was a kind of rose wine..? 

Anyway, its a little dusty and divey and, like most things in Chinatown, there is a constant flow of tourists but I really enjoyed my drink and the mellow vibe...and quietly singing along with the bartender when Karma Chamelion came on the jukebox.
author: Miss Information X.

description:
Probably my new favorite dive bar in the city.  We went there a couple weeks ago for my buddy's Bday, hearing that they have the best Mai Tais in the City.  The bartender there, Daniel, is just HILARIOUS.  He looks like my uncle in a trucker hat, and I'm pretty sure he was hammered when we strolled in.  He gave my friend a free shot of patron for his birthday, and when asked about the Mai Tais he claimed he invented that drink 15 years ago in that very bar.  We ordered a round and he basically threw a mixture of like 5 or 6 liquors into that blender, including 151 and some chinese liquor in a ceramic jug that looked like it had to be some kind of home-brewed moonshine.  plus pineapple juice.  Sure enough that was a delicious--and incredibly strong--little blended cocktail.  I don't think I had ever had a mai tai before that so I can't say if it was the best in the City, but I definitely was satisfied.  Daniel also came over and hung out with us for a while since we were the only people in the bar for like an hour.  

Oh yeah, and the playlist at the bar was nothing but the hits from the 90's, including a selection of Color Me Badd, Salt n Pepa, and of course who can forget Bel Biv Devoe.  Chinatown bar hopping is just comedy.
author: William S.

description:
from the outside, this place is pretty terrifying. i've walked by on numerous occasions while on the search for some secret somethings i get in china town (i'll never tell) and have vowed never to enter. it looks like hell. it really does. but it's not that bad. 

i, for one, stuck to bottled beer, because i refuse to drink vodka from a plastic cup; i'm too classy for that. the bouncer was really nice, and while the basement smelled riper than a banana in December in Brazil, the band down there was pretty decent. my perspective on this place is probably skewed, however, as i came for a birthday party so everyone there was either a friend or a friend of a friend and i think it's safe to say that it's pretty obvious that i roll with cool people.
author: Rachael S.

description:
I love dive bars and this one holds a special place in my heart. Ah, the memories!  You can rent out the basement here for special events. I was able to book it less than 2 weeks before the event date and Jackie was very helpful.  We held my birthday party here in the basement where the owner/bartenders allowed us to set up DJ equipment and have our own private dance party! Those special Mai Tais are dangerous, but they sure are tasty going down. 

The birthday dance was such a hit that my DJ friends are having another one this month just for fun, open to anyone: Sat, 9/22/07 9pm - close. ($3 cover after 10) If you like to dance at dive bars, come join us: http://www.sfstation.com/noname-dance-party-e104341
author: Jodi W.

description:
surprisingly fabulous Chinatown dive bar. 

It's not the dive with red lights, casino carpet and motley crew on the jukebox. The lights are a little brighter, but it has a long cool bar with lots of red vinyl booths in back, great for groups. It's a sf dive bar with an 'chung king express' twist 

they tolerated our debauchery and kept the drinks coming. cool find.
author: Beth M.

description:
My brother was hosting a band and art event downstairs of this place. We happen to be in town last Friday so we could go. It was tons of fun. We got there a little early, and saw people still setting up the stage and putting up art work. So we went back upstairs and watched the end of the Giants/Cards game on the bar TV. It was a cool L shaped bar and the upstairs had a few booths just past the bar area. The door man was really cool, he knew who we were after a while. Don't try and bring any outside food or drinks in...he will catch you. Once the bands started playing there were tons of people downstairs. If you have been drinking and trying to go down the stairs ...hold on to the railings....its a steep set of stairs and I almost fell like 3 times. All 3 bands were cool and I even met someone who did some of the paintings, and I got him to paint me something for my new baby boy Davis. Once he is done he will mail it to us...well my brother will...he is friends with my brother who lives there in SF. The place was easy to find and the bartenders were both really nice and when it got close to 11pm, every time I went up to the bar and stood in line, the woman who was bartending had my drinks ready for me by the time I got to the front of the line. She was really busy and she still remembered what we were drinking. I left her quite a big tip. When we come back in town and if my brother hosts another party ...we will be there. We had a great time.

MZ
author: Mike Z.

description: Not the best place to go for hip hop clubbing music.  The underground dance floor is more of like the basement of a really bad frat party and was super sketch.  Cover probably depends on who is DJ-ing for the night, but it was $12 when I went.  Worst $12 I've ever spent.  The overall quality of the place was definitely sub par.  Never coming back.
author: Ben T.

description: Check out Sweater Funk on Sunday nights where the cool kids party to rare disco in the sweltering basement of this Chinatown dive. Tsing Tao, lanterns, no cover.
author: chris o.

description: Went for a friend's birthday... Perfect weirdly divey hang out in the heart of china town.  The Mai Tai's were unbelievably strong. Had a great, fun time.
author: Best M.

description:
Was walking through C-town on my way to north beach and stopped by this place as it just looked really out of place - small place crammed with random stuff, single long bar on curve, a few old guys yelling at each other in Cantonese.  Reminds me of some of the dive bars in HK except this place was cleaner.  And didn't stink.

Friendly bartender - at least the girl was, the guy was aloof and I basically felt he was trying to stare me down.  She recommended the Mai Tai so I tried one and got it dive bar style - in a little plastic cup.  Kinda expensive for the size.   They added some sort of Chinese liquor to it (forget the name now) that increased the sweetness of the drink.
author: Dave L.

description: As a dive bar this ranks as one of the best. You've got dim lights, stained carpets, ancient paint and wallpaper, a really smelly bathroom, a giant Buddha in the corner, a cave-like entrance, and Vanessa, a great bartender. I loved the way the shot prices are marked on each bottle with a Sharpie marker. You have to try the "Chinese Whiskey" in the ball shaped ceramic bottle. Overall a very cool and interesting dive bar.
author: Brian F.

description: Best place in Chinatown! Awesome little dive bar with lots of character, great music, and great service!  Doesn't even feel like you're in the hustle and bustle of Chinatown.  I would come back everytime I visited!
author: Courtney T.

description: The basement music venue is probably violating all the fire codes, but it's fun. Kind of like a high school party in somebody's parents' basement. I think pretty much anybody can play there, you just have to put your band on a list or something. Skeevy Chinese guys, uncomfortable looking yuppie girls, and a surprising number of middle aged ex-Cal student-looking types. Bottled beer is the way to go here.
author: Megan W.

description: Not just a dive bar. A dirty Chinese dive bar. Chinese as in fortune cookie Chinese. Crammed packed with an embarrassment of riches in Chinese kitschy clutter, the place looks like the remains of a movie set that has been allowed to age for decades. The dingy carpets probably still have opium residue from the time it was an opium den, and you may feel like taking a shower if you spend too much time inside. As the night wears on, the white devils get more and more wasted, a few passed out in the back booths. I can say that there is no experience like Li Po's.
author: Boris C.

description: Hands down the saddest bathroom I have seen in a bar. And yet, I found it strangely attractive, because I knew immediately this place isn't pissing around-you are here to drink and that's about it. No pretentious douches with oil slicked hair, no meatheads looking for your number, no eyeliner wearing boys wearing tees featuring a ribcage and heart trapped inside. Can you tell I have a problem with people? Ermm, maybe this is why I drink in the first place. But either way, it's nice to know one place where I can do so while indulging in the anonymity I do so cherish.
author: Ayelet I.

description: I swear this place used to be an opium den back in the day. Tucked away in the middle of Chinatown's dim sum restaurants and kitschy souvenir stores, this bar looks like it belongs in some 1970s movie. Then again, I've always been a fan of red vinyl booths in the back and a juke box that plays random bands like The Moody Blues. But what makes this dive so effin' cool is the downstairs basement which makes for a great last minute dance floor and place for two turntables and a microphone.
author: Ivy M.

description:
a quiet wednesday night spent by the counter with some friends after a meeting, a warriors' game on the big screen tv and a prince song from the jukebox in the background.

"could i get a glass of water?" asked a friend. 

"I'll pour your some sprite," said the bartender. 

"could we get some lime with the tequila?"  asked a friend. 

"I'll cut you a fresh one," said the bartender.

a quiet moment passed with no demands from us. 

"here, this round's on me," said the bartender and poured us all tequila.
author: Andrew P.

description: Another dive bar in Chinatown, still no draft beer. How can an establishment be considered a dive bar without something nasty on tap like Blatz or Pabst?!?! But at least they're open on Sunday, and they had a fun little ol' dance party going on downstairs in the concrete bunker/basement that kept me occupied until the small hours of Monday morning.
author: Hugh R.

description: Old chinese men, hipsters, and a dark, dank cellar which doubles as a micro-music venue. Another charming place place to see SF fringe, experimental, basically LOUD music. Enter through the back stairs (grab the free earplugs if they have 'em), climb over the band/stage and move towards the back to avoid the mosh pit action. Keep your mouth shut and head tipped down in case it gets steamy and the ceiling starts to drip. Hot tip: there's another stairway way out at the back of the room that leads straight up to the bar door.
author: Sirima S.

description: They have Penthouse erotic photo hunt, nice old asian dudes who join in at 1 a.m. to help you touch boobies and the bartenders are nice.
author: Christina S.

description:
came here last night. full of hip hop and hipsters. it was a good time. the downstairs is like a sauna so id suggest u stand by the fan. haha!
drinks are cheap and owners all speak english and chinese so theres no language barrier. i like the decor because of its authenticity and i love how i can walk outside to smoke a cig and i see the historic chinatown. this place is friendly, the DJ last night was absolutely AMAZING. all underground mash ups. it was dope.
author: Glen L.

description:
meant  to write about this place a long time ago, so when someone mentioned it over the weekend, i got all nostalgic ...

a friend and i went here after some real emotional roller coasters at work and were, i suppose, looking for a place to slink down and melt into our mai tais.  and, boy, did we ever.  everything in the other reviews of li po is pretty accurate, but what they didn't mention was just how strong those mai tais are.  jesus lord.  i am usually beyond liberal when it comes to drinking, so it's pretty safe to say i have a higher tolerance than most , and so when i got full on drunk after my first cocktail, i made a mental note (in the limited capacity that i could) to come back to li po the very next time circumstances call for getting completely loaded in a small, non-scenester invaded, non-pretentious bar in chinatown.  makes me smile just to think of it ...

i should add that even though this place does feel just a wee bit divey, the drink prices are not cheap.  that said, the $7 mai tai i had was well worth every penny .  cheers to getting your money's worth ;)
author: Eleanore T.

description:
this place is always a must for late night china town/north beach cocktails.
-extremely interesting people inside....i think they've probably been there for 20 years....
-i recommend the Mai Tai..it will get you twwwwiiiisssted!
yay for li po!
author: Victoria D.

description: if you're looking for something cheap, go here! they offer so much promos in their drinks that it's fairly impossible not to go home feeling a little light! it's not your high-class bar but hey, the people here are nice and everybody just comes here to drink so what the hell right? this should be one of the most popular bars inside chinatown. we enjoyed our stay and as soon as visit SF again, we'd definitely hit this joint again.
author: Paolo P.

description: This place has some serious style - splashes of color everywhere! No other dive has been able to compare to the extreme mix of hipster bar-goers and neighborhood regulars. I like that it's off of the regular beaten path...makes you feel like you found a diamond in the rough. Plus, with nights like Sweater Funk...you're liable to get yourself into some serious dancin' while you sip on your fav. beverage. :-)
author: Katy A.

description: Stopped by to see the midnight crowd a couple of times... a jukebox that quits after playing two of five songs through a single computer speaker, television playing the Chinese Price is Right and then an infomercial on American Patriotism, people eating steamed beef jerky, violent yelling at dice games...
author: Rob R.

description: This is great if you want something raw and underground. As you enter the main bar, you'd never think that they host bands downstairs. Bands play in a concrete tomb of some sort. It's a serious death trap -- a storage area turned into a music venue. There's only one way in or out and no windows. Heaven forbid there's a fire or anything. It's a great place to rock out but not for the paranoid.
author: Elsie M.

description:
i hold a special place in my heart for this place because this is where i got my first DJ gig in san francisco years ago ... in the dungeon basement. apparently rumour has it a few years ago, when they were gutting the basement and cleaning it up to make a dj space down there, they found a dead body hidden in the wall. not surprising. 

so anyways, i used to spin records here every thursday night with a couple of guys (who went on to run EZ5 - see my EZ5 review). the night was pretty dead. the space was cool for a short time, but it's sort of lost it's appeal to me. i don't think they have any more dj nights here - just crappy bands play here now. the upstairs bar is ok. i come here every once in a while - if i'm in chinatown. the jukebox is pretty funny ... they used to have this one cd in there where the cd cover shows the band posing and the guitarist was missing a hand ... not sure if they still have that cd in there - but look for it when you're there.
author: James J.

description: I suggest coming here on a rainy night when the power is out in chinatown and there is a raging fire down the street.  as you enter this bar, largely emtpy, yet smoke is wafting around, you'll feel like it's 1926 and you're starring in a movie about vice in san francisco.  order ng ka py and tsingtao and play dice.
author: Lita F.

description: I went to Li Po to watch a show, and was so glad I discovered this little hole in the wall.  Very cool ambiance and full of a diverse group of people - regulars, Chinatown residents, hipsters, etc.  - all having a good time.  4 stars only because the drinks come in plastic cups.
author: Carol R.

description: Four Stars for the soft-core Booby Touch Game! That thing is endlessly fascinating after 4 cocktails. For some reason my girlfriends and I won't play it until we're good and buzzed, but once that happens it's ON!!!!!!!
author: stephanie c.

description: A dive can never be 5-star, but this one comes close. I was there for the first time the other night and sampled 2 or 3 of their house-specialty Mai Tai's. I don't remember exactly because they knocked me on my ass so thoroughly I was dead drunk in less than an hour and didn't recover my senses for another three. And the headache. Oh, the headache.
author: Brett L.

description: Haven't been to the downstairs music room.  Some friends and I actually came in here to rest our feet after tramping around Union Square all afternoon.  I found it to be a cozy little dive that wasn't afraid to milk the whole chinatown opium-den-cum-dragon's-cave vibe.  The bartendress talked us into trying some sort of Mai Tai made with a mystery liquor that was made with voodoo power on a forbidden island and brought there by pirates, or something.  Good stuff.
author: Wes M.

description: You don't think of Chinatown as a nightime destination, but this is a great little dive bar worth checking out when you're in the mood for something different.
author: shoba d.

description: Stumbled in here one time when I was new to SF. There was a small cosy group of graduating students celebrating. The bartender, obviously sotted old chinese guy, poured no joke 10 boilermakers and proceeded to light them. The fire spread across the bar in blue flame. My friend and I rushed back to the wall. The bartender casually attempted to stifle the burning bar with a "handy" alcohol-soaked bar-rag. The rag caught on fire. A woman came out of the back shouting incomprehensibly but sensibly bearing dry towels. The fire burned all the alcohol quickly and was soon out. We ordered some beers and hung back for a bit.
author: matt c.

description: So I've been here a few times- usually for a show and let me tell you that their mai tai is rockin. They have a "secret" ingredient that is in some crazy bottle with asian writing on it. That stuff takes you to another place let me tell you.  The downstairs dungeon is a little stuffy, but when you are getting your dance on with a mai tai in one hand it is all good.
author: Erica B.

description: Ah, the Li-Po. An Asian boy-prince among dive bars. 70's decor with an entrance made-up to look like a cave. Cheap beer, old men playing dice and yelling at each other in Chinese (I'm assuming here). An old cheezy Chinese guy in a blue adidas track suit with a cigarillo tried to buy us all beers to impress our lady friends. It was a banner evening. Downstairs, past the bathrooms and through the stockroom is a big, cement former opium-den (also local legend?) where there are cool basement shows. Check it out.
author: Alex C.

description: Order the "Chinese Whiskey".  It tastes like Thai Iced tea with a Chuck Norris roundhouse in the face.  Order a Mai Tai, they are the best in the city here.  Play some tabletop video games, listen to 70s soft rock, and admire the scenery.  This place is great if you are drunk and looking for a fun bartender to talk to.
author: Ben H.

description: This is the perfect bar in my book. The booths are nice and dark with graffiti on the walls (I sat in the one with the sad dead bird in it). The bartender was very nice and seemed somewhat high. The patrons here are generally friendly. The jukebox also has a great selection of old 50's rock and 70's soul. Life can't get any better.
author: kArlos A.

description: This has to be one of the most fabulous bars to stop in for a drink.  It has a great atmosphere, Jackie has to be one of the best bartenders ever, every time I have been here she has kept me laughing for sure. The drinks are great, especially  the Chinese Mai Thais and cinnamon-ny shots.  This is not a place filled with typical b.s. it is a nice down to earth bar that you can go and relax and have fun in. I always have a fabulous time here.
author: Sunshine S.

description: I swear to God, I have used communal village toilets in rural China in 1987 that were cleaner and better maintained than Li Po's bathrooms. But those village bogs were built over pig pens and did not server Blue Moon, so Li Po gets my vote as the place to sit at the bar and drink beer when your S.O. is visiting every single crap tourist trap of a Chinese store on Grant Street.
author: Paul M.

description: Holy crap. . . .I grew up in this neighborhood as a kid.  How on earth did I not know about this dive bar.  Shame on me. . .dang this place is hella "Big Trouble in Little China" feel to it.  Enter the door and yes, all those cheesy, made in china,  decor is all about this place.  Lanterns, Chinese Gods, protection and hope you get rich symbols all about.  And my people love golds and reds, so expect a lot of those colors in here.  I say stick with beers and shots here, cuz the bartenders, who look like a dad and daughter duo, aren't very good at mixed drinks.  In front is the bar area, with three booths to sit in the back.  There's an upstairs that's chained off, but look, a basement area.  Besides the typical nasty bathrooms down there, is an area where bands play gigs here.  No ventilation down here, barely any lighting with random couches (that Salvation Army probably wouldn't take) and coffee tables.  Went to a punk rock show and I can guarantee, it smelled like a boys locker room down here.  This place looks like the carpet hasn't been maintained since it was first installed, but hey, my people are cheap.  LOL!  Surprised that the crowd was an assorted bunch, but man, my ghetto redneck Chinese peeps were here too.  They sure were loud, cussing, bad fashion and definitely FOBs, playing dice games at the bar.  It makes me want to cringe just thinking of it.  Overall, its a cool spot to just grab a drink, admire the decor, chat up to an hour or two, but that's it.  Move on to the next bar, but yeah, tourist would eat this place up.  I can totally see it.  Even with their bag of San Francisco t-shirts and dollar Chinese fans in tow.
author: Janice F.

description: A grotto of cheap drinks (1 star), great music (1 star), awesome peeps (1 star), Chinese heritage (1 star) and multiple spaces of revelry (1 star) = 5 stars!
author: Nat Z.

description: Li Po rocks. I have actually never ordered a drink at this bar... but I love Photo Hunt.
author: Christy H.

description: I loved Li Po.  Went there with a group.  Was talked in to a bad Chinese beer by the bartender before I came to my senses and ordered a real beer.  The decor alone is worth the trip.  It's a place you must go at least once while in SF, then stumble over to the Buddha Lounge.  The huge lantern and the dark red corner gave Li Po's an odd feel like you'd just were digging through the center of the earth and passed through hell as you made your way to China. Had a very good time there, but don't know what it's like on a regular night.
author: Surf R.

description: Many a fond memory at the Li Po. I haven't been in years but to me it's always gonna be 4 stars.
author: Angela K.

description: This is a San Francisco institution, and I am embarassed to say that I went for the first time last night. Right in the heart of china town, it ooozes dive bar charm and the gong that they ring for last call and birthdays has been there since 1937. They have dice behind the bar if you ask them and its a popular activity there. We were there on Thursday and it was practically empty, which I love, but I can't vouch for a Saturday night.
author: Kai H.

description:
Five things great about Li Po.

1. Daniel's famous Mai Tai topped off with ancient chinese wine.
2. Drinking games in the red vinyl booths in the back.
3. No Mama Candie's ear wrenching karaoke.
4. Order takeout from local restaurants to enjoy with your drinks.
5. Intriguing converstations with friends, regular patrons and curious tourists.
author: Jerry H.

description: Mai Tais with "special secret" chinese liquor, microwave popcorn, multiple Buddha statues, and a broken photo booth? That's a 10 in my book. Anyone trekking to SF should stop in to the Li Po Room for a cocktail.
author: Jen A.

description: I've only been here once for a friend's birthday get to together but it was loads of fun! Well, loads of fun in the sense that there was good company and liquor! Their music selection in their tiny little jukebox doesn't have anything past the 80s and it's a puzzle to figure out who are the people in there. If you can read Chinese and know some of the Chinese singers, there is even a bigger variety to chose from. But the bartenders/(I guess)the owners are really friendly. And no one can beat the decor with their red vinyl bar stools.
author: janet j.

description: Not so sure about this place. Talk about random. At least they had erotic photo hunt and an almost broke pacman. It's definitely different and out there so if that's what you're looking for, this is the place. I heard about the basement stuff but I guess it was closed the night I went so maybe I just didn't get the full experience like some have.
author: Mike C.

description: The bar itself is a kick - the drink prices aren't bad (although I mostly stick to Tsing Tao), the feel of the place is authentic and thoroughly non-touristy, and the clientele are mixed and interesting.  The basement "event" area, I have to say, is like something out of a bad movie - dingy, dark, a claustrophobia-inducing ceiling, and smells funny.  But even that has a sort of charm, I guess - if you are with the right people.  Go there with someone who speaks Chinese, or you may have some trouble getting what you want.
author: Peter V.

description: punk rock shows in Chinatown?  yup!  first off, Li Po has pretty much all you could ask for in a Chinatown bar.  excellent atmosphere, kitschy decor, cheap cocktails, jukebox, and very fast and friendly bar service.  despite the crowd i didn't wait for a drink all night.  walk down to the basement where the bands are playing and you are suddenly transported to a very intimate music venue that feels very much like a house show.  if i lived closer this would definitely be a regular spot.
author: Alex K.

description: i can't believe i forgot to review LiPo...... can't say much more than, its exactly what a Chinatown Dive should be like. dark, cave-like, empty and a little bit scary. perfect for those nights when you dont want anyone to find you. i used to come here when i lived in north beach and was hiding from my Ex. just kidding Jim. located right on grant. easy access. this could also be one of those places you go to drown your sorrows. not that i ever did that, but someday i plan on coming here in a surly mood and drinking till i fall off the bar stool. wow, i have such lofty goals.
author: Michelle I.

description: the bartender here also bought me a shot.  but the downstairs basement is wicked eerie.
author: Pickle R.

description: li po is li perfect!  big red booths in back are apparently the place to make out.  not that i would know.  bartender (i'm pretty sure she is also the owner) is friendly and more importantly, not stingy with the booze or pretzels.  the juke box selection is fucking horrendous, the worst i've ever seen.  i'm talking dead cantonese stars and celine dion.  some nights, scenesters like to hear their own kind play downstairs but it's best to avoid those nights and hit this place mid day during the week.  top notch!
author: Laura B.

description: There was a crazy emo white guy DJing there last Saturday in the basement and I had the time of my life. He played 80's and fun dancing music off his lap top. Everyone was going nuts dancing- even though there were a couple different groups of strangers we all hung out and had a blast. Pretty shady but an awesome dive bar.
author: H J.

description: seems/looks old as china itself, interior is all china (exactly as you would expect and imagine), walk in, go around the window, and immediately greeted by the bar.  small curve in the front and one in the corner.  about 18 stools, all nicely covered in red leather/vinyl.  nice blacktop bar with a classic wood rail.  bar back with chinese drawings and decorations.  buddha shrine in the corner.  rarely comment on price, but the cocktails were somewhat expensive (small, small glasses, basically shot glasses), but also strong (1 and 1/2 shots probably).  a double will cost you $12 and not worth the price.  past the bar are a few tables for groups.  only one smaller tv and no food (can bring it in with no complaints).  felt kind of tourist-y, maybe because it is on the same street as many of the shops or because there was not a single asian in the place aside from the bartender.  may be a dive bar in the sense that lipo is dirty and only takes cash, but i would attribute that more to the thriftiness of the owners.
author: D h.

description: let's put on a punk rock show every sunday, all day, at this place.
author: r b.

description: sweet surreal dive bar in chinatown.  big red vinyl booths, old chinese dudes playing the so-bad-it's-good jukebox, and bottles of beer.  surprisingly expensive, but you're paying for... the scene.
author: sunny d.

description: li po rules.  the last time we went the guy behind the bar hooked us up with some stiff drinks with some kind of super chinese alcohol. we asked him what it was but he wouldn't tell us..or maybe he did, we just couldn't understand what he was saying.  anyway, it was really good but my friend brett's tummy didn't like it.
author: Richard K.
